questions.text: A 30-year-old man with chronic osteomyelitis presented with purulent discharge from a wound in his right leg. A swab was collected and Gram staining showed the following finding. Identify the incorrect statement about the causative organism.

choices.text: The organism is tube coagulase positive.
On culture, golden yellow pigments are produced on nutrient agar.
Beta-hemolysis is seen on blood agar.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the gram stain showing gram-positive cocci in clusters are suggestive of Staphylococcus aureus. The incorrect statement about S. aureus is that it is catalase negative. S. aureus is catalase positive, whereby it can be differentiated from the catalase-negative streptococci.

S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus arranged in grape-like clusters that may cause various pyogenic infections like a carbuncle, furuncle, abscess, osteomyelitis, and even septicemia. On nutrient agar culture, smooth, shiny, easily emulsifiable golden yellow-pigmented colonies (option C) are formed due to the presence of β-carotene. On a nutrient agar slope, the confluent growth presents a characteristic oil-paint appearance. On blood agar, it shows a wide zone of beta (complete) hemolysis with sharp edges. (Option D)

Biochemical tests of S. aureus are as follows:

Staphylococci produce catalase, which converts hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen and produces bubbles, as shown below.

S. aureus is coagulase positive. The coagulase test can be done using two methods:

  • The tube test detects free coagulase. When 0.1 mL of an agar culture suspension of S. aureus is added to 0.5 mL of human or rabbit plasma in a test tube with an anticoagulant and incubated in a water bath at 37°C for 3–6 hours, the plasma clots and does not flow when the tube is tilted. This shows a tube coagulase-positive test. Prolonged incubation is avoided as the clot may be lysed by the fibrinolysin produced by a few strains.

  • The slide test detects bound coagulase (clumping factor). The bacterial isolate is emulsified with a drop of saline and added with a drop of rabbit or human plasma. A prompt clumping of the cocci is suggestive of a positive test. It should be performed after ensuring the absence of autoagglutination and can be positive for S. aureus and for a few strains of coagulase-negative staphylococcus. 

The below image shows positive and negative tube coagulase tests.

 

S. aureus are indole negative, methyl red (MR), and Voges-Proskauer (VP) positive. They hydrolyze urea, reduce nitrates to nitrites, and liquefy gelatin.

The organism is also positive for enzymes like nuclease, hyaluronidase, and hydrolase. It produces cytolytic toxins such as hemolysins (α, β, γ, δ), Panton-Valentine leucocidin, toxic shock syndrome toxin, and enterotoxins, which are responsible for staphylococcal food poisoning.

The typing of bacterial strains can be done by phenotypic and molecular methods. Phenotypic methods involve the typing of the strain according to its susceptibility to bacteriophages. This method needed periodic revision of the reference phages and is not used now.

The image below shows the golden yellow colonies of S. aureus. 

Related Pearl: Cutaneous Infections/Diseases caused by Staphylococcus aureus

  • Ecthyma
  • Folliculitis
  • Furunculosis

  • Sycosis

B. Secondary infection

  • Eczema, infestations, ulcers, etc.

C. Cutaneous disease due to effect of bacterial toxin

  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)
  • Toxic shock syndrome
  • Staphylococcal scarlatina
  • Recurrent toxin‐mediated perineal erythema

questions.text: A male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with intermittent rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and mucous discharge. He passes 4–5 stools a day. Histological examination showed the following lesion. What is the first-line management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of crypt abscesses and other symptoms are consistent with moderate ulcerative colitis and may be treated with sulfasalazine (5-amino salicylic acid agents), glucocorticoids, immunosuppressants, and biologics. 
The treatment differs based on the severity of the disease.

Ulcerative colitis is characterized by the involvement of the rectum and colon. Patients usually present with rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and mucous discharge per rectum. Generally, in most cases, the condition is confined to the rectal area but may spread proximally. 

Ulcerative colitis is graded based on the frequency of bowel movements and systemic involvement. 

  • Mild disease - ≤4 stools per day with/without rectal bleeding;
  • Moderate disease - ≥4 stools per day with few systemic signs of illness; 
  • Severe disease - ≥6 blood stools per day with fever, tachycardia (≥90 beats/min), anemia (hemoglobin <10.5 g/dL), and elevated levels of inflammatory markers (ESR ≥30 mm/h)
  • Fulminant disease - >10 stools per day with severe anemia requiring blood transfusion and progressive colonic dilation (toxic megacolon)

5-ASA agents can be given to patients with mild to moderate disease.
Glucocorticoids, immunosuppressants, and biologics are effective in patients with moderate to severe disease.
Surgery is indicated in patients with fulminant disease.

Other options: 

Option B: Resection of the affected colon/surgery for ulcerative colitis is indicated when there is an intractable disease, fulminant disease, toxic megacolon, colonic perforation, massive colonic hemorrhage, colon dysplasia or cancer, colonic obstruction, or extracolonic manifestations.

Option C: Avoid NSAIDS (except for acetaminophen) since these medications may sometimes worsen symptoms.

Option D: Antibiotics generally have no role in the treatment of ulcerative colitis, except when patients develop pouchitis after colectomy and ileal pouch–anal anastomosis (IPAA).

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman is 20 weeks pregnant. She mentions that her previous labour was prolonged and tedious and eventually the doctor used an instrument to deliver her first child. What size of the marked diameter would point towards the diagnosis of cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
The marked diameter is diagonal conjugate (from the lower end of pubic symphysis to the sacral promontory). Cephalo-pelvic disproportion (CPD) at the pelvic inlet is diagnosed when the diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm. 

Cephalopelvic disproportion is a state where the normal proportion between the size of the fetus to the size of the pelvis is disturbed. It can either occur due to an average size baby with a small pelvis or a relatively large baby with a normal pelvis.

A history of prolonged or tedious labor, followed by either spontaneous or difficult instrumental delivery is suggestive of pelvic contraction. Difficult vaginal delivery ending in a stillborn or neonatal death without any etiological factor also suggests a contracted pelvis. Past history of fracture, rickets, osteomalacia, tuberculosis of the pelvic joints or spines, and poliomyelitis is elicited.

CPD can occur at the inlet, mid pelvis, or at the pelvic outlet. It is diagnosed at these levels by the following measurements.

  • Inlet CPD
    • Anteroposterior diameter < 10 cm
    • Diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm
    • Transverse diameter < 12 cm
  • Midpelvis CPD
    • Sum of the interspinous and posterior sagittal diameters of the mid pelvis </= 13.5 cm
    • Interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  • Outlet CPD
    • Interischial diameter </= 8 cm

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient came to the hospital with rashes, arthralgia, myalgia, and photosensitivity for a week. She was diagnosed with tuberculosis and has been on anti-tubercular treatment for the past 3 months. She has no past history of similar episodes. What is the most probable diagnosis for her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the patient's current symptoms is drug-induced lupus erythematosus (DILE).

Isoniazid is one of the most common causes of DILE. The rash is spread over both cheeks, forming the typical malar rash. The patient also has other systemic symptoms including arthralgia and myalgia. The patient will be positive for anti-histone antibodies.

Drug-induced lupus usually occurs after 2-3 months of exposure to the offending drug and will spontaneously resolve on stopping the drug.

Drugs that cause DILE:
Procainamide, disopyramide, propafenone, hydralazine, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, beta-blockers, propylthiouracil, chlorpromazine, lithium, carbamazepine, phenytoin, isoniazid, minocycline, nitrofurantoin, sulfasalazine, hydrochlorothiazide, lovastatin, simvastatin, interferon, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors.

These medications sometimes induce ANA in patients who do not develop DILE. So, it is necessary to test for ANA first and decide on the withdrawal of the drug on the basis of the results.

Other options :

Option A - Irritant contact dermatitis is an inflammatory condition due to exogenous agents. The lesions are well-defined and may range from minimal erythema to ulcers. Hands (intertriginous areas) are most commonly involved. The most common agents include chronic wet work, soaps, and detergents.

Option B - Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by multiple sharply defined dull red to brown lesions due to some drugs. The patient has no history pertaining to the abovementioned conditions. On re-exposure, the lesions develop in the same site but may spread. Common locations include lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa. It causes a burning sensation. Common drug associations include pseudoephedrine (produces a non-pigmenting reaction), phenolphthalein (present in laxatives), sulfonamides, tetracyclines, NSAIDs, and barbiturates.

Option D - There is no relevant history regarding drug interactions.

The image shown below is of a healed fixed drug eruption on the glans penis.

questions.text: During a microbiology experiment, the gene for diphtheria toxin from Corynebacterium diphtheriae is carried on corynebacteriophages, and the toxin is produced only by the bacteria that are lysogenized by the phages. Which of the following methods of horizontal gene transfer is outlined in the above example?
questions.solution:
The transfer of genes for diphtheria toxin on a corynebacteriophage occurs by transduction.

Transduction can be defined as the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage. This type of horizontal gene transfer may occur by two mechanisms:

  • Lytic cycle - In the lytic cycle, also known as the virulent cycle, a large number of progeny phages build up inside the host bacterium; eventually, the host cell ruptures, releasing the bacteriophages. Some of the bacteriophages will now contain bacterial DNA, which can then be transferred to other bacteria.
  • Lysogenic cycle - In the temperate or non-lytic cycle, the host bacterium is not lysed. Rather, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome. This phage DNA multiplies with the host cell and is transferred to daughter cells. 

Option A - Conjugation is the method of gene transfer in bacteria that involves physical contact by a male or donor bacterium with a female or recipient bacterium through an extracellular protein extrusion or appendage called the sex pili. The genetic material that is transferred is usually derived from plasmids. The bacteria that possess the ability to form the sex pili contain the F+ plasmid and are designated as F+. The F+ bacteria can transfer a single strand of the F+ plasmid DNA to F- bacteria via the sex pili. 

Option C - Transformation is the direct uptake of naked DNA by the bacterial cell from the environment. Several bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria undergo transformation. 

Option D - Transposition is a process of gene transfer that involves special segments of DNA called transposons (jumping genes).

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman who presented with abnormal uterine bleeding is scheduled for endometrial biopsy. In her case file, you see her transvaginal sonography report. What is the endometrial thickness you are expecting to see?
questions.solution:
In a postmenopausal woman with abnormal uterine bleeding, investigations like endometrial sampling is indicated when the endometrial thickness is >4 mm. Since the patient is posted for an endometrial biopsy, the thickness of her endometrium is likely to be more than 4 mm. 

Timing Endometrial thickness
Immediately after menstruation 1–2 mm
Early proliferative phase 5–7 mm
Secretory phase 7–16 mm
Preovulatory phase  up to 12 mm
Postmenopausal (Asymptomatic) <4 mm
Postmenopausal with bleeding; investigations should start when the thickness is >4 mm

An endometrial biopsy can be done by

  • Dilatation and curettage
  • Uterine cavity aspiration using a pipelle and endometrial sampling (office biopsy)

Indications for endometrial sampling:

  • Any woman aged >45 years with abnormal uterine bleeding
  • A woman aged <45 years with exposure to excessive estrogen, such as those with polycystic ovary disease, severe obesity, or tamoxifen treatment
  • Women with failed medical management and persistent bleeding
  • Transvaginal ultrasound showing an endometrial thickness of >12 mm in premenopausal women and >4 mm in postmenopausal women

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about direct ophthalmoscope?

choices.text: It produces a real, inverted image
It produces a magnification of 15 times
Fundus view is possible upto ora serrata
Area of the field in focus is about 8 disc diameter

questions.solution:
A direct ophthalmoscope produces an image magnification of 15 times. 

Direct Ophthalmoscopy:

  • The most commonly practiced method for routine fundus examination.
  • Direct ophthalmoscopy should be performed in a semi-darkroom and the patient's right eye should be examined by the right eye of the observer and the patient's left eye with the observer's left eye.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
A spindle-shaped wound with clean-cut margins as seen in the image indicates an incised wound. 

An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument, through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. The length of the wound is more than the depth and width.

The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is more at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

Other options:

Option A- A laceration is a tear or a split in the skin, mucous membrane, muscle, or any internal organ produced by blunt force. They are also termed tears or ruptures. 

Margins are irregular and ragged. Tears that are seen at the ends, diverging away from the main laceration are called swallow-tails. Bruising is seen around the wound.

Deeper tissues are unevenly divided with tissue tags at the bottom of the wound. Hair and epidermal tags are driven deeply into the wound and hair bulbs are crushed. The depth of the wound contains abundant foreign material. 

Classification of a laceration:

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration)
    • This occurs when the skin is crushed between two hard objects
  • Stretch laceration
    • It occurs due to the over-stretching of the fixed skin.
    • Usually seen in run over by a motor vehicle, kicking, and compound fractures
  • Avulsion or shearing laceration
    • An avulsion is a lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues due to shearing force delivered at an acute angle
    • This is common in road traffic accidents
  • Tears - Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue can occur from localized impact
  • Cut laceration - Deep and wide cut over the body tissues by a heavily sharp-edged instrument

The below image shows a lacerated wound.


Option B- Incised-like lacerated wounds are seen at sites where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue. A blunt force on the areas of the skin close to the bone causes linear splitting of the tissue which results in the laceration resembling an incised wound. There will be some tissue crushing present but the margins will be relatively sharp. 

The common sites are the scalp, forehead, eyebrows, zygoma, lower jaw, perineum, shin, and iliac crest.

The image below shows incised-like lacerated wound.


Option C- Chop wounds or slash wounds are deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with a heavy sharp cutting-edged weapon. The dimensions of the wound correspond to the crosssection of the penetrating part of the weapon. The margins are sharp and show slight abrasion and bruising with the destruction of underlying organs. The presence of an incised wound on the skin with an underlying fracture or deep grove in the bone indicates a chop wound.

The image below shows a chop wound.

questions.text: All of the following are included among the major criteria of the modified Duke's criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, except _____.

choices.text: Echocardiography showing endocardial involvement with definite vegetations
Coxiella burnetii anti-phase I IgG antibody titer greater than 1:800
At least two consecutive positive blood cultures for Coxiella burnetii

questions.solution:
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii is one of the major criteria of modified Duke's criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. All other options are true.

Infective endocarditis is associated with bacterial or fungal infection of the valvular or endocardial surface of the heart. The definitive diagnosis can only be established by histological and microbiological examinations of the vegetation.

However, a diagnostic schema called, modified Duke criteria, is usually used for diagnosis. The criteria are based on clinical, laboratory, and echocardiographic findings commonly encountered in patients with endocarditis, as described below.

The diagnosis is made based on the presence of

  • Two major criteria, or
  • One major and three minor criteria, or
  • Five minor criteria.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A patient presents with endophthalmitis 5 days after cataract surgery. All of the following treatments can be used, except _____.
questions.solution:
Intravenous steroids are not used for the treatment of endophthalmitis.

Endophthalmitis is defined as an intraocular inflammation that predominantly affects the inner spaces of the eye and their contents, i.e. the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber. The cardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid and diminished vision. Once the endophthalmitis sets in it is important to treat all the cases empirically with a combination of antibiotics and steroids from the beginning.

Steroids are given in endophthalmitis to reduce the inflammation of the tissues. The preferred route of administration is either by intravitreal injections, topical concentrations or oral route. Intravenous route of administration of steroids is not used in endophthalmitis.

Acute postoperative bacterial endophthalmitis occurs within 1-7 days after cataract surgery and the most important factor to prevent it is preoperative administration of 5% povidone iodine.

The various drugs,routes and surgical management used to treat endophthalmitis are as follows:

  • The mainstay of treatment is intravitreal injections of antibiotics.
                 First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus ceftazidime 2.25mg in 0.1ml.
                 Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg in 0.1 mL plus amikacin 0.4mg in 0.1ml.
    If there is no improvement, a repeat intravitreal injection should be given after 48 hours
  • Topical Solutions of antibiotics are started immediately and used frequently
                 Vancomycin (50mg/ml) or cefazolin (50mg/ml)
                 Amikacin (20mg/ml) or tobramycin
  • Systemic antibiotics have a limited role in the treatment but are commonly used in practice.
  • Steroid therapy includes
                 Intravitreal injection of Dexamethasone(0.4mg in 0.1ml) which is started along with antibiotics.
                 Topical Dexamethasone (0.1%)
                 Oral steroids such as prednisolone are started after 24 hours of intensive antibiotic therapy.
  • Supportive therapy are
                 Cycloplegics such as Atropine 1%
                 Anti-Glaucoma drugs such as oral acetazolamide or timolol in patients with raised intraocular pressure
  • Vitrectomy- Pars Plana Vitrectomy is done if the patient does not improve with the above therapy in 48-72 hours or when the visual acuity is reduced to hand movements near the eye.

questions.text:
A young boy was diagnosed to have pituitary adenoma. The physical appearance of this boy is shown in the image given below. If you were to compare his early morning ACTH levels with those of a normal person, how would they differ?

ACTH - Adrenocorticotropic hormone

choices.text: ACTH level lower than that of the normal person
ACTH level same as that in the normal person
ACTH level higher than that of the normal person

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the typical physical appearance and presence of pituitary adenoma, is suggestive of Cushing's disease. Early morning ACTH levels in patients with Cushing's disease would be much higher than those of normal individuals. 

Cushing’s disease is caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. The increased ACTH causes increased cortisol production, about three times more than the normal level.

The illustration given below shows the clinical features of Cushing's syndrome.

Administration of large doses of dexamethasone can be used to differentiate between ACTH-dependent and ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome.

The illustration given below shows the diagnostic algorithm to determine the cause of Cushing syndrome.

In normal physiologic states, the ACTH levels are higher in the early morning as compared to the rest of the day. However, they are not as high as those with Cushing's disease.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with developmental delay and multiple seizure types. The electroencephalogram (EEG) is shown below. Which of the following anti-epileptics can be used for the management of this patient?
  1. Valproate
  2. Topiramate
  3. Lamotrigine
  4. Gabapentin
  5. Vigabatrin
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and an electroencephalogram (EEG) showing 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep are suggestive of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. The drugs used for this condition are valproate, lamotrigine, topiramate, clobazam, and rufinamide,

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome- Typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years. Consists of a triad of:

  • Developmental delay
  • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
  • EEG findings 1–2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness

The seizures can result in frequent falls and injuries. Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies. Clobazam or valproate can be used for drop attacks. In resistant cases, a ketogenic diet, corticosteroids, and intravenous immunoglobulin can be tried.

Below are the EEG characteristics of various types of seizure and their treatment.

Disease Typical EEG features Drug of choice
Lennox–Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep Valproate 
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern) Ethosuximide
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike polyspike and slow-wave discharges Valproate 
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

It is advisable to refrain from using gabapentin, oxcarbazepine, pregabalin, tiagabine, and vigabatrin due to their potential to exacerbate myoclonic seizures or to be ineffective.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman was admitted by her parents due to inappropriate behaviour for the past 7 months. In the OPD, she constantly wandered about, pointed aimlessly at her surroundings, burst into laughter without any reason, and made lip-sucking actions. She said that an evil giant was always around her, although no one was near her. Lack of personal care and unorganised behaviour were also noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young woman with inappropriate, bizarre behaviour, aimless activity, presence of delusions, and lack of personal care points towards a diagnosis of schizophrenia, which is likely to be of the hebephrenic or disorganised type.

Hebephrenic schizophrenia (disorganised) has an early onset, generally occurring before 25 years of age. It is characterised by marked regression of behaviour that becomes disorganised and poor contact with reality. Lack of personal care and aimless non-constructive activity is also usually noted. Social behaviour and emotional responses are inappropriate. Sometimes, these patients may burst out laughing or have inappropriate grinning or grimacing behaviour. It has the worst prognosis after simple schizophrenia. 

Schizophrenia is a psychotic disorder with the following criteria: 

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within these 6 months, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms), where 2 or more of the following have to be present (at least one must be among the a, b, or c): 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behaviour
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

3. The rest of the 6 months may include

  • Continuing psychotic symptoms
  • Prodromal symptoms preceding clear-cut psychosis
  • Residual symptoms after the resolution of the psychotic symptoms

4. Residual symptoms are defined as attenuated forms of psychotic symptoms, such as

  • Odd beliefs
  • Magical thinking
  • Ideas of reference
  • Odd perceptual experiences
  • Peculiar or concrete thinking
  • Vague speech
  • Odd behaviour
  • Negative symptoms may also be included

5. Exclusion of mood disorder & substance abuse

Other types of schizophrenia

Paranoid schizophrenia:

  • Most common type.
  • Often called paraphrenia in progressive deterioration. 
  • Usual onset in 3rddecade
  • Characterized by delusions of persecution, grandeur, control, etc.
  • Can be associated with hallucination

Catatonic schizophrenia:

  • Marked disturbance in motor function
  • May involve stupor, negativism, rigidity, excitement, or posturing
  • Alteration between extremes of excitement and stupor
  • Best prognosis
  • Term coined by Kahlbaum

Simple schizophrenia:

  • The primary symptom is withdrawal from social and work-related situations
  • Characterized by a gradual, insidious loss of drive and ambition
  • Do not experience persistent hallucinations or delusions
  • Poor prognosis (simple > hebephrenic)

Related Pearl: Symptoms of schizophrenia

Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Hallucination
Delusion
Bizarre motor acts
Flattening of affect
Anhedonia
Alogia
Apathy
Paucity of thought
Poverty of speech
Common in acute schizophrenia Common in chronic schizophrenia
Hyperactivity of the dopaminergic system in the mesolimbic system Hypoactivity of the dopaminergic system in the mesocortical system

questions.text: A renowned artist was started on medication for a chronic ailment. After a couple of weeks, he started painting a series of artworks with a typical yellow predominance shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs can cause yellowing of vision?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of yellowing of vision (xanthopsia). It is an early indication of digoxin toxicity.

It can also be an adverse effect of thiazide diuretics like chlorthalidone, hydrochlorothiazide, indapamide.

Digoxin is the cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation/flutter.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter to increase intracellular sodium. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by the sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

Note: Sildenafil use can characteristically lead to blue-green tinting of vision.

Other options:

Option A: Ethambutol is an antitubercular drug. It can cause retrobulbar neuritis and red-green color blindness.

Option C: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic drug. It causes corneal verticillata, photosensitivity, blue-gray discoloration that occurs in body areas when exposed to sunlight, hypo or hyperthyroidism, and pulmonary fibrosis.

The image given below shows corneal verticillata. Note the whorl-like corneal pattern of cream-colored lines on the cornea.

Option D: Chloroquine is an antimalarial drug. Adverse effects of chloroquine include headache, blurring of vision, lichenoid skin eruptions, bleaching of hair, and widened QRS interval. High doses may lead to irreversible retinopathy and ototoxicity.

questions.text: The given sign is most prominent after how many hours of death?
questions.solution:
This picture shows postmortem marbling, i.e. greenish brown or purplish red discoloration of superficial veins. It becomes most prominent after 36-48 hours of death. 

Marbling is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfmeth-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36–48 hours after death.

It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins. Intestinal bacteria infest the venous system, and there is subsequent gas production and hemolysis, which stains the vessel walls. This becomes prominent in the summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

questions.text: A male patient presents with hearing difficulty and tinnitus. On examination of his ear, you note numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal. MRI showed acoustic neuroma. Involvement of which of the following nerves is responsible for numbness in his ear?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of numbness in the posterosuperior meatal wall of the external auditory canal is suggestive of the Hitzelberger sign. It is seen in acoustic neuroma and occurs due to facial nerve involvement.

Acoustic neuroma is also called a vestibular schwannoma or an eighth nerve tumor. It arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve. It is the most common cerebellopontine angle tumor and is associated with neurofibromatosis 2.

Clinically, patients typically present with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus.

The posterior wall of the auditory canal receives sensory fibers from the CN VII/ facial nerve through the auricular branch of the vagus. Therefore, the involvement of the facial nerve in acoustic neuroma results in hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall, which is called Hitzelberger’s sign.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets presents with normal levels of serum calcium.

X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets has X-linked dominant inheritance. There is a mutation in PHEX gene, which leads to elevated FGF23. FGF23 inhibits renal tubular phosphate absorption, thus leading to its increased excretion.

Clinical features include bony deformities in children. They particularly develop genu valgum or genu varum when they begin to walk. Adults develop heterotrophic bone formation around large joints and ligaments of the spinal canal. This leads to enthesopathies and neurological symptoms.

Laboratory findings include low serum phosphorus level, elevated serum alkaline phosphatase level, but normal serum levels of PTH and calcium.

Treatment includes a combination of phosphorus and calcitriol. The response is monitored by checking the levels of alkaline phosphatase, which tend to normalize on treatment. The balance between phosphorus and calcitriol is very important. Excess phosphorus supplementation will decrease calcium absorption from the intestine, leading to secondary hyperparathyroidism and thus worsening bone lesions. Excess calcitriol on the other hand can cause hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man developed nausea and jaundice over the past week. Laboratory investigations revealed an active hepatitis B infection. Which of the following liver pathology findings is depicted in the slide below?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman's bodies and they represent apoptosis.

Councilman's bodies are acidophilic bodies, which represent hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis. They are mainly seen in acute viral hepatitis.

Apoptosis is a pathway of cell death that is induced by a closely regulated suicide program in which the cells destined to die activate intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells' nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins. 

Mechanism of apoptosis: There are two distinct pathways that can lead to caspase activation and cause apoptosis of the cell.

  • The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway
  • The death receptor or extrinsic pathway

The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • There are several proteins in the mitochondria that can induce apoptosis. These include cytochrome c and some proteins that neutralize the endogenous inhibitors of apoptosis.
  • The permeability of the mitochondria is controlled by a family of proteins called the BCL-2 family, which act as sensors.
  • These sensors are activated when the cells are deprived of growth factors and other survival signals, are exposed to agents that damage the DNA, or accumulate a large number of misfolded proteins.
  • These activated sensors, in turn, activate the proapoptotic molecules like BAX and BAK, which form channels in the mitochondrial membrane, through which cytochrome c and other mitochondrial proteins escape into the cytosol and cause activation of caspase-9, which, in turn, leads to the activation of the caspase cascade and, eventually, apoptosis of the cell.
  • On the other hand, if all the growth factors and other survival signals are present, then they produce more antiapoptotic members of the BH1-4 family like the BCL2, MCL 1, and BCL-XL. These proteins limit the escape of proapoptotic mitochondrial proteins.

The death-receptor (extrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

  • Death receptors are surface molecules that are members of the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) receptor family, like TNF 1 and Fas (CD 95).
  • These receptors are expressed on the surface of many cells and can trigger apoptosis. In the cytoplasmic region, these receptors have a “death domain.”
  • Fas ligand (FasL) is a membrane protein expressed mainly on activated T-lymphocytes. Fas-FasL interactions are required for thymic medullary negative selection. Defective interactions also cause the autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome. 
  • When these T-cells recognize Fas-expressing targets, Fas molecules are cross-linked by FasL and bind adaptor proteins via the death domain.
  • These, in turn, recruit and activate caspase-8 and -10.
  • In many cell types, caspase-8 and -10 may cleave and activate a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family called Bid, thus feeding into the mitochondrial pathway.
  • The combined activation of both pathways delivers a lethal blow to the cell.
  • Cellular proteins, notably, a caspase antagonist called FLIP, block the activation of caspases downstream of the death receptors. Interestingly, some viruses produce homologues of FLIP, and it is suggested that this is a mechanism that viruses use to keep infected cells alive.
  • The death receptor pathway is involved in the elimination of self-reactive lymphocytes and in the killing of target cells by some cytotoxic T-lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old P3L3 lady complained of bright red bleeding per vagina 15 days after the vaginal delivery of her 3rd baby. Which among the following options could be the likely cause of this bleeding?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with bright red vaginal bleeding on the 15th day of postpartum is secondary postpartum hemorrhage, which can be caused by a placental polyp.

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) occurring between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery is called secondary or late PPH.

Causes of secondary PPH include:

  • Placental polyp: Retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and eventually form a placental polyp, which on detachment from the myometrium causes brisk hemorrhage.
  • Abnormal involution of the placental site.
  • Retention of placental cotyledon or products of conception.
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm.
  • Endometritis
  • Coagulopathy

It is treated with oxytocin, methyler­gonovine, or a prostaglandin analog if the patient is stable and sonography reveals an empty uterine cavity. Antimicrobials are given if a uterine infection is suspected. Gentle suction curettage can be done if large clots are seen in the uter­ine cavity on sonography, or if bleeding persists after medical management.

Other options: 

Option A: Multiparity can lead to inadequate retraction and frequently adherent placenta and cause primary PPH.

Option B: Perineal lacerations and an atonic uterus are causes of primary PPH. 

Option C: Atonic uterus is one of the causes of primary PPH.

questions.text: A patient with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome has headaches and an unsteady gait. His MRI brain is given below. Which of the following intracranial tumors is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given coronal T1-weighted (T1WI) MRI of the brain shows a well-defined hypointense lesion in the posterior fossa, and the clinical vignette is suggestive of hemangioblastoma.

Hemangioblastomas are fluid-filled cystic lesions of vascular origin that typically arise in the cerebellum and retina. They occur both in patients with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease as well as sporadically.

VHL disease is characterized by the development of numerous benign and malignant tumors in different organs. It is associated with a mutation in the VHL tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3.

Features of VHL:

  • Pheochromocytoma
  • CNS hemangioblastoma - cerebellar and spinal
  • Retinal hemangioblastoma
  • Choroid plexus papilloma

Option A: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) is usually seen in association with neurofibromatosis type 2. Given below is the MRI showing bilateral cerebellopontine angle masses extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus, which is suggestive of vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma). 

Option C: Meningiomas are primary extra-axial neoplasms arising from the meningothelial arachnoidal cells. It is seen as a well-defined, hyperdense mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially.

Option D: Pilocytic astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults. These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The majority of neoplasms are located in the cerebellum. However, they can also appear around the third ventricle, optic nerves, spinal cord, and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres. The answer here cannot be pilocytic astrocytoma as the clinical case is about VHL. So, hemangioblastoma is the brain tumor associated with VHL, and not pilocytic astrocytoma. Without clinical history, it is difficult to distinguish between the two on radiographs.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency room with a history of recurrent episodes of bloody stool. The following investigation is performed, and the child was found to have Meckel diverticulum. Which of the following radionuclide agents is used for this investigation?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of  99mTc-pertechnetate scintigraphy, which is the most accurate diagnostic test for Meckel's diverticulum in children.

Meckel's diverticulum results from the failure of the yolk sac to close during fetal life. It is located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum. It is usually detected incidentally but can present with gastrointestinal bleeding. The bleeding is usually from a chronic acid-induced ulcer adjacent to a Meckel diverticulum that contains ectopic gastric mucosa.

Radionuclide like the 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in the diverticulum.

 Other uses of 99mTc-pertechnetate:

  • Thyroid imaging
  • Parathyroid imaging to distinguish it from the thyroid gland
  • Testicular imaging

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presented with a prolonged history of fainting spells and palpitations. He is a known case of Brugada syndrome and has been started on quinidine for the same, after which he developed a cardiac rhythm, as shown in the ECG given below. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?

WPW: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

AVNRT: Atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia

choices.text: Torsades  de pointes with QT prolongation

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the given scenario is torsades de pointes with QT interval prolongation.

Quinidine can cause polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, or torsades de pointes, which has been shown in the given ECG. Quinidine is often used in the management of patients with Brugada syndrome, as a class I antiarrhythmic agent (Ia).

Torsades de pointes, which means “twisting of the points,” is a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia characterized by the twisting of the QRS axis around the baseline and a polymorphic appearance. This rhythm is most commonly seen in association with hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia. There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization.

Other cause of torsades de pointes:

  • Drugs like quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide, and phenothiazine (amiodarone is rarely associated with torsades de pointes because the delay in repolarization induced by it is uniform)
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction

Management:

  • Discontinue the offending drug
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, pH, and hypoxia
  • Magnesium sulfate infusion 
  • Increase the heart rate with electrical pacing, isoproterenol infusion, or intravenous atropine 

If the patient is hemodynamically stable, IV MgSO4 is the treatment of choice. IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and prevention of the recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades de pointes.

If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done.

Brugada syndrome is a rare syndrome characterized by >0.2 mV of ST-segment elevation and negative T-wave in more than one anterior precordial lead (V1–V3).

Episodes of syncope or cardiac arrest are common due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) in the absence of structural heart disease, as in Brugada syndrome. Cardiac arrest may occur during sleep or be provoked by febrile illness. Males are more commonly affected than females. Mutations involving cardiac sodium channels are identified in a quarter of cases. Quinidine has been used successfully to suppress frequent episodes of VT.

Drugs

    • Class IA: Quinidine, disopyramide, procainamide
    • Class III: Sotalol, amiodarone (QT prolongation common but torsade ventricular tachycardia is rare), ibutilide, dofetilide, almokalant
  • Antibiotics

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A patient develops a postoperative wound discharge. The culture of the discharge reveals infection with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Which of the following cephalosporins can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ceftaroline, which is considered as anti-MRSA cephalosporin, is indicated for MRSA infections and can, therefore, be used in this patient. It is grouped as fifth-generation cephalosporins along with ceftobiprole.

Ceftaroline has gram-negative and also enhanced gram-positive coverage. It is effective against MRSA and penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Other options:

Option A: Ceftizoxime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is less active against S. pneumoniae and more active against Bacteroides fragilis. It has no action on MRSA.

Option B: Cefpirome is a fourth-generation cephalosporin that has antipseudomonal activity and activity against many organisms, such as Enterobacter and Pseudomonas, that are resistant to other cephalosporins, with no significant action on MRSA.

Option C: Ceftolozane is an anti-pseudomonal cephalosporin that is a structural analog of ceftazidime. It has enhanced activity against Pseudomonas, including activity against strains resistant to ceftazidime through β-lactamase overexpression, with no action on MRSA.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: During the post-mortem heart examination of a patient, the resident palpates a muscular ridge, which is the site of origin of pectinate muscles. In which of the following chambers is the resident palpating this structure?
questions.solution:
The structure being palpated by the resident is crista terminalis. It is present in the right atrium.

It is a muscular ridge that runs anteriorly along the atrial wall from the opening of the superior vena cava to the opening of the inferior vena cava. It corresponds externally to sulcus terminalis. It is the site of origin of pectinate muscles. 

It divides the right atrium into a smooth posterior part and a rough anterior part. Both the vena cavae empty into the posterior smooth part.

questions.text: A chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presented with a history of a mild burning sensation in his mouth that is aggravated while eating spicy foods. The oral examination showed creamy white patches on the oral mucosa. The wet mount microscopy of the scraping obtained from the patches is given below. This organism is a  ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of creamy white patches on the oral mucosa and the wet mount microscopy showing budding and pseudohyphae are suggestive of oral candidiasis caused by candida, which is a yeast-like fungi.

Fungi are eukaryotic organisms with a rigid cell wall made of chitin and mannan and true nuclei with the nuclear membrane and paired chromosomes. They divide sexually, asexually, or by both processes and can be unicellular or multicellular. They are classified into 4 types based on their morphology :

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Candida species are yeast-like fungi, which normally inhabit the skin and mucosa. Candida albicans is an ovoid or spherical budding cell, which produces pseudohyphae both in tissues and in culture. Candidiasis is an opportunistic endogenous infection. Risk factors include treatment with corticosteroids or antibiotics, high levels of glucose, and AIDS.

Diagnosis includes :

  • Gram staining - Gram-positive budding cells with pseudohyphae.
  • Sabouraud agar culture - Creamy white smooth colonies with yeasty odor.
  • Corn meal agar culture - Candida albicans form chlamydospores.
  • Reynolds Braude phenomenon - Candida albicans form germ tubes when incubated in human serum.
  • CHROMagar - Candida albicans colonies appear green.

Treatment: Topical clotrimazole, nystatin, and fluconazole.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: The hysterosalpingography of a patient with chronic pelvic inflammatory disease shows bilateral fallopian tube blockage. Which of the following organisms has the highest propensity to cause this tube block?
questions.solution:
Chlamydia trachomatis has the highest propensity to cause bilateral fallopian tube blockage.

Chlamydia infection remains asymptomatic in the endocervix and produces minimal symptoms, and therefore the infection goes unnoticed and untreated, but the damage it causes to the fallopian tube is five times higher than Neisseria gonorrhoea.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is usually a polymicrobial infection. The most common causes of PID are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. 

Other organisms causing PID are Mycoplasma, E.coli, and anaerobes. PID commonly spreads as ascending infection along with sperms. Genital tuberculosis mostly has a hematogenous spread.

On ultrasound, a tubo-ovarian abscess may be seen which appears as a complex cystic adnexal or cul-de-sac mass with thick irregular walls and septations.

Others: Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought by his mother with complaints of self-biting of his lips and nails. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated uric acid levels and partial deficiency of the enzyme HGPRT. What is the most likely diagnosis?

HGPRT - Hypoxanthine phosphoribosyltransferase.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with partial HGPRT deficiency points to the diagnosis of Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome is an x-linked disorder characterized by a partial deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT). 

Affected children present with developmental delays, hypotonia, and dystonia. Involuntary movements such as choreoathetosis develop within the first few years of life. Pyramidal signs like spasticity and hyperreflexia can also be observed.

Self-injurious behavior most commonly noted includes biting of lips, fingers, and cheeks, causing profound disfigurement. There might also be a history of aggressive behavior like pinching, spitting, grabbing, hitting, or verbally abusing. Nephrolithiasis and gouty arthritis occur due to hyperuricemia.

Blood investigations generally show features of megaloblastic anemia and increased serum uric acid.

Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase enzyme inhibitor, is the mainstay of treatment for hyperuricemia and its complications. Behavioral symptoms are managed with psychiatric, and medical interventions.

Other options:

Option A:  Lesch Nyhan syndrome is associated with signs and symptoms of Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome but is associated with complete deficiency of the enzyme HGPRT.

Option C: Patients with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) present with infections. Diarrhea, pneumonia, otitis media, sepsis, and cutaneous infections are common presentations. It is caused by various genetic mutations that lead to the absence of T- and B-cell function. They have a low lymphocyte count.

Option D: Autism mainly presents with problems in social communication and social interaction. They have poor verbal and non-verbal communication, absence of eye contact, repetitive behaviors like lining up toys or flipping objects, echolalia, etc. Intellectual impairment may or may not be present.

questions.text: In a road traffic accident victim with a GCS scale of 8/15, rapid-sequence intubation is planned. Which of the following is not done in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Manual ventilation before intubation is not done in rapid-sequence induction (RSI).

RSI is done during emergency surgery, with the objective of securing the airway rapidly and preventing aspiration.

Steps of RSI are shown in the image below:

Steps not done in RSI:

  • Manual ventilation before intubation: Avoided as this inflates the stomach and causes regurgitation
  • Premedications: Not given as surgery is done immediately under emergency

RSI is avoided in patients with raised intracranial pressure as it worsens the condition.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals an infant with sparse and kinky hair. This, along with loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase. 

Menkes disease results from a deficiency of lysyl oxidase co-factor i.e copper. This is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A mutation: Menkes disease - X-linked recessive
  • ATP7B mutation: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy who collapsed while playing basketball was brought to the emergency room and was resuscitated. On evaluation, he was found to have sustained ventricular tachycardia secondary to arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy. Which syndrome is associated with this?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient suffered from sustained ventricular tachycardia secondary to arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC). ARVC is associated with Naxos syndrome.

ARVC is autosomal dominant cardiomyopathy characterized by fibrofatty replacement in the myocardium of the ventricles. It most commonly affects the right ventricle. It is due to mutations in the gene encoding desmosome-associated protein plakophilin 2. This leads to defective cell-adhesion proteins in the desmosomes that link adjacent cardiac myocytes.

As shown in the image below, Naxos syndrome is characterized by woolly hair and palmoplantar hyperkeratosis.

Morphology shows severe thinning of the right ventricular wall due to loss of myocytes, accompanied by extensive fatty infiltration and fibrosis.

The image given below is a gross photograph of the heart showing dilated right ventricle and near transmural replacement of its free wall with fat and fibrosis.

Carvajal syndrome is a variant of Naxos disease but is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of psychiatric illness presents to the outpatient. She admits to abusing diuretics for the past 2 weeks. On examination, blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. With respect to extracellular fluid volume (ECF), intracellular fluid volume (ICF), and plasma sodium, which of the following changes will this patient have?

choices.text: Increased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium
Decreased ECF, decreased ICF, and increased plasma sodium
Decreased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium
Increased ECF, decreased ICF, and increased plasma sodium

questions.solution:
Diuretic overuse shows decreased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium, leading to hypoosmotic volume contraction.

A similar picture is seen in adrenal insufficiency. Due to a deficiency of aldosterone, there is a decrease in both plasma volume and osmolality.

Other Options:

Option A: This is seen in cases of hypoosmotic volume expansion like in the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) and bronchogenic tumors. 

SIADH is associated with euvolemic hyponatremia. This leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx also leads to a decrease in the ICF's osmolarity. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, an increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both compartments.

Option B: This is seen in cases of hyperosmotic volume contraction like in diabetes insipidus and excessive sweating.

Option D: This is seen in cases of hyperosmotic volume expansion like in high NaCl intake. The addition of excess NaCl to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

questions.text:
Which of the following is false regarding services provided for high-risk groups under the targeted interventions of NACO?

NACO- National AIDS Control Organization
ICTC- Integrated Counseling and Testing Centers

choices.text: Screening and treatment of sexually transmitted infections
Limiting the availability of sterile needles and syringes to IDUs

questions.solution:
Limiting the availability of sterile needles and syringes to IDUs is not a service offered through targeted interventions for the high-risk group under NACO guidelines. 

Following are the main services offered through targeted interventions:

  • Detection and treatment of sexually transmitted infections
  • Condom distribution 
  • Condom promotion through social marketing 
  • Behavioral change communication
  • Creating an enabling environment with community involvement and participation
  • Linkages to integrated counseling and testing centers
  • Linkages with care and support services for HIV-positive high-risk groups.
  • Community organization and ownership building.
  • Specific interventions for injecting drug users 
    • Distribution of clean needles and syringes
    • Abscess prevention and management
    • Opioid substitution therapy
    • Linkage with detoxification/rehabilitation services.
  • Specific interventions for men who have sex with men/ transgenders:
    • Provision of lubricants
    • Specific interventions for transgenders/hijra populations
    • Provision of project-based STI clinics

questions.text: On assessing a patient in psychiatry OPD, you ask him "What is your name?". He replies " game, frame, some shame, lame, blame.." and continues telling such rhyming words which are unrelated to each other. This thought disorder falls under which of the following category?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in which a patient speaks continuous irrelevant rhyming words is suggestive of clang association which is a disorder of stream of thought, as per Fish's classification of thought disorders.

Clang associations are thoughts in which the logical connection may be missing and the words are related only by the sound of words like rhyming or assonance than by their meaning. Such type of thought disorder is seen in disorders like schizophrenia and mania. 

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl was brought to the hospital after her parents noticed red blood in her stools. Physical examination showed the below finding. Small bowel radiography and histopathology showed multiple, small- to medium-sized hamartomatous polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of red blood in stools, mucocutaneous pigmentation, and hamartomatous small to medium-sized polyps are suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.

The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region.

Germline mutations in the gene STK11 are present in approximately half of the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histopathology shows the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

Complications:

  • Peutz-Jeghers polyps can cause intussusception.
  • It is associated with a markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Regular surveillance is recommended from a very young age for sex cord tumors of the testes.
  • During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Below is the histologic image of the arborizing pattern seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Juvenile polyps are the focal malformations of the epithelium or the lamina propria. They occur in children less than 5 years of age. Microscopy of the polyp reveals dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. 

Option B: Turcot syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis and constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors like medulloblastomas and glioblastomas.

Option D: Lynch syndrome, also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with the cecum and colon carcinomas. It is a DNA mismatch repair defect. They are also at an increased risk of developing cancers of the endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text:
A patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed a bottle of illicit liquor. His ABG shows metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?

ABG - Arterial blood gas
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the Arterial blood gas analysis (ABG) showing metabolic acidosis is suggestive of methanol toxicity. Fomepizole is used for the treatment of this condition.

Methanol poisoning is caused due to ingestion of illicit liquor which contains ethanol adulterated with methanol. Methanol is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid by alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenases, respectively. The metabolites of methanol are responsible for the toxic effects.

Clinically, patients present with headache, vomiting, abdomen pain, uneasiness, confusion, delirium, and coma. Formic acid specifically damages the retina and optic nerve and results in blurring of vision and blindness.

Elevated levels of formic acid and other organic acids result in metabolic acidosis on ABG.

Treatment of methanol poisoning includes keeping the patient in a quiet, dark room to protect the eyes from the light. Gastric lavage with sodium bicarbonate if the patient is brought within 2 hours of ingesting methanol to combat acidosis. Ethanol infusion since ethanol is preferentially metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase over methanol and helps by reducing the rate of generation of formaldehyde and formic acid.

Fomepizole is a specific inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase and the drug of choice for methanol poisoning. Folate therapy with calcium leucovorin reduces blood formate levels by enhancing its oxidation. Hemodialysis is used in severe cases of methanol toxicity.

Other options: 

Option B: Flumazenil is the inverse agonist of benzodiazepine receptors and is used for the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose.

Option C: N-acetyl cysteine is used as an antidote for the treatment of paracetamol poisoning.

Option D: Naloxone is a competitive opioid antagonist used for the treatment of opioid overdose.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient presents to the clinic for bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain for the past week. Colonoscopy shows continuous involvement with inflammation involving mucosa and submucosa. Pseudopolyps are observed. Microscopic evaluation of biopsy specimens shows crypt abscesses with no granulomas. A diagnosis is made based on a biopsy. Which of the following is not an extra-intestinal manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to ulcerative colitis and primary biliary cholangitis is not an extraintestinal manifestation of ulcerative colitis.

The clinical vignette describing chronic diarrhea with colonoscopic findings showing friable mucosa with continuous involvement, pseudopolyps, and microscopic findings showing crypt abscesses is suggestive of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis is characterized by recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosa of the colon and rectum. The diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is based on the history of diarrhea with the identification of colonoscopic and biopsy findings.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman complains of pain and foreign body sensation in her eye. Physical examination reveals redness of her eyes, the presence of a greyish-white serpiginous ulcer, and hypopyon that have increased significantly over 2 days. Which of the following organisms most likely caused this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of ulcus serpens which is characteristically caused by Pneumococcus.

The characteristic hypopyon corneal ulcer caused by Pneumococcus is called ulcus serpens. The bacterial hypopyon is sterile. 

Ulcus serpens is a greyish-white or yellowish disc-shaped ulcer occurring near the center of the cornea. The ulcer has a tendency to creep over the cornea in a serpiginous fashion. Pain is lesser as compared to other bacterial corneal ulcers. The hypopyon enlarges rapidly. Features similar to bacterial corneal ulcers such as watering of the eye, photophobia, blurred vision, and redness of the eyes are seen.

Other clinical signs include:

  • Swelling of lids
  • Blepharospasm
  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Ciliary congestion
  • Violent iridocyclitis is commonly associated
  • Often results in secondary glaucoma

Other causes of corneal ulcers with hypopyon include - Staphylococci, Streptococci, Gonococci, Moraxella, and Pseudomonas pyocyanea.

Other options:

Option A - Pseudomonas - produce an irregular sharp ulcer with thick greenish mucopurulent exudate, diffuse liquefactive necrosis, and semiopaque (ground glass) surrounding the cornea.

Options C & D - Typical oval or irregularly shaped bacterial ulcers with or without hypopyon. They do not produce serpiginous ulcers as seen in ulcus serpens.

  1. Spermatozoa
  2. Spermatogonia
  3. Spermatocytes
