questions.text: A research fellow in biochemistry is studying the lac operon concept of gene regulation. He cultures E. coli. in a glucose-deficient and lactose-containing medium. Which of the following genes expressed in this condition helps convert lactose to galactose and glucose?
questions.solution:
The gene marked as 2 is the lac Z gene, which codes for β-galactosidase. This enzyme converts lactose to galactose and glucose.

Lac operon concept

Jacob and Monod studied the Lac operon model, which is the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium Escherichia coli. It is switched on when the bacteria have to utilize lactose for utilization. Otherwise, it is switched off. It contains the following genes:

  • lac I- it codes for the repressor protein
  • cAMP response element (CRE)- It is activated by binding the cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP). When activated, it increases the binding of RNA polymerase and increases gene expression.
  • Promoter site- It is the site where RNA polymerase binds the gene for transcription. 
  • Operator site- It is the site where repressor protein binds.
  • lac Z gene- It codes for β-Galactosidase that hydrolyzes lactose to galactose and glucose. 
  • lac Y- It encodes for lactose permease, which increases the permeability of lactose into the cells.
  • lac A- It encodes for thiogalactoside transacetylase. 

For the working of Lac operon, the operator site should be free and the CRE site should be activated.

1. When glucose is present and lactose is absent- The bacteria utilize glucose. The lac I gene produces repressor protein, which binds to the operator site. Repressor-operator binding prevents the binding of RNA polymerase and, consequently, prevents transcription of the lacZ, lacY, and lacA structural genes into a polycistronic mRNA. 

In addition to this, excess glucose inhibits adenylyl cyclase. Therefore, the production of cAMP is reduced. Less cAMP means less cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP) binding to CRE. CRE is not activated, and lac operon is switched off.

2. When glucose is absent and lactose is present- Bacteria utilize lactose. The lactose inactivates the repressor protein. This prevents the binding of repressor protein to the operator site. The operator site is now free and RNA polymerase can start with the transcription. The low glucose level causes an increase in the adenylyl cyclase activity, and increases the cAMP levels. This increases the binding of CAP to CRE, which in turn activates the transcription of the lacZ, lacY, and lacA structural genes into polycistronic mRNA. 

3. When both glucose and lactose are present- The bacteria utilize glucose. The unused lactose binds to the repressor protein and renders it inactive. The operator site is free. However, the increased glucose level inhibits adenylyl cyclase and decreases the cAMP levels. Therefore, even though the operator site is free, CRE is not activated, which leads to the switching off of the lac operon.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presented with features of heart failure. After a detailed evaluation, he was prescribed carvedilol to control his symptoms. Which of the following is incorrect about the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The option that is incorrect about the mechanism of action of carvedilol is alpha-2 antagonism.

Carvedilol is a third-generation non-selective beta-blocker (β1+β2) with weak α1 antagonism property. At high doses, it also exhibits calcium channel–blocking properties. It also has anti-oxidant properties through a free radical scavenging mechanism.

It also has anti-inflammatory properties and membrane-stabilizing activity. It is used in the treatment of hypertension, heart failure (stable cases), and left ventricular dysfunction post-myocardial infarction. Its renoprotective effects are favorable in patients with diabetes or metabolic syndrome. 

In congestive heart failure, beta-blockers should be used with caution. The starting dose of beta-blockers is less than 1/8th (low dose) of the target dose and then titrated upwards slowly over weeks (doubling every 4 weeks). These beta-blockers are highly useful in mild to moderate CHF (NYHA I, II) and should not be used in decompensated heart disease. 

Related Pearl: Non-selective beta blockers with membrane stabilizing action

  • Carvedilol

questions.text: An MRI of a woman presented with recurrent episodes of blurry vision, paresthesia, and numbness in the legs for the past 3 weeks is given below. The characteristic finding shown is best observed under which imaging modality?
questions.solution:
The given MRI shows Dawson finger, and it is best visualized under the fluid-attenuated inversion-recovery (FLAIR) imaging modality. This is a characteristic finding seen in multiple sclerosis. 

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. The common symptoms of multiple sclerosis are as follows:

  • Sensory symptoms - paresthesia (tingling sensations, pins and needle sensation), hypesthesia (numbness)
  • Optic neuritis - decreased visual acuity and color perception, unilateral/ bilateral
  • Limb weakness - spastic paralysis, gait disturbances, Babinski's sign positive
  • Facial weakness
  • Vertigo
  • Hearing loss 
  • Bladder dysfunction
  • Lhermitte's sign (shooting pain down the back on neck movement)
  • Uhthoff's sign (worsening of neurological symptoms on exposure to elevated temperatures eg. hot shower)

MRI is the imaging modality of choice in a patient with multiple sclerosis due to its high sensitivity. It shows finger-like periventricular and callosal lesions, perpendicular to the ventricular surface (Dawson fingers).

Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) shows the central vein sign in multiple sclerosis.

T1-weighted MRI shows hypointense lesions seen as black holes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was admitted to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, paradoxical respiration was seen. His chest X-ray is shown below. All of the following can be done to manage this patient except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of paradoxical respiration and the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side are suggestive of a flail chest. All the above measures can be used to treat flail chests except strapping as it impairs chest wall movement leading to hypoxia.

A flail chest usually results from blunt trauma associated with 3 or more rib fractures in 2 or more places. It arises when these injuries cause a part of the chest wall to move independently of the rest of the chest wall. It is diagnosed clinically by observing paradoxical respiration. On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall gets displaced inwards, and on expiration, it moves outwards. They are at higher risk of developing pneumothorax/hemothorax. CT scan is the gold standard investigation.

Management includes oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy. Intermittent positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) is reserved for patients developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic right-sided ear discharge for the last 1.5 months presented with complaints of deep-seated ear pain, severe retro-orbital pain, and diplopia. On examination, the following finding is seen on lateral gaze. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of persistent ear discharge, deep-seated ear ache, retro-orbital pain, and diplopia is suggestive of Gradenigo syndrome, seen in petrous apicitis or petrositis. It is due to the spread of infection from the middle ear and mastoid to the petrous part of the temporal bone.

In this case, there is a failure of abduction of the right eye on lateral gaze, which indicates paralysis of the right lateral rectus due to right abducent (cranial nerve VI) nerve palsy. 

Gradenigo syndrome consists of a triad :

  • Persistent ear discharge
  • Deep-seated ear or retro-orbital pain
  • VI nerve palsy

 Infection from the mastoid air cells reaches the petrous apex via two pathways:

1. Postero-superior tract: starts at the mastoid, and runs behind or above the bony labyrinth or through the arc of the superior semicircular canal to the petrous apex.

2. Antero-inferior tract: starts at the hypotympanum, and goes around the cochlea to reach the petrous apex.

Dorello's canal is a dural sheath at the petrous apex which gives space for the passage of the abducent nerve and hence this nerve is compressed by the epidural abscess formed at the apex in petrositis. Retro-orbital pain is due to the involvement of the trigeminal ganglion.

HRCT and MRI of temporal bone help in reaching the diagnosis. 

FLAIR image showing hyperintensity at the right petrous apex due to pus and edema, indicative of petrous apicitis.

Other options:

Option A: Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis will present as headache, picket-fence fever, edema over mastoid, tenderness along the jugular vein, fatigue, blurring of vision, and rarely seizures.

Option C. Coalescent mastoiditis will present with mastoid tenderness and deep-seated ear ache but other features like retro-orbital pain and lateral rectus palsy will be absent.

Option D: Brain abscess will present as headache, high-grade fever, focal neurological deficits, and seizures. MRI of the brain will show central hypodensity with peripheral rim enhancement. Diffusion-weighted image (DWI) will show diffusion restriction.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks of gestation presented with bleeding per vagina. A sample of the PV bleed is obtained and an Apt test is performed, which is positive. What is the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Apt test is an alkali denaturation test to detect fetal hemoglobin (HbF). A positive Apt test suggests it is fetal blood. Among the given conditions, vasa previa is the one that would contain blood of fetal origin and therefore, the most likely cause of bleeding in this case. 

Apt test is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation, while HbA is not. The test is performed by collecting the blood sample in a test tube containing water and adding NaOH. Maternal blood turns yellow-brown, while fetal blood remains pink in the test tube.

Vasa previa is a condition in which umbilical vessels run across the cervical os. This makes them vulnerable to bleeding due to pressure from the presenting part of the fetus or during the rupture of membranes.

Color flow Doppler can be used for diagnosis. If diagnosed before bleeding occurs, the patient can be managed by elective C-section before the onset of labor. Bleeding leads to fetal exsanguination and must be managed immediately with an emergency C-section. 

Other options: Bleeding due to abruptio placenta, cervical polyp, and placenta previa is of maternal origin. Hence, the Apt test will be negative in these cases.

questions.text: A male infant with a history of not passing meconium was referred to you. On examination, abdominal distension was noted. The findings of barium enema are shown below. You can manage this case surgically by all of the following surgical procedures, except ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium enema showing a dilated right colon, with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon, are together suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. All the above procedures are used in the surgical management of this case, except Bianchi procedure, which is an intestinal lengthening procedure used in short bowel syndrome. 

Hirschsprung disease is a developmental disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus. The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

Most infants present with abdominal distention and bilious vomiting. There is a failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life.

The imaging method of choice for diagnosis of Hirschprung disease is a contrast enema. The gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is a rectal biopsy. The biopsy specimen shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing: This method is now being widely used and is considered superior to acetylcholinesterase staining in confirming the diagnosis.

Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson procedure, where aganglionic bowel is removed and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.
  • Duhamel procedure, where the aganglionic rectal stump is left in place and the ganglionated normal colon is pulled posterior.
  • Soave procedure: In this procedure, endorectal mucosal dissection is done within the aganglionic distal rectum; then, the ganglionated normal colon is pulled through the remnant muscular cuff, and a coloanal anastomosis is performed.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents with fever and productive cough. She has had a history of multiple respiratory tract infections since birth.  Laboratory investigations show elevated IgM antibody levels. IgG levels are found to be low, while IgA and IgE are absent. Mutation in which of the following genes is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Elevated IgM with low to absent levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies suggest hyper-IgM syndrome. Mutation in the gene encoding for the CD40 ligand is responsible for this condition.

CD40 ligand is normally responsible for class switching. Class switching refers to the genetic recombination event in which the heavy-chain constant segment of the IgM gene is replaced with a different constant segment that leads to a different type of antibody being produced (e.g. IgG, IgA, IgE, etc.).

Mutation in the gene that codes for CD40 ligand will impair class switching of the IgM antibodies to any other antibody type, and this results in relatively higher levels of IgM. Frequent infections of the respiratory and gastrointestinal tract result from lower levels of other antibodies. Elevated IgM antibodies can sometimes react with blood cells, causing autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. In others, IgM-producing plasma cells may proliferate and infiltrate the gastrointestinal mucosa.

Other options:

Option A: The adenosine deaminase (ADA) gene is deficient in the autosomal recessive variant of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). This results in the production of toxic metabolites that destroy the rapidly dividing T-cell lineage (affects T-cells more than B-cells). These children are susceptible to recurrent infections, and without a bone marrow transplant, they usually die within the first year of life. 

Option B: Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene is mutated in X-linked agammaglobulinemia. It occurs because the B-cells fail to undergo maturation. All lines of immunoglobulins are found to be low in this disease. Since it is an X-linked disorder, it is most commonly seen in young males. They present after the age of 6 months with recurrent respiratory tract infections.

Option D: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) gene is mutated in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. This is also an X-linked disorder that presents with eczema, thrombocytopenia, and recurrent infections. They usually show low IgM levels, normal IgG, and elevated IgE and IgA levels.

  • Tuftsin deficiency

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old P2L2 woman presents to your office with foul-smelling bloody discharge per vaginum. Her CECT reports show a 3.5 x 4 cm ulceroproliferative mass in the cervix invading the parametrium, with para-aortic node involvement. What is the line of management for this case?

choices.text: Radical hysterectomy + Pelvic lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
The patient has carcinoma cervix, which is at stage IIIC2 due to para-aortic node involvement. As per FIGO 2018 guidelines, the treatment for this stage is chemoradiation.

Chemoradiation can improve survival rates. It allows for remission in certain cases or a reduction in morbidity.

Other options:

Pelvic exenteration may be considered in stage IVA. 

Surgical treatment is considered in the early stages of the disease. Radical hysterectomy is preferred in stages IB1, IB2, and a few cases of IIA.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fatigue, dry cough, and dyspnea on exertion. On examination, his hands showed hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint. Laboratory results revealed normocytic normochromic anemia and elevated anti-CCP antibodies. What is the most common interstitial lung disease associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and blood picture in the scenario suggest rheumatoid arthritis. The most common interstitial lung disease associated with this condition is usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).

Laboratory diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Increase in erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein.
  • Serum rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody (anti-CCP) are positive. Anti-CCP antibodies are more specific for diagnosis and a predictor of poor prognosis.
  • The most common anemia associated is normocytic normochromic anemia.

Hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint suggest swan neck deformity in rheumatoid arthritis. UIP has a poor prognosis and is generally refractive to treatment.

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) is the initial investigation of choice for a patient with interstitial lung disease. The most common HRCT pattern seen in a patient with ILD in rheumatoid arthritis is the UIP pattern. Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) can also be seen. The characteristic HRCT findings of UIP are - 

  • Bilateral, lower lobe, subpleural reticular changes
  • Traction bronchiectasis
  • Honey combing pattern

The image given below shows the CT findings of UIP:


Option B - Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) is characterized by bilateral, subpleural, symmetrical ground glass reticular opacities and traction bronchiectasis. In contrast to UIP, honeycombing is uncommon and has a better prognosis. This pattern is universally found in patients with systemic sclerosis. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis but is not as common as the UIP pattern. Management includes steroids, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate, and rituximab with pulmonary rehabilitation.

Option C - Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) shows patchy subpleural consolidative opacities. A characteristic peribronchiolar/ perilobar opacities with a rim of subpleural sparing called the reverse halo sign is seen. COP is commonly mistaken for pneumonia and can present secondary to polymyositis.

 The image given below shows the reversed halo sign:


Option D - Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities. It is associated with high mortality.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis. 

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: Choose the cardiac event that corresponds to the phase of isovolumetric contraction.
questions.solution:
Isovolumetric contraction corresponds best with "c" wave of JVP. 

Events of the Cardiac Cycle

Systole 

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively. 

Diastole 

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with 'a' wave in JVP.

questions.text: A patient underwent reconstruction surgery with a flap known as the Abbe-Estlander flap, shown below. This flap is used for the reconstruction of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Abbe-Estlander flap, which is used for lip reconstruction.

The Abbe-Estlander flap is a full-thickness lip-switch flap. Here, a part of the uninvolved lip is rotated across the mouth and into the defect of the involved lip.

The Estlander and Abbé flaps are based on the labial artery used for the reconstruction of the lip. The Estlander flap involves resection of the commissure, while the Abbé flap preserves the commissure.

Related Pearl: Lip reconstruction flaps

  • Up to half of the lip can be removed and closed primarily.
  • Defects encompassing between one half and two-thirds of the lip require augmentation.
  • Karapandzic flap consists of circumoral incisions with the circular rotation of the skin flaps while maintaining innervation.
  • When the defect involves the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for more midline defects.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with severe joint pain in her left knee and an inability to move the distal interphalangeal joints of her hand. She has a family history of psoriasis. Which of the following is the classical radiological finding in such cases?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette mentions left knee involvement (asymmetrical joint involvement) with the inability to move the distal joint (arthritis of small joints in the finger), and a family history of psoriasis, suggesting the diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. Pencil-in-cup deformity with subluxation of the thumb is a classical radiological finding in psoriatic arthritis. 

These changes occur due to periarticular erosion and bony resorption. The image below shows the pencil-in-cup deformity in psoriatic arthritis:


Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis. It usually develops before 40 years of age. In the hands, the most common joint involved is the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP). It also involves the PIP and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP).

The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of the hands:


Clinical features include asymmetric joint involvement, early morning stiffness, enthesitis, dactylitis, and nail changes (hyperkeratosis and onycholysis). Inflammatory markers like CRP and ESR are elevated. Plain X-rays of the hands and feet in erosive disease show:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
  • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation 'whiskering'

NSAIDs, steroid injections, methotrexate, and cyclosporin/ biologicals can be used for the management of this condition. Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK 1/3 - Inhibitor that has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis.

Other options:

Option A- Boutonnière deformity- It is a flexion deformity of the fingers. It presents as flexion deformity at the PIP joint and extension of the DIP joint. It is caused by disruption of the extensor tendon due to trauma or rheumatic disease.

Option B- Swan-neck deformity- It presents as hyperextension of the PIP joint and flexion of the DIP joint (the reverse of Boutonnière deformity). It can occur due to an imbalance of the action of flexors and extensors at the PIP joint and failure of the palmar plate of PIP in conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis or lax joints.


Option C- Z-thumb deformity- It is seen in rheumatoid arthritis. It presents with hyperextension of the interphalangeal joint and flexion of the metacarpophalangeal joint.

questions.text: You are interpreting data collected from a city to write a research paper on the extent of pollution in it. You come across the soiling index. What is it an indicator of?
questions.solution:
The soiling index or smoke index is an indicator of air pollution.

The soiling index is a measure of the total suspended particulate matter in air. A known air volume is filtered through a white filter paper, and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter. It is expressed as micrograms/ cubic meters of air over a certain period. The best indicators of air pollution include sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles. 

Currently, the Air Quality Index (AQI) is the most commonly used tool for the air quality status and severity of pollution. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature, and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration  to calculate the AQI -

  • PM10 (airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  • PM2.5 (airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  • NO2 (nitrogen dioxide)
  • SO2 (sulfur dioxide)
  • CO (carbon monoxide)
  • O3 (ozone)
  • NH3 (ammonia)
  • Pb (lead)

The National AQI categories and the range are as follows :

AQI Category AQI Range
Good 0 - 50
Satisfactory 51 - 100
Moderate 101 - 200
Poor 201 - 300
Very poor 301 - 400
Severe 401 - 500

 

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Major components are sulfates, nitrates, sodium chloride, mineral dust, black carbon, and water.

Radon, lead, asbestos are formed from construction materials, paints, and demolition

Effects of indoor air pollution:

  • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
  • Stroke
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • COPD
  • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
  • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight

Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide - one of the best indicator of air pollution
  • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
  • Grit and dust measurement 
  • The co-efficient of haze - assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosols in the air
  • Air pollution index - measure of pollution severity
  • Suspended particle matter (SPM) 

In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: The finding shown in the image below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image shows a chocolate cyst, which is seen in ovarian endometriosis.

The cysts form secondary to endometriotic implants in the ovarian stroma that bleed periodically and undergo shedding.

Spontaneous cyst rupture, with the release of thick, tarry brownish fluid, can lead to acute peritonitis, and this may be mistaken for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, appendicitis, diverticulitis, or torsion of a tumor.

questions.text: The ICDS department carried out a nutritional survey of a group of children in the town. The length-for-age of an 18-month-old girl baby is shown as 'X' in the image below. This growth chart indicates that the child has:
questions.solution:
The point X in the given WHO growth chart  (length for age) indicates that the child falls below -3SD and can therefore be classified to have chronic malnutrition/severe stunting.

Low height for the age (height for age < -2SD) in children indicates chronic malnutrition and stunting. 

Classification of nutritional status depending on the anthropometry (height/length for age): 

Classification Criteria
Moderate stunting (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/length-for-age < –2 SD and > –3 SD
Severe stunting (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/length-for-age < –3 SD


The World Health Organization (WHO) has established international standards for normal child growth from birth to 5 years of age. The normalization of the anthropometric measures is done in terms of z-scores (standard deviation scores). The anthropometric indicators are marked in a growth chart which is compared with a reference curve.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

The nutritional status of a child is assessed in terms of anthropometry:

  • Low weight-for-height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. 
  • Low weight-for-age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.


The below image shows the WHO growth chart for girls (6 months-2years). Boys have similar charting in blue color.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with mild recurrent hemoptysis without fever or weight loss. The chest X-ray appears normal and the sputum is negative for AFB. Which of the following is the next best diagnostic investigation?
questions.solution:
In this case, considering the patient's age of 50 years, history of chronic smoking, and recurrent hemoptysis, all of which raise suspicion for lung malignancy, the next best diagnostic investigation would be a CT scan. 

Any patient presenting with recurrent hemoptysis requires chest imaging. The initial imaging modality is a plain radiograph. However, patients with risk factors for malignancy need further evaluation with a CT scan. 

CT can identify masses, bronchiectasis, and parenchymal lesions. Further management depends on the CT findings. Fiberoptic bronchoscopy, which is an invasive procedure, is done after a mass is seen on a CT scan to enable sample collection for biopsy. Also, bronchoscopy has an overall lower sensitivity than MDCT in detecting the underlying causes of bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: While MRI can be valuable in certain situations, such as evaluating the mediastinum or vascular structures, a chest CT scan is generally the preferred initial diagnostic investigation for assessing lung pathology, especially in cases of hemoptysis.

Option D: Bronchography is visualizing the tracheobronchial tree on plain radiography by instilling contrast material via the bronchus. It has been replaced by advancements in CT scans.

Risk factors for the development of lung cancer:

  • Tobacco smoking: Associated with 90% of lung cancers.
  • Occupational and environmental exposure to carcinogens: Includes passive smoking, environmental air pollution, radon, asbestos, arsenic, chromium, nickel, beryllium, and silica.
  • Family history (genetic predisposition).
  • Other risk factors: Pulmonary scarring, previous radiation, pulmonary fibrosis, and chronic infections (e.g., tuberculosis, HIV).

questions.text: In Piaget's theory of cognitive development, object permanence is seen in which stage?
questions.solution:
According to the cognitive development stages described by Jean Piaget, object permanence is present in the sensorimotor stage of cognitive development.

There are 4 stages in cognitive development through which the thinking process of an individual develops. They are:

  1. Sensorimotor stage (birth–2 years):
    • Starts with an out-of-sight, out-of-mind type of thinking
    • Ends with object permanence (knowing an object exists even though it cannot be seen) 
    • Symbolisation- developing mental symbols and words for the objects
  2. Pre-operational stage (2-7 years):
    • Thinking without reasoning- intuitive thinking 
    • Only concerned about their own needs and perspective- egocentric thinking
    • Other thinking processes are seen- animism, primitive thinking, centration, magical or fantasy thinking
  3. Concrete operational stage (7-11 years):
    • Start to see things from other's perspectives
    • Thinking is concrete and literal
    • Develop conservation- understanding that despite changes in shape, the object remains the same. For eg: when water is transferred from a bottle to a glass, they understand that it is water only and that the volume is the same
    • Develop the concept of reversibility- knowing that one thing can turn into another and back. Eg., water and ice
    • Other processes such as classification, transitivity
  4. Formal operational stage (>11 years):
    • Develop abstract thinking, wherein they can generalize or conceptualize
    • Can make a hypothesis and use deductive reasoning

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus. She has a history of chronic kidney disease. Which of the following statement is correct about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Metformin is contraindicated in all stages of CKD
Pioglitazone is avoided as it is exclusively metabolized by kidneys
Glipizide can be used even in severe renal disease
Linagliptin can be used only after dose reduction

questions.solution:
Among the given statements, the correct one is glipizide can be used even in severe renal disease. Glipizide is the only sulfonylurea class of oral hypoglycemic agent that can be safely used without dose adjustment even in severe and moderate renal disease.

In patients with chronic kidney disease, glucose metabolism is disturbed. The circulating insulin levels are mildly elevated in patients with uremia as there is reduced degradation by the kidneys.

Drug therapy Usage in CKD
Insulin
  • Progressive dose reduction is needed according to the declining GFR.
Metformin
  • Metformin can be used in stages I and II with frequent renal function monitoring.
  • When GFR becomes less than half of the normal, it should be stopped
Pioglitazone
  • It undergoes hepatic metabolism exclusively and can be used without dose adjustment at all stages of CKD.
  • Pioglitazone is related to fluid retention, anemia, and osteoporosis as side effects and can potentially exacerbate bone loss due to renal osteodystrophy. 
Sulfonylureas
  • Should be used with caution and appropriate dose adjustments due to the risk of hypoglycemia.
  • Glipizide however can be used in CKD with no dose reductions as it does not lead to the production of any active metabolites that are cleared by the kidney. 
Dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP-4) inhibitors
(gliptins)
  • These can be used in all stages of CKD with dose adjustment except for Linagliptin (no dose adjustment needed in all stages)

questions.text:
Two RAE tubes are given below. Identify them with their respective surgeries that they are used in.
(RAE:  Ring-Adair-Elwyn tubes)

choices.text: B-North faced RAE, used in Ophthalmic surgery
A-North faced RAE, used in Oral surgery
A-South faced RAE, used in Ophthalmic surgery
B-South faced RAE, used in Oral surgery

questions.solution:
The correct answer is: A-North faced RAE, used in Oral surgery; B-South faced RAE, used in Ophthalmic surgery.

South/ Oral Ring-Adair-Elwyn (RAE) endotracheal tube: It is preferable for nasal and ophthalmic surgeries because it has a preformed right-angle bend at the level of the teeth so that it does not disrupt the surgical field.

The image below shows south faced oral RAE tube used for surgery of upper cleft lip with nose involved.

North/ Nasal RAE tube: It is preferred in oral and dental surgeries as it has a preformed right-angle bend at the level of the nose so that the tube is directed over the forehead. Nasal intubation should be considered with caution in LeFort II and III fractures because of the possibility of a coexisting basilar skull fracture. Nasal intubation is contraindicated in a basilar skull fractures. 

The image below shows a north nasal RAE tube used for Macrostomia surgery.

questions.text:
You are an intern in the gynecology department. You are asked to monitor all the patients requiring hormone replacement therapy (HRT). Which of these four patients would you prescribe HRT to?

TAH: Total abdominal hysterectomy

BSO: Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

choices.text: A 35-year-old woman who has undergone TAH+BSO
A 7-year-old girl who has Turner syndrome
A 47-year-old woman with hot flushes and history of breast cancer
A 60-year-old woman with a history of ischemic heart disease

questions.solution:
The 35-year-old woman who had undergone TAH+BSO (Total abdominal hysterectomy + Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy) is the only one who needs hormone replacement therapy (HRT).

Other Options:

Option B: This girl with Turner syndrome can receive HRT once she reaches adolescence.

Option C: HRT is contraindicated in this woman due to her history of breast cancer.

Option D: HRT is not indicated as a prophylactic measure against coronary artery disease. A woman with previous ischemic heart disease does not benefit from HRT, and its use is not recommended.

However, it may be useful in some cardiovascular diseases.

Indications for HRT:

  • Therapeutic: Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency and adolescents with gonadal dysgenesis
  • Prophylactic: High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s disease, and colonic cancer
  • Premature menopause following hysterectomy, tubectomy, radiotherapy, chemotherapy

Contraindications for HRT:

  • History of breast cancer or uterine cancer or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of the thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gallbladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy who presented with hepatomegaly, tremors, poor coordination, and choreoathetosis was diagnosed with Wilson's disease. Where does the underlying defect likely lie in this condition?
questions.solution:
In Wilson's disease, there is a mutation of the ATP7B gene. The likely underlying defect resulting from this mutation is in the excretion of copper into bile.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss of function mutation of the ATP7B gene, which codes for the enzyme copper-transporting ATPase present on the hepatocyte canalicular membrane.

In general, the free copper is taken up by hepatocytes and incorporated to form ceruloplasmin gets released into the bloodstream and accounts for 90% to 95% of plasma copper. Excess hepatic copper gets transported into the bile and eventually excreted in the feces.

The deficiency of the ATP7B gene impairs copper transport into the bile, its incorporation into ceruloplasmin, and secretion of ceruloplasmin into the blood. This results in a decrease in circulating ceruloplasmin levels and increased levels of hepatic copper. Total serum copper level may be decreased due to the deficiency in ceruloplasmin.

The excessive accumulation of copper injures the hepatocytes. This in turn releases the non-ceruloplasmin-bound copper into the bloodstream, which later gets deposited in tissues like the basal ganglia of the brain and the cornea. This results in behavioral disturbances and extrapyramidal symptoms and the characteristic KF ring that is seen on slit-lamp examination. There is a marked compensatory urinary copper excretion. However, these levels do not suffice to prevent the deposition of copper in tissues.

questions.text: A female patient came to the hospital with complaints of fatigue, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and dizziness on standing. She has generalized hyperpigmentation that is more pronounced in areas exposed to the sun. She is a known patient of hypothyroidism and is on thyroxine. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities would most likely suggest primary adrenal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
The electrolyte abnormality that would most likely be present in Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) is hyponatremia.

Adrenal insufficiency can be divided into:

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) is most commonly due to autoimmune adrenalitis. These patients are likely to develop other autoimmune diseases such as vitiligo, premature ovarian failure, and autoimmune thyroid disease. Other causes of Addison's disease include destruction of the adrenal gland due to infections such as TB, hemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome due to meningococcemia) or infiltration.

Secondary adrenal insufficiency occurs due to hypothalamic-pituitary axis dysfunction. This can include iatrogenic suppression due to chronic therapy with glucocorticoids, or because of pituitary and hypothalamic tumors. Pituitary apoplexy because of hypovolemic shock during parturition (Sheehan syndrome) can also cause secondary adrenal insufficiency.

The patients present with fatigue and loss of energy. Primary adrenal insufficiency causes hyperpigmentation due to excess ACTH, which stimulates the melanocytes to produce more pigment. Hyperpigmentation is maximally seen in areas exposed to sunlight or that which undergo friction. However, secondary adrenal insufficiency presents with skin paleness due to the complete absence of ACTH. 

The diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency is established by the ACTH stimulation test.

ACTH stimulation test (also known as the short cosyntropin test or short Synacthen test) involves the administration of an exogenous, synthetic peptide that has an activity similar to ACTH on the adrenal glands. Serum cortisol levels are measured prior to, and after the administration of the synthetic peptide. Cortisol levels lower than the cut-off value indicate a failure of the adrenal glands to increase the production of cortisol in response to synthetic ACTH — thus confirming the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Note that this will be seen in both primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Primary and secondary adrenal insufficiencies can be differentiated biochemically:

Primary adrenal insufficiency Secondary adrenal insufficiency
Serum cortisol after ACTH stimulation: low Serum cortisol after ACTH stimulation: low
Serum ACTH: high Serum ACTH: low
Plasma renin: high (minerocorticoid deficiency also present, since adrenal gland itself is not functioning) Plasma renin: normal (adrenal gland itself is functional and can be regulated by renin-angiotensin system)

 

Patients should also undergo screening for steroid autoantibodies and a CT scan of the adrenal glands to narrow down the cause of the adrenal insufficiency. 

Treatment is with oral hydrocortisone 15-25 mg/day in 2-3 divided doses. Long-acting agents are not preferred because they cause receptor activation even when the cortisol levels are supposed to be physiologically low in the body. Mineralocorticoid replacement is done with fludrocortisone 100-150 μg.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: A nephrectomy specimen of a 40-year-old man showed the following histological picture. The tumor cells are positive for CK7. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this type of renal carcinoma?

choices.text: Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct

questions.solution:
The given image is of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC), which is most commonly associated with Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome and not von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) syndrome. VHL syndrome is associated with clear cell RCC.

Chromophobe carcinoma is composed of cells with prominent cell membranes and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, usually with a halo around the nucleus. It shows large cells having a plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo. They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.

Chromophobe RCC cannot be histologically graded because of its innate nuclear atypia.

Cytogenetic examination of the tumor shows multiple chromosome losses and extreme hypodiploidy. The tumor is thought to grow from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. It has an excellent prognosis compared to clear cell and papillary cancers.

Close differential diagnoses are as follows:

  • Oncocytoma: Perinuclear halo is not seen.
  • Clear cell RCC: CK7 is diffusely positive in chromophobe RCC which distinguishes it from clear-cell RCC.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A patient with aplastic anemia undergoes bone marrow transplantation. Within 2 weeks, he presents with complaints of bloody diarrhea. Upon further examination, he was found to have jaundice and blistering rashes on the skin. What is the possible mechanism behind the patient's current clinical picture?

choices.text: Immune cells of the host attacking transplanted tissue
Preformed antibodies of the host attacking transplanted tissue

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). The possible mechanism behind the patient's current clinical picture is transplanted cells attacking host tissues.

Transfusion of irradiated RBCs prevents the incidence of GVHD associated with the transfusion.

GVHD occurs when immunologically competent cells or their precursors are transplanted into immunologically compromised recipients. The transferred cells recognize the alloantigens in the host and attack host tissues. It is seen most commonly during hematopoietic stem cell transplantation but may also occur following the transplantation of solid organs. 

GVHD may be of two types: acute and chronic.

Acute GVHD occurs within days to weeks after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. It mainly involves the immune system and the epithelia of the skin (in the form of generalized rash), liver (in the form of jaundice), and intestines (in the form of bloody diarrhea). But the affected tissues are not heavily infiltrated by lymphocytes.

Chronic GVHD may follow acute GVHD or may occur insidiously. These patients have extensive skin damage, with the destruction of skin appendages and fibrosis of the dermis, resembling systemic sclerosis. Cholestatic jaundice and esophageal strictures are also common. There will be involution of the thymus and depletion of lymphocytes in the lymph nodes. There will also be recurrent bouts of life-threatening infections. Some may even develop autoimmunity, owing to the grafted CD4+ helper T cells reacting with host B cells and stimulating them, which may result in autoantibody production.

Depletion of donor T cells by irradiation before transfusion can eliminate the occurrence of GVHD. But irradiation also has its adverse effects such as tumor recurrence in leukemic patients, increased incidence of graft failures, and EBV-related B-cell lymphoma.

questions.text: A postoperative patient presented with abdominal distension 4 days after laparotomy. He had not yet passed flatus after surgery. On examination, bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory values suggest hypokalemia. X-ray shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple air-fluid levels. What type of intestinal obstruction is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of postoperative paralytic ileus, which is a type of adynamic intestinal obstruction.

Paralytic ileus is an adynamic obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission of peristaltic waves, secondary to neuromuscular failure in the Auerbach’s and Meissner’s plexuses. Paralytic ileus lasting 24–72 hours usually occurs after any abdominal procedure and is self-limiting. It is of clinical significance if any of the following are observed 72 hours after laparotomy:

  • No return of bowel sounds on auscultation
  • No passage of flatus

Features of paralytic ileus are marked abdominal distension, effortless vomiting, absent bowel sounds, and absolute constipation. Colicky abdominal pain is not a feature.

Hypokalemia and uremia may be seen and are known to contribute to the development of paralytic ileus. On radiology, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels (if an erect film is felt necessary).

Paralytic ileus is managed with the use of nasogastric suction and restriction of oral intake until bowel sounds and the passage of flatus return. Electrolyte balance must be maintained.

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of easy fatiguability, weakness, and joint pain. On further questioning, he says that he was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease 1 year back and is on treatment for the same since then. His blood work results are given below. The presenting features of this patient are caused by the adverse effect of which of the following drugs?
  • Hemoglobin - 10.5 gm/dL
  • Total leukocyte count- 7.6 x 103 /microL
  • Platelets - 350000 /microL
  • RBC - 3.23 x 106 /microL
  • Peripheral smear: Macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of an adverse effect of chronic treatment with omeprazole. It is associated with decreased vitamin B12 absorption, thus leading to megaloblastic anemia in this patient.

Other side effects of using proton-pump inhibitors (PPI) for long-term care include the following: 

  • Increased susceptibility to infections like hospital-acquired pneumonia and Clostridium difficile infection (pseudomembranous enterocolitis). 
  • Increased risk of bone fracture due to reduced calcium absorption.
  • It is also associated with the risk of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in patients with ascites. 

Omeprazole serves as both substrate and inhibitor for CYP2C19. Thus, omeprazole may inhibit the activation of clopidogrel and decrease its antiplatelet action.

Other options:

Option A: Misoprostol produces diarrhea, with or without cramps. It can also cause clinical exacerbations of inflammatory bowel disease.

Option B: The most common side effect of sucralfate is constipation. It should be avoided in patients with renal failure who are at risk of aluminum overload.

Option D: H2 receptor antagonists like cimetidine produces side effects like diarrhea, headache, drowsiness, fatigue, muscular pain, constipation, and gynecomastia.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below. These inclusions are periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. Which type of emphysema does this patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The presence of PAS-positive and diastase-resistant inclusion bodies in the hepatocytes is suggestive of α1 antitrypsin deficiency. This condition is associated with panacinar type of emphysema.

α1-antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin (α1AT) into the serum. Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema.

It also causes liver disease as a consequence of the abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in some cases. Liver biopsy round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes that are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. 

Emphysema is a condition in which the air spaces distal to the terminal bronchiole are abnormally enlarged due to irreversible damage to their walls. This results in poor gaseous exchange and progressive air trapping.

Emphysema can be of four major types depending on the areas affected: (1) centriacinar, (2) panacinar, (3) paraseptal, and (4) irregular.

Out of these, only the pan-acinar type is associated with α1-antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency and liver damage. In this type of emphysema, the acini from the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli are uniformly enlarged.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

  • Commonly seen in smokers

questions.text: An air conditioner technician presents with diarrhea, high fever, chest pain, and dyspnea. Chest radiograph showed pleural effusion and patchy pulmonary infiltrates. The gram staining of the pleural fluid showed the following organism. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of gram-negative bacilli point towards the diagnosis of legionnaire's disease for which the drug of choice is azithromycin. 

Legionnaire’s disease is caused by Legionella pneumophila. They are found in lakes, streams, and other water bodies. Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc.

It is mostly asymptomatic under the age of 55 years. Infection is usually severe in immunocompromised patients. It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhoea, and delirium. On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. 

A milder form of a clinical syndrome known as Pontiac fever, which is usually self-limiting and only has mild symptoms of fever, myalgia, and headache.

Microscopy of the sputum samples shows numerous leucocytes without any organism. Gram staining of the sterile sites like pleural fluid and lung tissues show faint gram-negative bacilli. They require a counterstain of basic fuschin as safranin stains the bacteria poorly. They are a group of fastidious, aerobic gram-negative bacteria. They can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar.

Diagnosis is established with the help of direct fluorescent antibody tests and BCYE culture specimens. Urine antigen tests and molecular assays may also be used.

Azithromycin is the drug of choice. Respiratory quinolones such as levofloxacin can also be used as alternatives to macrolides.

The total duration of therapy is 10-14 days for immunocompetent hosts and up to 3 weeks for immunosuppressed patients. 

The below image shows the Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test.


B-lactams, monobactams, and aminoglycosides are considered ineffective.

questions.text: Which among the following options is the most common presentation of retinoblastoma in children?
questions.solution:
Strabismus is the second most common presentation of retinoblastoma in children. So, the best answer for the question among the given options would be strabismus. The most common presentation is always leukocoria.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. It is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.

It is of 4 types:

  • Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye.
  • Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leads to retinal detachment.
  • Mixed type.
  • A diffuse infiltrating type.

Presenting features of retinoblastoma in decreasing order:

  • Leukocoria or amaurotic cat’s eye - a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye
  • Poor vision

The image given below shows leukocoria.

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
 
Enucleation is done when
  • More than half of the retina is involved.
  • Involvement of the optic nerve.
  • Involvement of the anterior chamber and presence of glaucoma.

The illustration given below shows the management of retinoblastoma.

Note- The most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma is through direct invasion. It can invade the optic nerve and spread to the brain, or it can also directly spread to the sclera or orbit.

Related Pearl: Reese Ellsworth classification for retinoblastoma

  • Solitary tumor, <4DD, at or behind equator
  • Multiple tumors, all <4DD, all at or behind the equator
2 Favourable
  • Solitary tumor, 4–10 DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all 4–10DD all behind the equator
3 Possible
  • Any lesion anterior to equator
  • Solitary tumor, >10DD behind equator
4 Unfavorable
  • Multiple tumors, some >10 DD
  • Any lesion extending anteriorly to ora serrata

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Optic nerve injury following sinus surgery (FESS) is due to the removal of which of the following ethmoidal cells?
questions.solution:
Optic nerve injury following sinus surgery (FESS) is due to the removal of Onodi cells.

Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. The optic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells.

Option A: Haller cells are a type of anterior ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillary sinus. 

Option B: Agger nasi is an anterior ethmoidal cell that is present in the agger nasi ridge.

Option D: Bulla ethmoidalis is the ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process and forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris through which the maxillary, frontal and anterior ethmoidal sinuses drain.

questions.text: A patient who presented with clinical features of hematuria and proteinuria of >500 mg/dL is diagnosed with glomerulonephritis.  The findings of urine microscopy are shown below. Identify the cast.
questions.solution:
Urine microscopy shows orange-red to brown casts, which are RBC casts. This finding is specific to glomerulonephritis and vasculitis. 

RBC casts form as RBCs entering the tubule fluid become trapped in the cylindrical mold of Tamm-Horsfall protein.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the casualty with an injury to his leg. On examination, bruises and ecchymoses of varying ages are noted all over the body. The x-ray shows a spiral fracture of the femur. Which of the following is less likely to be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Head injury as the most common cause of death

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with a spiral fracture of the femur and bruises of various ages points to a diagnosis of battered baby syndrome, where evidence of strangling or stabbing is less likely to be seen.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. The syndrome is also known as child abuse syndrome, non-accidental injury of childhood, Caffey's syndrome, and maltreatment syndrome in children.

The syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury vary with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Classical features:

  • Multiple bruises, lacerations, and abrasions of varying ages and shapes all over the body
  • Round pitted burns from cigarette stubs
  • Tear of the frenulum resulting from efforts to silence a crying or screaming child
  • Infantile whiplash syndrome - subdural hematoma and intraocular bleeding as a result of shaking the child, as described by Caffey
  • Subgaleal hematoma
  • Traumatic alopecia, appearing as bald patches
  • Perforations and rupture of abdominal viscera
  • Retinal separation, vitreous, subconjunctival, and retinal haemorrhages and black eye

Skeletal injuries that are commonly seen:

  • Skull fractures
  • Large periosteal hematomas
  • Epiphyseal separation and periosteal shearing in the limbs
  • Transverse and spiral fractures of long bones - Due to compression, bending, and direct forcible blows
  • Fractures of ribs in the midaxillary line due to anteroposterior compression of the chest
  • Fractures at the costochondral junctions due to violent squeezing of the chest from side to side
  • Multiple rib fractures (called knobbing fractures) along the posterior angles of the ribs, in the paravertebral gutter, giving rise to the string-of-beads appearance on x-ray (Option B)

A skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of the appendicular skeleton, skull, and spine

Head injury is the most common cause of death in battered baby syndrome (Option C), followed by rupture of an abdominal organ(Option D).

questions.text: An HIV-positive pregnant woman delivers a male baby vaginally at term. What is the next step of management in this baby?

choices.text: Start nevirapine syrup once daily at birth
Start zidovudine syrup only after a positive PCR test at birth
Start nevirapine syrup only after a positive PCR test at 6 weeks
Do not start nevirapine or cotrimoxazole before a definitive diagnosis

questions.solution:
The next step in the management of a baby born to an HIV-positive mother is to start nevirapine syrup (2 mg/kg/dose) once daily at birth.

All infants born to HIV-positive mothers test positive for HIV antibodies due to passive transfer from the infected mother. Babies who remain uninfected may become seroconverters after losing maternal antibodies around 6-12 months of age. Thus antibody testing is not used for the diagnosis of HIV infection in babies born to infected mothers.

The diagnosis of HIV infection in babies born to HIV-infected mothers is done by HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program (early infant diagnosis) now uses HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample.

All babies should be started with syrup nevirapine or syrup nevirapine and zidovudine (in high-risk infants) at birth irrespective of infective status. Cotrimoxazole suspension is started at 4-6 weeks.

The dried blood spot is sent for RNA PCR at 6 weeks. If the test turns positive, then a whole blood sample is sent for HIV-1 PCR. If the test turns positive, cotrimoxazole suspension is continued and anti-retroviral therapy is started.

If the test turned negative, nevirapine syrup is stopped at 6 weeks of age and cotrimoxazole suspension is continued till the next PCR test, usually at 6 months. A negative test at 6 months excludes cotrimoxazole from the therapy.

Exclusive breastfeeding can be continued till 1 year of age and gradually stopped one month after that so that the baby remains free from HIV antibodies at the time of antibody testing around 18 months.

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with fatigue. She had mild pallor on physical examination. Lab values reveal Hb -  9.8 g/dl, MCV - 106 fL, Platelets - 1,80,000/cu.mm, leukocytes - 7800/cu.mm. Which of the following would favor a diagnosis of Vit B12 deficiency over folic acid deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with lab findings showing high MCV is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia. The presence of increased methylmalonyl Co-A favors Vit B12 deficiency. In folic acid deficiency, methyl malonyl CoA levels are normal.

Peripheral smear findings:

  • Macro-ovalocytes
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • Reticulocyte count is low
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anaemia is severe
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules

The image given below shows hypersegmented neutrophils seen in megaloblastic anaemia.

 

Other Options:

Option A: Oval macrocytes can be seen in both Vit B12 deficiency as well as folic acid deficiency.

Option B: If peripheral neuropathy had been present, it woukd have favoured Vit B12 deficiency. 

Option C: Homocysteine levels are increased in both Vit B12 deficiency as well as folic acid deficiency. 

Bone marrow findings:

  • Markedly hypercellular as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors.
  • The sieve-like pattern of chromatin of immature precursors (Megaloblasts)
  • Granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms
  • Megakaryocytes can be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei
  • The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia
