Related Pearl: Schilling Test

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. The test is then repeated with an additional component that can promote vitamin B12 absorption. If the additional component is able to correct the defect and radiolabeled vitamin B12 is absorbed, it will be detected in the urine.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with blurring of vision and the presence of a dark spot with distorted vision in his right eye for the past week. He has been taking steroid tablets for asthma. His best corrected visual acuity measured 6/24 in his right eye and 6/6 in his left eye. Posterior segment examination is shown in the image. What is the first-line management for this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with visual abnormalities, history of steroid intake, and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment are suggestive of central serous retinopathy. Discontinuation of steroid use is the first line of management in this case.

Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) is an idiopathic disorder characterized by a localized serous detachment of the sensory retina at the macula.

Recent studies implicate abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Risk factors:

  • Age: young adults (20–50 years)
  • Sex: male > female
  • Steroid intake 
  • Emotional stress
  • Pregnancy
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Hypertension
  • Sleep apnea syndrome

Clinical features:

  • Mostly unilateral
  • Retinal detachment - Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent
  • FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern
  • OCT - optically empty neurosensory elevation at macular region.

Spontaneous resolution is seen in most cases and hence observation is enough. Steroids are contraindicated. The disease is usually self-limiting but may recur.

Other treatment options for recurrent and chronic cases: Laser photocoagulation, photodynamic therapy, and intravitreal anti-VEGF.

The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/ enlarging dot sign - A small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size - seen in Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR).

The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing smokestack appearance - A small hyperfluorescent spot that ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom - seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

 The image below depicts optical coherence tomography (OCT) showing fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal detachment - seen in CSR.

questions.text: In a village, out of 20 women taking contraceptives this year, 7 women reported that they conceived accidentally. During the review period, the duration of exposure to the contraceptive was 30 months for all of these women. Calculate the pearl index.
questions.solution:
The pearl index in this case is 14. Pearl index is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, whatever its outcome. 

Total accidental pregnancies  = 7

In the denominator, the total months of exposure to oral contraceptives are considered. The total period under review is 20 women x 30 months each = 600 months.

Substituting the values in the above equation, we get:

Pearl index = (7 x 1200)/600 = 14 per 100 woman-years of exposure(HWY)

 

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to child psychiatry OPD with complaints of repetitive non-verbal gestures for communication. His parents also mention that he prefers to be alone in school always and does not interact with any of his peers. He has very restricted interests in activities. His IQ level, cognitive development, and language skills are normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 5-year-old boy with repetitive non-verbal gestures for communication, impaired peer relationships, and restricted interest in activities with a normal IQ and language skills points towards a diagnosis of Asperger syndrome.

Asperger syndrome is an autistic spectrum disorder characterised by a wide range of impairments in social communication and restricted and repetitive behaviours. The aetiology is complex, with genetic and potentially environmental and perinatal contributions. It predominantly affects boys after 3 years of age. It is usually not associated with mental retardation, and a normal IQ, along with competencies in social skills, is considered a good prognostic factor.

Asperger syndrome is characterised by:

  • Impairment in social interaction and development:
    • markedly abnormal nonverbal communicative gestures
    • failure to develop peer relationships at the expected level
  • Restricted interests and patterns of behaviour
  • No significant delay in language, clinically significant cognitive delay, or adaptive impairment

Treatment of Asperger's syndrome involves promoting social communication and peer relationships. Very often, these children are highly verbal and have excellent academic achievement. To help these individuals in social and work settings, self-sufficiency and problem-solving techniques can be utilised.

As per the current updates (DSM-5), autism spectrum disorder (ASD) includes several conditions that are characterized by early onset of severe delay in the development of social and communicative skills and also unusual responses to the environment.

The diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder are as follows:

  1. Persistent deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts
  2. Restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviour, interests, or activities
  3. Symptoms must be present in the early developmental period
  4. Symptoms cause clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of social functioning
  5. These disturbances are not better explained by intellectual disability or global developmental delay.

Other options:

Option A: Rett’s syndrome is seen exclusively in girls, where deterioration of developmental milestones, head circumference, and overall growth occurs after 5 months of age. The absence of such a history of deterioration from previous normal development, along with the absence of other characteristic features of Rett's syndrome like- stereotypic motions (eg-hand wringing), poor coordination, ataxia, complete loss of verbal abilities, respiratory difficulties, and seizures makes a diagnosis of Rett syndrome unlikely. 

Options C & D: Heller syndrome/Childhood disintegrative disorder, occurring between the ages of 3–5 years, is characterized by a significant developmental regression after a period of normal development for at least two years. This results in a deterioration of behavioural and adaptive functioning, including self-help skills, with loss of language and social skills, along with stereotyped movements and compulsive behaviour. The absence of these features makes a diagnosis of Childhood disintegrative syndrome unlikely.

questions.text: A patient with acute intestinal obstruction and bowel distension is posted for immediate laparotomy. Which of the following anesthetic agent is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Nitrous oxide is contraindicated in a patient with intestinal obstruction and bowel distension. This is due to its tendency of rapid diffusion into air-containing cavities than nitrogen in the blood, thus increasing the pressure.

Nitrous oxide is the least potent inhalational anesthetic agent. It has a very high diffusion capacity than nitrogen (air) itself, which causes the cavity to expand. Thus it is avoided in cases like pneumothorax, air embolism, acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention, intracranial air, pulmonary air cysts, intraocular air bubbles, and tympanic membrane grafting.

It can even diffuse into tracheal tube cuffs, thus increasing its pressure and hampering mucosal blood circulation. It is also avoided in patients at high risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV).

Other side effects include bone marrow depression, megaloblastic anemia, teratogenicity and peripheral neuropathy.

Other options:

Option B - Desflurane is avoided in patients with severe hypovolemia, malignant hyperthermia, and intracranial hypertension.

Option C - Halothane is avoided in patients with unexplained liver dysfunction, intracranial space-occupying lesions and reduced left ventricular function.

Option D - Isoflurane has no unique contraindications but has to be avoided in patients with the risk of developing malignant hyperthermia as it can be a triggering agent.  

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients.

questions.text: A family of four from London developed recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea and abdominal pain after their trip to Bali. Stool culture on MacConkey medium is given below. Biochemical tests done show IMViC ++-- and negative Eiken's test. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin secreted by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette along with lactose fermenting MacConkey agar (bright pink), IMViC : ++--, and negative Eiken's test is suggestive of Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)/traveler's diarrhea caused by the E. coli heat-stable enterotoxin which acts by activation of cGMP in the intestine.

Persons from developed countries visiting endemic areas often suffer from ETEC diarrhea, a condition known as Traveler's diarrhea. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is the most common cause of Traveler’s Diarrhoea. It can range from mild watery diarrhea to fatal disease, similar to cholera.

The first step in pathogenesis is adherence to the intestinal mucosa by fimbria called colonization factor antigens. ETEC then produces enterotoxins which may be either heat-labile (LT) or heat-stable (ST).

This is distinguished by several tests, one of the serological tests being Precipitin test (Eikien's) which is positive in LT and negative in ST. IMViC test includes indole, methyl red (MR), Voges-Proskauer (VP) and citrate utilisation. E.coli is indole positive and MR positive, and VP negative and citrate negative.

Two types of heat-stable enterotoxins are known :

  1. STa/ST I
  2. STb/ST II

STa acts by activation of the cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) in the intestine. This is rapid and accumulates fluid in the intestine in the infant mice (infant mouse test) which is the standard method for the demonstration of STa.

The mode of action of STb is unknown but it is neither through cAMP or cGMP.

ETEC with heat-labile enterotoxins act by activation of cAMP.

  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A male patient presented with headache and blurry vision. Fundoscopy showed bilateral papilledema. MRI of the brain was normal and showed no space-occupying lesions. On further questioning, he admits to taking high-dose multivitamin supplements. Which vitamin excess is likely to cause the above scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of increased intracranial pressure in the absence of space-occupying lesions points towards the diagnosis of pseudotumor cerebri. Vitamin A excess is the likely cause.

Toxicity occurs when the accumulation of vitamin A goes beyond the capacity of intracellular binding proteins. The unbound vitamin A causes membrane lysis and tissue damage.

Related Pearl: Hypervitaminosis A

Hypervitaminosis A:

  • Vitamin A excess can present as two forms: vitamin A toxicity and carotenaemia.
  •  Hypervitaminosis A results from overconsumption of non‐prescription nutritional supplements, prescription medications containing vitamin A derivatives and foods high in vitamin A.
  • Carotenaemia is a benign disorder caused by excessive β‐carotene intake.
  • In carotenaemia, carotenes are excreted from sebaceous glands and sweat glands, and ultimately deposit in the stratum corneum. This results in carotenoderma.
  • Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.
  • Individuals with chronic hypervitaminosis A have dry and scaly skin, desquamation, cheilitis, alopecia, follicular hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation, associated pseudotumor cerebri and skeletal changes (premature closure of the epiphyses and pathological bone fractures).
  • Prognosis:
    • Vitamin A toxicity: discontinuation of vitamin A leads to resolution of almost all symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, with the exception of cirrhosis and sequelae related to pseudotumour cerebri.
    • Carotenaemia: Excellent prognosis with no clear long‐term adverse effects. Pigmentary changes resolve within weeks to months of decreasing β‐carotene intake.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents features of heart failure 1 month after she had a vaginal delivery. Her pregnancy was uneventful, except for increased levels of prolactin. She has no history of heart disease during or before her pregnancy. Echocardiography shows left ventricular systolic dysfunction. All of the following are known predisposing factors for this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of heart failure during the puerperal period without prior heart disease, associated with left ventricular systolic dysfunction, is suggestive of peripartum cardiomyopathy. Pregnancy at a young age is not a known predisposing factor for this condition.

Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy. It develops during the last month of pregnancy or within the first 5 months following delivery. 

The predisposing factors include:

  • Cardiac gene mutations, involving several genes like TTNC1, TTN, and STAT3.
  • Twin pregnancy/ multifetal gestation
  • Smoking
  • Preeclampsia 

Other proposed causes include viral myocarditis, abnormal immune response to pregnancy, malnutrition, inflammation, etc.

This condition is associated with increased secretion of prolactin by the pituitary and antiangiogenic molecule sFlt-1 (soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase) by the placenta at term gestation.

It is diagnosed using Pearson's criteria:

  • Development of cardiac failure in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months after delivery
  • Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure
  • Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy, and
  • Left ventricular systolic dysfunction seen on echocardiography, such as depressed ejection fraction or fractional shortening along with a dilated left ventricle.

Management involves treating the features of heart failure. Bromocriptine has been found useful in this condition. Many women recover within 6 months of delivery, while some continue to have residual effects.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a history of a minor fall. The affected limb is in extension and has slight external rotation. The radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is false about the condition?

choices.text: Malunion can happen if this condition is not treated
The patient may be able to walk
Shortening of limb is less than 1 inch

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and radiograph are suggestive of an impacted fractured neck of the femur, which is an intracapsular fracture. The neck of femur fractures almost never unite, hence nonunion is more likely to occur than malunion. 

Malunion is more likely to occur in inter-trochanteric or extracapsular fractures, as they are more likely to get displaced.

Neck of femur fractures can occur in the elderly age group due to a trivial fall, however, it is usually due to a more severe injury if it occurs in young adults. Patients have painful movements of the hip joint, but may be able to walk. On examination, there is tenderness in the hip, shortening of the limb <1 inch, and external rotation of the affected limb. Active straight leg raising is not possible.

Radiological features of this fracture include:

  • Break in the medial cortex of the neck
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter being more prominent
  • Overriding of the greater trochanter, so that it lies at the level of the head of the femur
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in the Shenton's line

In an impacted fracture, only bending of trabeculae may be visible.

Complications of fracture neck of the femur are non-union, avascular necrosis, and secondary osteoarthritis. Non-union occurs due to poor blood supply, inadequate reduction or fixation, and poor healing that occurs in intra-capsular fractures. 

After a fracture of the femoral neck, all the medullary blood supply and most of the capsular blood supply to the head are affected. Due to this diminished vascularity, avascular necrosis of a part or the entire femoral head commonly occurs. This can lead to non-union. MRI is the best investigation to diagnose avascular necrosis.

Impacted fractures can be treated conservatively or with screws if there is fear of fracture displacement. Displaced or unimpacted fractures are treated with internal fixation. In the elderly, the head is often excised and replaced with a prosthesis.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: A breast cancer patient underwent mastectomy. Which of the following is not an indication for postmastectomy radiotherapy in these patients?
questions.solution:
T1N0 and T2N0 breast cancer is not an indication for post-mastectomy radiotherapy. In such patients, mastectomy and sentinel lymph node dissection is sufficient for local control, and radiation therapy is not required.

Indications for post-mastectomy radiotherapy in breast cancer patients:

  • Tumor size >5 cm
  • Positive surgical margins
  • Involvement of >4 axillary nodes
  • T4 disease

Post-mastectomy radiation therapy improves local control and overall survival. It is directed at the chest wall and often includes the draining lymph nodes of the breast.

questions.text: A 13-month-old child was brought with an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for 10 minutes, following a fever of 100.4°F.  There is no history of any prior unprovoked seizures. Which of the following is not a major risk factor for the recurrence of the above condition?

choices.text: Age of child less than 1 year

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 13-month-old child presenting with generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for 10 minutes associated with high-grade fever in a neurologically healthy child is suggestive of febrile seizure. A family history of epilepsy is not a major risk factor for the recurrence of febrile seizures.

A family history of epilepsy is a minor risk factor for the recurrence of febrile seizures. 

Risk factors for the recurrence of febrile seizures:

Major:

  • Age less than 1 year
  • Duration of fever less than 24 hours (short duration of fever before the onset of febrile seizure)
  • Fever range: 38–39 °C (100.4–102.2°F)

Minor:

  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Low serum sodium level at the time of presentation

Having no risk factors carries a recurrence risk of around 12%.

Febrile seizures are seizures associated with a high-grade fever (more than 100.4°F). They occur between the age of 6 months to 5 years, without underlying intracranial infections or prior unprovoked seizures. 

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged (>15 min)
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent within 24 hours
Chances of going into epilepsy are 1% Chances of going into epilepsy are 6%

Simple febrile seizures will occur only once within 24 hours of the onset of fever in a neurologically normal child. Lumbar puncture should be performed at the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months of age (to exclude meningitis).

Electroencephalogram and neuroimaging are advised for children with risk factors for epilepsy or neurological abnormalities.

During acute episodes, intravenous lorazepam and midazolam are used for the termination of seizures if they last more than 5 minutes. Rectal diazepam is prescribed to use at home as rescue medication if febrile seizures last more than 5 minutes.

If the episodes of febrile seizures are 3 or more in 6 months, or 4 or more seizures in 1 year, oral clobazam (1 mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode can be used as intermittent prophylaxis.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is tasked with ensuring the disinfection of a water reservoir in a village to reduce the spread of water-borne illnesses. He uses the apparatus shown below. On adding the indicator, which of the following color changes indicates that the chlorine demand of the water sample is met?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Horrock's apparatus, which is used to measure the chlorine demand of water. The chlorine demand of the water sample is said to be met when water turns blue upon adding the indicator. 

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.solution:
The scenario of a 16-year-old girl with absent secondary sexual characters, normal stature, with XX karyotype and high FSH and LH is suggestive of pure gonadal dysgenesis.

46 XX and 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis without the phenotype of Turner's syndrome (short stature, webbed neck) is described as pure gonadal dysgenesis. It is characterized by the presence of primary amenorrhea with or without normal secondary sexual characteristics. 

Option A: Testicular feminizing syndrome occurs in karyotype XY. Secondary sexual characters are present and the uterus is absent.

Option C: Kallmann syndrome is a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. GnRH synthesis is reduced, therefore FSH and LH are low, and secondary sexual characters are absent.

Option D: Turner syndrome is associated with short stature and karyotype X0. Secondary sexual characters and the uterus is present, but the ovaries are streaked.

questions.text: A patient on anticoagulant therapy presents to the emergency room with severe bleeding. Further investigations showed that the cause is due to drug toxicity. The resident doctor administered fresh frozen plasma and vitamin K to reverse the effects. Which of the following drugs is likely to be the cause of the presenting features?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of warfarin toxicity. Vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma are used for the reversal of warfarin overdose.

Mechanism of action of warfarin: Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X and proteins C and S is induced by carboxylation of their glutamate residues, with the help of the reduced form of vitamin K as a cofactor. This reduced form of vitamin K needs to be constantly recycled back from its oxidized form for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which is competitively inhibited by warfarin. Hence, there will be a reduction in the activation of coagulation factors.

 

The image below shows warfarin's mechanism of action.

Warfarin is used for the treatment of acute deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism and for the prevention of stroke or systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve. 

The adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation).

The therapeutic dose of warfarin is monitored by an INR range of 2–3. Warfarin toxicity can occur when the INR exceeds 4 and can lead to fatal bleeding. Treatment includes withholding of warfarin, administration of vitamin K, and transfusions of blood or fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors.

Other options:

Option A: Andexanet alfa is used as a reversal agent of factor Xa inhibitors (rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban).

Option B: Protamine sulfate is indicated for the reversal of heparin overdose.

Option C: Idarucizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (Fab) that binds to dabigatran and its acyl-glucuronide metabolites with an affinity higher than that between thrombin and dabigatran. It is used for the reversal of dabigatran toxicity.

questions.text: A man was brought to the hospital after he suffered a stab wound. CT-scan revealed an injury to the part of the artery that lies lateral to pectoralis minor muscle. Which of the following vessels is least likely to have its flow cut off completely?
questions.solution:
The third part of the axillary artery lies lateral to the pectoralis minor muscle. Injury in this part causes decreased blood supply in all branches of the third part of the axillary artery. The superior thoracic artery is a branch of the first part of the axillary artery, and is, therefore, the least likely to be affected.

The axillary artery is the continuation of the subclavian artery. It extends from the outer border of the 1st rib to the lower border of teres major, from where it continues as the brachial artery.

Pectoralis minor divides the artery into 3 parts (proximal to, posterior to, and lateral/distal to the muscle).

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with chronic cough, bronchiectasis, lower limb lymphedema, and the following nail findings. What are these nail findings called?
questions.solution:
This is an image showing yellow nails, and this feature is a component of the yellow nail syndrome. They can also occur due to secondary infection with Pseudomonas spp. or Candida spp.

Yellow nail syndrome consists of the triad of yellow nail discoloration, pulmonary manifestations (chronic cough, bronchiectasis, pleural effusion), and lower limb lymphedema. Chronic sinusitis is frequently associated with the triad.

The characteristic finding is the development of thickened and excessively curved, yellow nails. There is an almost complete stoppage of nail growth.

Other options -

Option A: Leukonychia is a white discoloration of the nail. True leukonychia occurs due to dysfunction of the nail matrix. Apparent leukonychia is seen due to pallor of the nail bed, as seen in chronic anemia, edema, and vascular diseases.

Option C: Terry's nails are a type of apparent leukonychia of nearly the entire nail, with obliteration of the lunula, and a narrow band of normal, pink nail bed at the distal border. They are commonly associated with liver cirrhosis, congestive heart failure, and diabetes. 

Option D: In Lindsay's nails, also known as half-and-half nails, the proximal portion of the nail is white and the distal half is red, pink, or brown, with a sharp line of demarcation between the two halves. It is a rare finding and can be seen in yellow nail syndrome, chronic renal failure, Crohn's disease, Kawasaki's disease, Behcet's disease, cirrhosis, hyperthyroidism, zinc deficiency, citrullinemia, pellagra, HIV infection, and even in healthy persons.

Maybe, picking the obvious answer is a good idea, sometimes!

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with firm papules with a rough surface on the genitalia. Histopathology of the tissues from the lesion is shown below. These findings are seen in _____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing koilocytes are seen in papilloma virus infection.

Koilocytes are squamous epithelial cells with perinuclear cavitation, nuclear enlargement, coarse chromatin, and irregular nuclear membranes. A rim of condensed cytoplasm around the perinuclear cavitation gives the cell a halo or cleared-out appearance. Koilocytes are often seen in cervical cancer, premalignant lesions of the cervix, genital warts, and anal and oral cancers. 

Genital warts or condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths caused by human papillomavirus, that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. The lesions may be discrete or merge to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. 

The following image shows pap staining showing koilocytes.

Other options:

Option A: Polyomavirus infections are associated with the presence of decoy cells in histopathology. Decoy cells are epithelial cells with intranuclear viral inclusion bodies characterized by large, homogenous, amorphous ground-glass-like intranuclear inclusion bodies and a condensed rim of chromatin.

Option C: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection that appears as discrete, pearly, umbilicated papules. It is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies.

Option D: Granuloma inguinale infection usually presents as genital ulcers. It is characterized by large mononuclear cells, whose cytoplasm contains numerous organisms that show bipolar staining with a safety‐pin appearance, called Donovan bodies.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man with known hypertension was brought to the casualty. He had headaches, nausea, vertigo, right-sided hemiparesis, and aphasia. His CT scan is shown below. On detailed evaluation, intraventricular hemorrhage was found to be present, with hematoma of volume 32 cc and no evidence of infratentorial origin. GCS score was calculated to be 8. Calculate the ICH score.

ICH: Intracerebral hemorrhage
questions.solution:
The Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) score for the above clinical scenario is 4. ( Age 80 years: 1; Hematoma volume >30 cc: 1; Intraventricular hemorrhage present: 1; Infratentorial origin absent: 0; Glassgow coma scale score 5 to 12: 1)

ICH Score (maximum score: 6)

Parameter Value Score
Age < 80 years 0
≥80 years 1
Hematoma Volume <30 ccs 0
≥30 ccs 1
Intraventricular hemorrhage present  No 0
Yes 1
Infratentorial origin of hemorrhage  No 0
Yes 1
Glasgow Coma Scale score  13 to 15 0
5 to 12 1
3 to 4 2

The given CT image shows a left-sided rapidly expanding hyperdense lesion that causes a midline shift and is indicative of acute ICH.

ICH (bleeding into the brain tissue) is the second most common cause of stroke (15–30% of strokes) and the most deadly.

Risk factors of ICH: 

  • Hypertension: Chronic high BP
  • Age: More common after the age of 55 years, with the buildup of protein in walls of arteries, called amyloid angiopathy
  • Gender: More common in men.
  • Race: Affects African Americans and Asians more than whites, possibly due to the higher prevalence of hypertension in these races
  • Previous history of stroke: Increases risk 23 times
  • Alcohol use and street drugs: Cocaine and amphetamines increase risk.
  • Liver disease: Increases risk due to issues with blood clotting
  • The primary brain causes: Tumors, vascular anomalies, infection, and venous sinus thrombosis

Treatment:

Non-surgical: 

  • Clotting factor administration, if the patient was on blood thinners;
  • Blood pressure control to reduce the risk of more bleeding; and
  • Measuring and controlling ICP (pressure on brain tissue due to clot) 

Surgical: 

  • Stereotactic clot aspiration
  • Craniotomy, followed by clot removal

Below is a CT image of acute ICH.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 49-year-old man with a history of long-standing acne rosacea presented to the clinic with a pink-colored mass over his nose as shown in the image. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The image given depicts rhinophyma or potato tumor, which is due to sebaceous gland hypertrophy.

It is an unusual and late manifestation of rosacea, solely seen in middle-aged men. The patient presents with a pink, lobulated mass over the nose with vascular dilation. Large tumors can also cause obstruction of breathing and vision. Treatment consists of complete excision and skin grafting or carbon dioxide laser.

 Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis causes rhinoscleroma. It is a chronic granulomatous disease of the nose. It can extend to the nasopharynx, oropharynx, and larynx. Clinical features include foul-smelling nasal discharge and crusting, woody feeling of the external nose and upper lip (due to subdermal infiltration), stenosis of nares, adhesions in nose, etc. Biopsy shows characteristic Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient comes to the emergency department with pain in the right arm after sustaining a fall at home. X-ray reveals a spiral mid-shaft fracture of the humerus. She is unable to extend her wrist, and there is diminished sensation at the anatomical snuff box. Which is the most likely nerve injured in this case?
questions.solution:
In a patient with a fracture of the humerus, inability to extend the wrist, and diminished sensation at the anatomical snuff box, the most likely nerve that is injured is the radial nerve.

High lesions of the radial nerve occur following a humerus fracture. There is wrist drop, due to weakness of the radial extensors of the wrist, an inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joints, and an inability to elevate the thumb. Sensory loss on the skin over the anatomical snuff box may also be present.

Radial nerve injuries can also occur due to injuries in the shoulder, axilla (very high lesions), and elbow (low lesions). 

In very high lesions like the lesions around the shoulder joint and axilla and crutch palsy, there is a loss of extension of the wrist and hand. The triceps is paralyzed, and the triceps reflex is lost.

Low lesions occur due to the fracture or dislocations of the elbow. The wrist extension is preserved, but the patient cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joint. There is also a weakness in the extension of the thumb. These patients have a radial deviation of the wrist due to the lack of balancing action of the extensor carpi radialis brevis.

Option A: Median nerve palsy, at the level of the forearm and wrist, leads to an inability to abduct the thumb and loss of sensation over the lateral three and a half digits. When the injury to the median nerve is higher up, like in the arm, along with the symptoms mentioned above, there is paralysis of the long flexors to the thumb, index, and middle fingers, the radial wrist flexors, and the forearm pronator muscles. The hand is usually held with the ulnar fingers flexed and the index straight, which is called the pointing index sign.

Option B: Ulnar nerve is most commonly injured in flexion type of supracondylar fracture. In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. Hence, there is hyperextension at metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at interphalangeal joints. This causes claw hand deformity. There is numbness of the ulnar one and a half fingers. Finger abduction is weak, and there is a loss of thumb adduction.

Option D: Axillary nerve injury presents with an anesthetic patch over the deltoid muscle and deltoid muscle weakness. Although abduction can be initiated by supraspinatus, it cannot be maintained that is done by deltoid.

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to _____.
questions.solution:
The given life cycle belongs to Schistosoma haematobium.

S. haematobium or vesical blood fluke is a trematode that lives in the pelvic and vesical venous plexuses. Its lifecycle involves man as a definitive host and freshwater snails as the intermediate host. Infective forms of schistosomes are fork-tailed cercaria larva. The eggs are non-operculated with a characteristic spine at one end.

The eggs are passed in the urine of the infected person, which will hatch in the water to release free-living ciliated miracidia. Miracidia then penetrate a suitable intermediate host and reaches its liver. In the liver, they produce first and second-generation sporocysts. The second generation sporocyst undergoes asexual reproduction producing cercaria larva. These are then released into the water. Persons become infected by contact with water containing cercariae during bathing. After entering the human body, they migrate through the heart and pulmonary circulation to reach the liver, where they attain sexual differentiation. From the liver, they reach the pelvic and vesical venous plexus, where they mature, mate, and lay eggs.

Clinical features include acute schistosomiasis in the form of skin rash at the site of penetration (swimmer's itch) or anaphylactic symptoms due to the release of toxic metabolites. Chronic schistosomiasis presents with chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the bladder leading to obstructive uropathies. There is an increased risk for bladder carcinoma and calculus formation.

Diagnosis : 

  • Detection of eggs in urine microscopy and bladder mucosal biopsy.
  • ELISA for antigen detection 
  • Detection of S. haematobium adult worm microsomal antigen (HAMA) by 
    • Falcon assay screening test (HAMAFAST) or ELISA
    • HAMA enzyme-linked immunoelectrotransfer blot (HAMA-EITB).
  • Intradermal skin testing (Fairley's test)

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis.

The following are the unique features distinguishing schistosomes from other trematodes:

  • Only one intermediate host.
  • They are unisexual/dioecious.
  • They produce non-operculated eggs.
  • Mode of infection is by penetration of intact skin with the help of forked tails of cercariae

Forms of most trematodes that are infective to humans are metacercaria larvae.

questions.text: An angiography study was done for a patient who presented with chronic dysphagia. The following vascular anomaly of the aortic arch was found to be the cause. Identify the anomaly.
questions.solution:
The vascular anomaly that is causing the dysphagia in this patient is an aberrant right subclavian artery. This condition is known as dysphagia lusoria.

Dysphagia lusoria is dysphagia produced due to compression of the esophagus by a developmental vascular anomaly, often an aberrant right subclavian artery. It arises directly from the aortic arch.

It can be diagnosed by CT angiography. Treatment is surgical repair either by reconstruction or ligation of the aberrant right subclavian artery.

The CT image below shows the presence of an aberrant right subclavian artery:


The CECT below shows the origin of the aberrant right subclavian artery (red arrow) causing extrinsic compression of the esophagus.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with increased lower abdominal pain on the first two days of her menses, which subsides on the third day. There is no excessive bleeding. She started menstruating one year back. She has no other complaints, and her examination findings are normal. What is her condition best described as?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of lower abdominal pain with no associated symptoms or underlying cause is most likely to be primary dysmenorrhea. Onset within 2 years of menarche and symptoms during the beginning of menstruation further support the diagnosis.

Dysmenorrhea is defined as cramping pain accompanying menstruation.

Classification of dysmenorrhea:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhea affects more than half of post-pubescent women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles. It does not have any particular cause. 
  • Secondary (acquired) dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of organic pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, PID, and endometriosis.
    Unilateral dysmenorrhea can be seen in a rudimentary horn of the bicornuate uterus, IUCD users, and cervical stenosis.

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the most prevalent type, characterized by cramping pain before or at the start of menstruation, especially on the first and second days of menstruation.
  • Congestive dysmenorrhea is seen in PID, IUCD users, pelvic vein varicosities, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids. These patients have increasing pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain a few days before menstruation, after which they have rapid relief of the symptoms. 
  • Membranous dysmenorrhea is characterized by endometrial shedding as a cast during menses, and this passage of the cast leads to painful uterine cramps. It is the rarest variety.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with generalized body aches, fatigue, and anxiety for the past 4 months, but her sleep is not affected due to pain. On examination, increased pain sensitivity and tender bony prominences are noted. Laboratory and radiological investigations were normal. You suspect fibromyalgia in her. Which of the following drugs is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Duloxetine is preferred in fibromyalgia patients having pain along with fatigue and anxiety, as it has antidepressant action as well.

The examination findings of tender bony prominences (earlier considered as a part of the diagnostic evaluation) and increased pain sensitivity with associated low mood favor the diagnosis of fibromyalgia.

Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. Other symptoms include fatigue, depression, sleep disturbances, cognitive dysfunction, and anxiety. It is predominantly seen in females. 

Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue. This includes chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome, and other pelvic pain syndromes. It is a diagnosis of exclusion.

Treatment strategies include physical conditioning, strength training, exercise programs, cognitive-behavioral strategies, and transcutaneous electric nerve stimulation (TENS) for movement-evoked pain and fatigue.

Pharmacotherapy with single agents to treat multiple symptom domains is recommended. Cyclobenzaprine, pregabalin, and sedating antidepressants like amitriptyline are used in fibromyalgia pain associated with sleep disturbances (Option A, B). However, in patients having pain associated with fatigue, anxiety, or depression, drugs that have both analgesic and antidepressant/anxiolytic effects, such as duloxetine or milnacipran, are used.

Option C: Glucocorticoids are not effective against fibromyalgia-related symptoms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who had multiple episodes of pancreatitis presented with a history of mild epigastric pain and passage of foul-smelling greasy stools for the past 5 months. On further evaluation, he was diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis. The TIGAR-O system used in the assessment of the underlying condition is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The TIGAR-O classification system of chronic pancreatitis is an etiological approach used to classify chronic pancreatitis. It is based on the following factors:

  • Toxic-metabolic - alcohol, smoking, hypercalcemia, hyperlipidemia
  • Idiopathic
  • Genetic - PRSS1, CFTR, and SPINK1 genes
  • Autoimmune - autoimmune chronic pancreatitis, IgG4-related disease
  • Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis
  • Obstructive - pancreas divisum, duct obstruction, malignancy

Chronic pancreatitis is an irreversible progressive inflammatory destruction of pancreatic tissue. It results from recurrent attacks of acute pancreatitis, which clinically presents with severe abdominal pain and is later followed by exocrine and endocrine pancreatic insufficiency. 

Radiologically, there may be calcifications seen on x-ray and CT. MRI reveals multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. These strictures and stones cause alternate stenosis and dilatation of the pancreatic duct, leading to the chain-of-lakes appearance. ERCP and EUS can be used for imaging the accurate pancreatic anatomy.

Other features seen are visible side branches, cysts, lobularity, an irregular main pancreatic duct, hyperechoic foci and strands, dilatation of the main pancreatic duct, and hyperechoic margins of the main pancreatic duct. The presence of four or more of these features is highly suggestive of chronic pancreatitis.

Most patients can be managed medically, which involves pain relief, management of diabetes, and maintenance of nutrition. Surgical interventions are done to relieve obstruction of the pancreatic duct, bile duct, or duodenum, or if there are complications.

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

Genetic

  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)

  • Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

  • Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

  • Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)

  • Radiation-induced

  • Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

Related Pearl: Surgical procedures for chronic pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of the pancreatic tail

A longitudinal pancreatotomy shows segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis. Following mobilization of a Roux limb of the jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his right scrotum. Physical examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum with an absent cremasteric reflex. On Doppler ultrasound, there is an absence of arterial flow to the right testis. Surgical exploration is done and the testis was not necrotic. What is to be done for the testis in the contralateral scrotum?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a boy presenting with acute pain in the scrotum, absent cremasteric reflex, and absent arterial flow on doppler is suggestive of testicular torsion. During surgical management of testicular torsion, orchiopexy at the same sitting is to be done for the contralateral testis which is viable.

Testicular torsion is a condition where the blood supply to the testis is compromised due to the twisting of the spermatic cord resulting in ischemia of epididymis and testis. The condition is most common in adolescent males. The risk factors for torsion testis are undescended testis, testicular tumor, and bell-clapper deformity of the gubernaculum.

Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting, apyrexia. Testis seems to be high in the scrotum and the tender, twisted spermatic cord can sometimes be palpated. The cremasteric reflex is lost on the side of the affected testis.

A diagnosis is arrived at primarily on clinical grounds. Doppler ultrasound scanning shows absent or decreased intratesticular blood flow compared to the contralateral side.

Immediate scrotal exploration is indicated even if there is a doubt regarding the diagnosis. An incision is taken along the midline (median raphe) or bilateral scrotal incisions are taken.

Surgical placement of the testicle in the scrotum is called orchidopexy (or orchiopexy). It is primarily used as a procedure to correct undescended testis but it is also used in testicular torsion.

Initially, the testis is detorsed and an intraoperative Doppler ultrasound is done. If the testis is found to be viable, a three-point fixation with non-absorbable sutures between the tunica albuginea and dartos fascia of the testis is done to prevent recurrence. 

In the same exploration, orchiopexy should be done to the contralateral testes to prevent future contralateral torsion as there is a chance for the same anatomical deformity to be present in the contralateral side.

Other options:

Options A and D: Contralateral testis will be at high risk of torsion in the future. Hence, orchidopexy has to be done in the same surgical exploration.

Option B: Orchidectomy is preferred in non-viable or necrotic testes.

questions.text: What is the modified shock index of a patient who has a heart rate of 105 beats/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 90 mmHg, and mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 70 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
The Modified shock index = HR/MAP = 105/70 = 1.5  

The shock index is a hemodynamic stability indicator. In patients with shock, it is a better predictor of mortality than blood pressure or heart rate alone. A shock index >0.9 is indicative of higher mortality.

Original shock index = HR/SBP 

The original shock index does not include the diastolic blood pressure (DBP) which is why the modified shock index was developed. The modified shock index is a more sensitive indicator of tissue perfusion than the original shock index. In critically ill patients, the DBP decreases earlier than SBP, hence, the modified shock index using MAP is better suited to assess the severity of shock.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. The biopsy findings of H&E staining and immunohistochemistry for BCL2 are given in the images below. The results of immunophenotyping of the cells are as follows: CD19+, CD20+, CD10+, and CD5-. What is the translocation seen in this disease?

H&E: Hematoxyline and eosin
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of follicular lymphoma. The majority of follicular lymphomas have the characteristic t(14;18) translocation.

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center.

This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

On histopathology, the lymph nodes exhibit a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions: 

  • Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm
  • Centroblasts - large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm

In most cases, there is a majority of centrocytes.

Other options:

Option B: t(9;22) results in Philadelphia chromosome, which causes chronic myeloid leukemia.

Option C: t(8;14) is seen in Burkitt lymphoma.

Option D: t(11,14) is seen in mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: All of the following are health care delivery indicators, except _______.
questions.solution:
Bed turnover ratio is an example of utilization rates of health services, not a health care delivery indicator.

The provision of health care and the equity of distribution of health resources in different parts of the country are reflected by health care delivery indicators.

Examples are:

  • Doctor-population ratio
  • Doctor-nurse ratio (option D)
  • Population-bed ratio (option C)
  • Population per health/ subcentre
  • Population per trained birth attendant (option A)

Utilization of services is expressed as the proportion of people in need of a service who receive it in a given period. It is considered to be indicative of the health status of the population.

The following are utilization rates:

  • The proportion of infants immunized against 9 diseases in the expanded program on immunization (EPI)
  • The proportion of women receiving antenatal care and supervised delivery 
  • Percentage of population using family planning methods
  • Bed occupancy rate
  • The average length of stay
  • Bed turnover ratio

questions.text: A 6-month-old child was brought by concerned parents with the following lesion. The child is otherwise healthy. What is the first-line management in this case?

choices.text: Start antipruritic medication to relive the itching
Remove of the scalp crusts using mild shampoo and toothbrush
Start topical calcineurin inhibitors for 1 week

questions.solution:
The above image shows cradle cap, which is suggestive of seborrheic dermatitis (SD). First-line treatment for cradle cap is the removal of the scalp crusts using mild shampoo and a toothbrush.

Cradle cap is the infantile form of seborrheic dermatitis which presents as an adherent yellowish scale crust. It may present with serous ooze and a greasy crust on the crown and front of the scalp, to create a firm mass that may progress to involve the whole scalp. It is a mild, self-limiting disease occurring in the first three months of life and resolves spontaneously by the first year of life.

It is caused by lipophilic yeasts of Malassezia species which are enormously present in seborrheic areas like the scalp, face, and body folds. It results in an abnormal shedding of keratinocytes, degradation of sebum, and disruption of the lipid balance on the skin surface. 

 According to NICE recommendations, treatment for infantile seborrheic dermatitis includes the following: 

  • First-line therapy - Removal of scalp crusts with baby shampoo and gentle brushing. Petroleum jelly or warmed vegetable oil can be used for overnight soaking and daily bathing with soap is advised.
  • Other treatment measures include topical imidazole creams and topical steroids.

Adult SD can be treated with topical anti-fungal therapy, keratolytic, and proper personal hygiene practices.

Differential diagnoses of infantile SD include tinea capitis, impetigo, acrodermatitis enteropathica, zinc deficiency, and histiocytosis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient presents with bands of pruritic, flagellate, and erythematous lesions over the trunk and extremities. He is a known case of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and is on treatment with an ABVD regimen for the past 4 months. What is the drug responsible for the presenting features?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of flagellate dermatitis. It is a specific adverse effect of bleomycin.

Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic. It acts by generating free radicals by binding with a reducing agent (iron) in the presence of oxygen. This metal-drug complex cleaves the DNA of the tumor cell.

It is used as a component in the treatment regimens of Hodgkin's lymphoma and testicular cancer.

Bleomycin has a bone marrow–sparing effect. The major adverse events include flagellate dermatitis and pulmonary toxicity, which may progress to pulmonary fibrosis.

Flagellate dermatitis starts as bands of pruritic, flagellate, and erythematous lesions over the trunk and extremities. These rashes heal with persistent flagellate hyperpigmentation. No treatment is necessary since the lesions usually disappear on the stoppage of the drug. These lesions respond to topical corticosteroids.

The image given below shows flagellate dermatitis.

Other agents causing flagellate dermatitis are docetaxel, bendamustine, and peplomycin.

Other options:

Option A: Adriamycin/doxorubicin is an anthracycline antineoplastic drug. It is used for the treatment of malignant lymphomas, Ewing sarcoma, soft-tissue sarcomas, and breast carcinoma. The major adverse effects include myelosuppression, cardiomyopathy, alopecia, and stomatitis. 

Option C: Vinblastine is a vinca alkaloid. Adverse effects of vinblastine include leucopenia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and anorexia. Local reactions like cellulitis and phlebitis may occur on drug extravasation during the injection.

Option D: Dacarbazine is a methylating agent used in the treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma, malignant melanoma, and sarcomas. The adverse effects include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, flu-like syndrome, and alopecia.

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios is not included under cognizable offense?

choices.text: Accepting gift hampers on referral of patient
Operating under the influence of alcohol

questions.solution:
Accepting gift hampers on the referral of patients is not a cognizable offense. 

Accepting gift hampers on the referral of patients comes under dichotomy. It is a type of unethical act, wherein a physician offers or receives any gift or bonus for referring or procuring any patient for medical or surgical treatment. 

A cognizable offense is that in which a police officer can arrest a person without having a warrant from the magistrate. Examples include cases of rape, murder, dowry death, and death due to rash or negligent acts. In such cases, the individual is sent by the police to the doctor for a medical examination. 

Punishments for cognizable offense: 

  • Death
  • Imprisonment for life
  • Imprisonment could be rigorous and involve hard labor
  • Forfeiture of property
  • Fine

In non-cognizable offenses, the accused cannot be arrested without a warrant issued by the magistrate. The injured person can directly go to the doctor or he may file an affidavit in the court of a magistrate, who will send him to the doctor for examination and report. 

Other options:

Options B and C: Operating under the influence of alcohol and performing amputation on the wrong limb come under criminal negligence. Criminal negligence is when a doctor lacks gross skill or care while treating, which results in serious injury/death of the patient, or when an illegal act is performed by a doctor. Criminal negligence is a cognizable offense.

Option D: Ragging in any form is a cognizable offense.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man who recently visited a forest reserve in Karnataka presented with sudden onset of headache, myalgia, fever, and severe prostration. He was diagnosed to have Kyasanur Forest disease. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the disease?

choices.text: It is caused by a virus of Flaviviridae family.
It is a transmitted by Haemaphysalis spinigera.
Dead monkeys serve as the amplifier of infection.
The disease spreads on contact with an infected patient.

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about Kyasanur Forest disease (KFD) is that the disease spreads on contact with an infected patient. No person-to-person transmission is described in KFD. 

Kyasanur forest disease is an arboviral infection caused by Kyasanur forest disease virus (KFDV), a member of the virus family Flaviviridae. It is transmitted by the bite of hard ticks, Haemaphysalis spinigera being the principal vector, which also acts as a reservoir. It was endemic to the forests of Karnataka but now has also been detected in neighboring states of Tamil Nadu and Kerala.

Transmission to humans usually occurs after a tick bite or contact with an infected animal (sick or recently dead monkey). Monkeys act as amplifier hosts. Forest birds and small mammals are the reservoir hosts.

The clinical features include constitutional symptoms like fever, headache, conjunctivitis, myalgia, hemorrhagic symptoms, and severe prostration. The diagnosis is established via PCR, virus isolation from blood, or enzyme-linked immunosorbent serologic assay.

A killed KFD virus vaccine was used in a small field trial and appeared to provide some degree of protection.
