questions.text: The physician explains the complications of diabetes and the need for compliance in simple terms to his illiterate patient. This is an example of which level of communication?
questions.solution:
This is an example of communication on an intellectual plane.

Communication on an intellectual plane involves giving empathetic, easy-to-understand explanations of their conditions and helping the patients develop insight into their ailments and their treatment plans. The doctor should take into account the fact that the patient's intellectual understanding may not be at the same level and, hence, put it in simple easy-to-understand terms.

For a successful doctor-patient relationship, a doctor must have in his/her regard communication on the following levels:

  • Communication on an emotional plane: Listening with empathy, building rapport, and ensuring openness and trust from the patient is part of this.
    • Example- Dr. X lending a sympathetic ear to the complaints made by the 84-year-old geriatric patient on his lingering backache is the emotional plane.
  • Communication on a cultural plane: To understand the community to which the patient belongs and his/her cultural and lifestyle factors that may influence health and disease and to advise in terms that the patient would understand. 
    • Example- Dr. A, the hypertension clinic physician, making his dietary advice in terms that fit the already existing lifestyle pattern in that area is an example of understanding the cultural plane.

There is no such plane as the scientific plane in communication.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with new-onset hematuria. He states that he has had abdominal pain for 1 week. There is no burning micturition or increased frequency/retention. His blood pressure is 158/105 mmHg, and there is flank tenderness. Ultrasound examination of the flanks is shown in the image below. Which of the following is false regarding the underlying disease?

choices.text: Cysts may also be present in the liver and pancreas.
Mutation of PKD 1 is responsible for 85% of the cases.
Cardiovascular complications are a major cause of mortality.
The most common type of kidney stone in this condition is the calcium oxalate stone.

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Uric acid stones are more common than calcium oxalate stones in ADPKD.

ADPKD is a genetic disorder characterized by multiple bilateral kidney cysts associated with cysts in other organs such as the liver, pancreas, and arachnoid membranes. It is caused by mutations in the PKD-1 (85% of cases) and PKD-2 genes which code for the transmembrane proteins polycystin-1 and polycystin-2. 

The presentation is variable and it may be asymptomatic until the fifth decade of life, when it is diagnosed incidentally. Abdominal mass, back or flank pain, and hypertension are common presentations among symptomatic patients. Gross hematuria may be present. 

Many patients develop renal stones. In patients with ADPKD, uric acid stones are more common than calcium oxalate stones. Renal cyst infections are very common in patients with ADPKD and are commonly caused by gram-negative bacteria.

Cysts may also be present in the liver and pancreas, and intracranial aneurysms may occur. Mitral valve prolapse and valvular insufficiency may be present. Cardiovascular complications are a major cause of mortality in ADPKD.  

The diagnosis is made based on positive family history and the presence of multiple bilateral renal cysts. Ultrasonography is used for presymptomatic screening of at-risk individuals.

Treatment involves blood pressure control, pain control with analgesics, and hydration. Surgical decompression of cysts is done occasionally. Most patients require dialysis eventually.

questions.text: In a case-control study, lung compliance of two different groups (1 and 3) was compared against that of the control group (2) and recorded as shown in the graph below. Which of the following cases likely represents groups 1 and 3, respectively?
questions.solution:
Graphs 1 and 3 correspond to decreased and increased compliance, respectively. Among the given options, pulmonary fibrosis is associated with decreased compliance, and pulmonary emphysema is associated with increased compliance.

The extent to which the lungs will expand for each unit increase in transpulmonary pressure is called lung compliance. The total compliance of both lungs together in normal, adult averages about 200 mL of air/cm H2O transpulmonary pressure.

  • The curve is shifted downwards in case of decreased compliance. 
  • The curve is shifted upwards and to the left in case of increased compliance.

Here the compliance is 3 > 2> 1.

Compliance is increased in normal ageing lungs and pulmonary emphysema due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched). 

Compliance is decreased in pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary edema, and unventilated lungs due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated. Pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive airway disease in which there is scarring and stiffening of the lungs. Decreased compliance is also seen in sarcoidosis.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text: A male child delivered via cesarean section at term was found to have apnea and hypotonia at birth. What is the immediate next step in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
The immediate next step in the management of a just-delivered newborn with apnea and hypotonia is the clearing of airway secretions.

As soon as a baby is born, the tone, cry, breathing efforts, and respiratory efforts are assessed. If the tone is poor or if the baby is not breathing, the following measures are done immediately.

  • Warming to maintain the normal temperature 
  • Proper positioning of the baby's airway, i.e. sniffing position with the head slightly extended.
  • Clearing of airway secretions
  • Tactile stimulation

If the heart rate is < 100 beats/min or the baby remains apneic after these steps, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) can be initiated with a bag and mask ventilation with a pulse oximeter and ECG leads connected. 

Signs of effective ventilation:

  • Adequate chest rise
  • Symmetric breath sounds
  • Improved pink color
  • Heart rate >100 beats/ min
  • Improving oxygen saturation
  • Spontaneous respiratory efforts
  • Improved tone

If there are no signs of effective ventilation even after 30 seconds of PPV, corrective steps MRSOPA should be performed to improve ventilation. MRSOPA includes mask readjustment, repositioning of the head, suction of mouth and nose, opening the mouth, pressure increase, and establishing an alternative airway.

After 60 seconds of PPV with ventilation correction steps, if the heart rate is < 60 beats/min, endotracheal intubation or laryngeal mask airway should be established. Even after intubation if the heart rate is <60/min, chest compressions should be initiated at the ratio of 3:1 (90 compressions:30 breaths).

After 60 seconds of intubation with chest compressions, if the heart rate is <60 beats/min, epinephrine (1:10,000 solution at 0.1–0.3 mL/kg intravenously or 0.5–1 mL/kg intratracheally) should be administered. The dosage can be repeated every 3–5 minutes. Persistent bradycardia may signify inadequate ventilation or severe cardiac compromise.

The resuscitation can be stopped if the heart rate is not detected even after 10 minutes of continuous adequate resuscitation.

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular treatment presents with a tingling sensation and paresthesia in the lower limbs. Which of the following enzyme assay is used to diagnose the deficient vitamin in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of tingling sensation and paresthesias in a patient on anti-tubercular treatment are suggestive of the adverse effect of isoniazid. The vitamin deficient in this patient is pyridoxine/vitamin B6. Therefore, the RBC transaminase enzyme assay is used to diagnose vitamin B6 deficiency. 

Isoniazid is the first-line antitubercular drug that inhibits the production of mycolic acid. It is a bactericidal drug against tubercle bacilli. Important side effects of isoniazid include peripheral neuritis, hepatitis, anemia, rashes, and arthralgia.

Peripheral neuritis occurs due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Patients present with clinical features of pyridoxine/vitamin B6 deficiency, which include paresthesias, numbness, and tingling sensation.

The most widely used method to know the vitamin B6 nutritional status is by measuring the RBC transaminase activity, by adding pyridoxal phosphate in vitro. Direct measurement of the plasma concentrations of the vitamin (pyridoxal phosphate) can also be done.

Therefore, 10 mg/day of pyridoxine is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with difficulty in hearing. A pure-tone audiogram was obtained, which is shown below. What is the interpretation of this audiogram?
questions.solution:
The given audiogram is suggestive of left-sided mixed hearing loss. 

Interpretation of the audiogram:

  • Blue colour indicates the left ear.
  • > indicates bone conduction (BC), and the threshold is >25 dB. Hence, BC is abnormal, which implies that the abnormality is in the sensorineural pathway.
  • × indicates air conduction (AC), and the threshold is >15 dB. Hence, AC is abnormal.
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal. It indicates sensorineural hearing loss.
  • In addition, the air-bone gap is present, which implies conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, the interpretation is left-mixed hearing loss.

A mixed type of hearing loss presents with defects in both conductive and sensorineural pathways. This type of hearing loss is seen in chronic suppurative otitis media and otosclerosis.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

questions.text: During your internship, you observe a resident doctor examining the thyroid gland using the method shown in the video below. Identify the method.
questions.solution:
The above video shows Crile's method of thyroid palpation.

Crile's Method: The patient is asked to swallow while palpating the gland with the thumb. This method helps to identify mild enlargements and for detecting the presence of nodules.

Other options:

Option B: Lahey's Method: The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the lobe laterally with the left hand and the lobe is palpated with the right hand.

 

Option C: Kocher's method: It is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

Option D: Pizillo's method: In short-necked and obese individuals the thyroid can be better inspected by asking the patient to place his hands behind the occiput of his/her head.

questions.text: A new factory has been given a license to fortify salt with iodine. What is the minimum recommended content of iodine in salt at the production level?
questions.solution:
The minimum recommended content of iodine in salt at the production level is 30 ppm.

Level of iodization

  • At consumer level: 15 ppm
  • At production level: 30 ppm

Goitrogens are chemical substances that interfere with iodine utilization by the thyroid gland, leading to the development of goiter. The brassica group of vegetables like cabbage and cauliflower contain goitrogens.

The daily requirement of iodine is 150 mcg for adults and 250 mcg in pregnancy.

Disorders due to iodine deficiency:

  • Goiter
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Retarded physical and mental development
  • Intrauterine death (spontaneous abortion and stillbirth)
  • Endemic cretinism

The National Iodine Deficiency Disorders Control Program conducts surveys to assess the magnitude of iodine deficiency disorders. The program conducts a resurvey every 5 years to assess the effect of the impact of iodized salt. They also supply iodized salt and conduct laboratory monitoring of iodized salt and urinary iodine excretion.

Global Iodine Deficiency Disorders Prevention Day is observed on 21st October every year.

questions.text: Which of the following nematodes is oviparous?
questions.solution:
Ancylostoma is oviparous, which means the organisms lay eggs to reproduce.

Female nematodes are classified as follows:

  • Oviparous – Laying eggs
    • Unsegmented eggs: Ascaris, Trichuris
    • Segmented eggs: Ancylostoma, Necator
    • Eggs containing larva: Enterobius
  • Viviparous – Producing larvae
    • E.g., Trichinella, Wuchereria, Brugia, Dracunculus
  • Ovoviviparous – laying eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately.
    • E.g., Strongyloides

Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) larvae enter the human host by skin penetration and undergo extraintestinal migration through the venous circulation to the lungs. They enter the alveoli, climb up to the bronchial tree and pharynx, and are swallowed. The larvae reach the small intestine and become adult worms.

Clinical manifestations include vitamin B12 deficiency and iron deficiency anemia, resulting from chronic occult intestinal blood loss. Dermatitis referred to as ground itch may occur when they penetrate human skin. Eosinophilic pneumonia can also be seen. The average blood loss of the host per worm per day is 0.2 mL with A. duodenale.

Oval, segmented hookworm eggs can be demonstrated in the feces by direct wet microscopy or concentration method. Stool culture by the Harada-Mori method demonstrates third-stage filariform larvae.

Infection with a zoonotic hookworm, especially Ancylostoma braziliense, can result in the subcutaneous migration of the larvae, causing cutaneous larva migrans.

The image given below shows cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child has delayed developmental milestones and intellectual disability, with the following appearance (image A). On further examination, there is an enlarged tongue, cloudy cornea, and hepatomegaly. A radiograph of the hand is shown in image B. A girl born in their family also had similar symptoms and she died at 9 years of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Hurler syndrome. The child is 2 years of age and has coarse facial features like a depressed nasal bridge, thick lips, and an open mouth with protruded tongue. The radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpals and phalanges. These features along with severe developmental delay, cloudy cornea, hepatomegaly, and intellectual disability suggest that the child has Hurler syndrome.

It is a severe type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) I. It is caused due to deficiency of α-L-iduronidase. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides. 

Patients usually present between 6-24 months of age. They have

  • Intellectual disability
  • Skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex- thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged diaphyses of the long bones, macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella
  • Cloudy cornea, glaucoma, retinal degeneration
  • Mixed hearing loss, etc

Other options

Option A- The Scheie syndrome is a milder form of MPS-I (MPS I-S ). The symptoms appear after 5 years of age and the diagnosis is made between 10-20 years. It is characterized by normal intelligence and stature, joint stiffness, aortic valve disease, corneal clouding, and mild dysostosis multiplex. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Option B- Hurler-Scheie syndrome is an intermediate between Hurler syndrome and Scheie syndrome. The onset of symptoms is between 3-8 years of age. They have mild or no intellectual dysfunction. Ophthalmic and cardiac involvement might be present.

Option D- Hunter syndrome is a type II MPS. It occurs due to the deficiency of iduronate 2-sulfatase. It shares the same features as type I MPS like coarse facial features, short stature, and dysostosis multiplex. However, there is no corneal clouding. It is the only MPS with X-linked recessive inheritance. So if a baby girl is affected in the family, it is less likely to be Hunter syndrome. All the other MPS are autosomal recessive.

questions.text: A patient from North America presented with acute pulmonary edema after an episode of fever, myalgia, and headache. He was found to be infected with the Sin Nombre virus. What type of virus is this?
questions.solution:
Sin Nombre virus is a type of Hantavirus. The given clinical feature is suggestive of Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome. 

Hantaviruses are classified under Bunyaviridae. They are rodent-borne viruses that are transmitted by inhalation of the virus contained in dried excreta of rodents. They are the natural pathogens of rodents like mice, rats, and voles. No human-to-human transmission is reported.

Clinical features: 

  • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) -  Presents with acute kidney injury, hemorrhages, fever, and circulatory collapse
  • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS) - Characterized by the acute onset of severe pulmonary edema after 3–4 days of a prodromal illness of fever, malaise, myalgia, and gastrointestinal symptoms

Laboratory diagnosis depends on viral nucleic acid detection by RT-PCR.

Hantaviruses are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of availability, ease of production, dissemination, the potential for high morbidity and mortality rates, and major health impact. It is a category C bioterrorism agent.

questions.text: A post–myocardial infarction patient presented to the emergency room with sudden-onset breathlessness and cough with frothy sputum. The patient's chest x-ray, on PA view, revealed the following findings. Identify the lines.
questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of pulmonary edema due to left-sided heart failure, and Kerley B lines are characteristic findings seen in this setting. Kerley B lines are horizontal subpleural lines, 1 cm in length and 1–3 mm in thickness, usually seen in the middle or lower zone of the lungs. 

Radiological signs of left-sided heart failure:

  • Cardiomegaly - Enlargement of the cardiac silhouette
  • Kerley B lines - Horizontal lines in the periphery of the lower posterior lung fields
  • Upper lobe pulmonary venous congestion 
  • Interstitial edema

 Types of Kerley lines:  

  • Kerley A lines:
    • They are deep septal lines and are longer than Kerley B lines.
    • They radiate from the periphery to the central portion of the lungs.
    • HRCT is the best modality for the demonstration of Kerley A lines.
    • They indicate severe pulmonary edema.
  • Kerley B lines:
    • These are thin lines 1–2 cm in length in the periphery of the lung.
    • They are perpendicular to the pleural surface and extend out to it.
    • They represent thickened subpleural interlobular septa.
    • They are usually seen at the lung bases.
  • Kerley C lines :
    • They occur due to the thickening of the lung parenchymal interstitium.
    • They have a reticular pattern on chest radiography.
  • Kerley D lines 
    •  They are exactly the same as Kerley B lines, except that they are seen on lateral chest radiographs, in the retrosternal air gap.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Early loss of procedural memory is not a feature of Alzheimer's disease.

Alzheimer's disease is a syndrome of acquired global or multifocal impairment of cognitive function involving a decline of intellect, memory, or personality in the presence of normal consciousness.

Risk factors:

  • Old age
  • ApoE ε4 allele
  • Less education
  • Diabetes
  • Positive family history
  • Head trauma 
  • Female sex
  • Viruses, prion

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: A 30-year-old pilot with low back pain requires a painkiller that is effective at once-daily dosing. You decide to prescribe the NSAID with the longest plasma half-life. Which drug will you choose?
questions.solution:
Piroxicam is chosen as it has the longest plasma half-life among NSAIDs.

Piroxicam is absorbed completely and undergoes enterohepatic circulation. Due to the long half-life, once-daily administration of the drug is sufficient for the therapeutic response.

questions.text: A patient in the postoperative ward was given opioids to relieve pain. But within a few hours, his respiratory rate decreased and oxygen saturation dropped. Opioid-induced respiratory depression was suspected and he was managed with naloxone. What is the intrinsic activity of naloxone?
questions.solution:
Naloxone is a competitive antagonist of opioids and hence it is used in the reversal of opioid-induced respiratory depression. All the competitive antagonists have no intrinsic activity i.e Intrinsic activity=0

The capacity of a drug to induce a functional change in the receptor is called intrinsic activity.

Type of drugs

Intrinsic activity

Agonists

1

Partial agonists

0 to 1

Competitive antagonists

0

Inverse agonists

0 to -1

The image given below shows the action of various types of selective receptor modulators.

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor.

Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist.

Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor.

Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.

Graph 3 represents the antagonist: An agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor, but does not have any effect of its own.

Example: Naltrexone and naloxone are antagonists at opioid receptors.

Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist.

Example: β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor.

questions.text: A surgeon performing a superficial parotidectomy asks you to identify the cranial nerve passing through the gland. Which of the following pointers is not used for the identification of the nerve trunk?
questions.solution:
In the given image, pointer 3 is the external acoustic meatus, which is not used to identify the facial nerve trunk during parotidectomy. 

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. It is then traced distally. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Tragal pointer/ Conley's pointer - It is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric - The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle. This point also helps to mobilize the parotid gland.
  • Squamotympanic fissure - It is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from temperomandibular junction (TMJ) to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process - The facial nerve lies superficial to it.
  • Mastoid process - Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main trunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch - It lies in relation to the parotid gland.
  • Marginal mandibular branch - It lies in relation to the facial vessels.
  • Temporal branch

questions.text: Which of the values indicated on the given image most likely correspond to the mean, median, and mode, respectively?
questions.solution:
The labelings in the given positively skewed graph indicate mean (3), median (2), and mode (1).

  • Mode - value with the greatest frequency
  • Median - Value that divides the frequency distribution into half when the data is arranged in ascending or descending order
  • Mean - Value that denotes the average of the distribution

The X-axis denotes the values and these correspond as follows:

  1. Negatively (left) skewed: Mean < Median < Mode
  2. Normal distribution: Mean = Median = Mode
  3. Positively (right) skewed: Mode < Median < Mean

Note:

Median is always in between mode and mean in a skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: Postmortem examination of a body reveals copious froth from the mouth, nose, and air passages. There is hemorrhage into the middle ears, subpleural hemorrhages at the base of the lungs, and emphysema aquosum, prompting suspicion of drowning. Which of the following findings would strongly suggest that the person was alive when he drowned?
questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm strongly indicates that the person was alive when he drowned because it indicates the struggle of the person for his life. 

Weeds, gravel, grass, sticks, twigs, and leaves present in the water may be firmly grasped in the hands due to cadaveric spasms. 

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - The most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - Frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed and from the cut surfaces when they are sectioned with a knife. But the absence of waterlogging by no means excludes true drowning (e.g. dry drowning).
  • Emphysema aqueosum - Overinflation of the lungs
  • Paltauf’s spots - Subpleural hemorrhages that probably reflect hemolysis within intra-alveolar hemorrhages
  • Dilation of the right heart and great veins - This is a very subjective and non-specific finding.
  • Foreign material in the stomach - The stomach may contain watery fluid or even foreign material from the water, such as silt, weed, and sand. This is also not a finding that can diagnose drowning.
  • Hemorrhage into the middle ears and into the temporal bone - This has been postulated as a positive sign of drowning, it is a non-specific finding.
  • Presence of fluid in the middle ear or paranasal sinuses 

Note - The autopsy findings in drowning are mostly nonspecific and none give conclusive evidence of drowning. 

Other options:

Option B: Cutis anserina (goose-skin or goose-flesh), in which the skin has a granular and puckered appearance can be seen on the anterior surfaces of the body, especially on the thighs.  It is produced by the spasm of the erector pilae muscles, attached to each hair follicle, and can occur in the living when the skin comes in contact with cold water. It can occur on submersion of the body in cold water immediately after death, while the muscles were still warm and irritable. It can also be produced by rigor mortis of the erector muscles.

Option C: The presence of sand, fluid, debris, weeds, vegetation, and other foreign material in the nostrils or upper airways is not a sign of antemortem drowning.

Option D: Washerwoman’s hands is a specific change that is seen in the skin of the palm and sole, which comprises of wrinkled, swollen, whitish sodden appearance of hands or feet. It can also be considered as water maceration of the skin of the hand, due to the absorption of water into the outer layers of the skin. Although the changes in washerwomen’s hands and feet are usually seen in dead bodies recovered from the water, this cannot be considered a sign of antemortem drowning.

Related Pearl: Difference between freshwater and seawater drowning.

questions.text: In an amenorrheic patient who underwent pituitary ablation for a craniopharyngioma, which of the following is most likely to result in an ovulatory cycle?

choices.text: Human menopausal or recombinant gonadotropin, followed by human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

questions.solution:
A patient with pituitary ablation would require the administration of human menopausal or recombinant gonadotropin, followed by human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) to result in an ovulatory cycle.

Because the pituitary gland is ablated, the patient cannot produce endogenous gonadotropin. Therefore, she would require exogenous gonadotropin in the form of human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG), which contains an extract of urine from postmenopausal women with follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) in various ratios.

Recombinant human FSH (rhFSH) is also available.

Carefully timed administration of hCG, which takes the place of an endogenous LH surge, will be needed to complete oocyte maturation and induce ovulation.

Endogenous or exogenous GnRH cannot stimulate the release of FSH or LH in this woman because the pituitary gland is nonfunctional. 

Other options:

Option A: Clomiphene citrate acts by competing with endogenous circulating estrogens for estrogen-binding sites in the hypothalamus. Therefore, it blocks the normal negative feedback of endogenous estrogens and stimulates the release of endogenous GnRH. However, the pituitary will not respond in this patient.

Options B and C: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) acts on the pituitary to stimulate the release of FSH and LH. Since this patient has undergone pituitary ablation, GnRH cannot act on the pituitary and the patient will not respond to this treatment.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented with complaints of abdominal distension, yellowish discoloration of eyes, and dark-colored urine for the past 6 months.  After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe and is scheduled for left hemi-hepatectomy. Which of the following segments has to be removed in the patient?

choices.text: II, III, IV, V, and VI

questions.solution:
In left hemi-hepatectomy (also called left hepatectomy), the segments marked as II, III, and IV should be removed. 

Cantlie’s line or main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein. The liver has 3 major fissures and 3 minor fissures.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage. Segment I corresponds to the liver's caudate lobe, and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. 

The Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Segments removed in various liver surgeries:

  • Right hepatectomy or right hemi-hepatectomy - V, VI, VII, VIII
  • Right tri-sectionectomy or extended right hepatectomy - IV, V, VI, VII, VIII
  • Left hepatectomy or left hemi-hepatectomy - II, III, and IV
  • Left tri-sectionectomy or extended left hepatectomy - II, III, IV, V, and VIII
  • Left lateral sectionectomy or bi-segmentectomy - II and III
  • Right posterior sectionectomy - VI, VII
  • Caudate lobectomy or segmentectomy - I

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: The measures that are taken to prevent a disaster from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are a part of _______.
questions.solution:
The measures that are taken to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are part of disaster mitigation.

Disaster mitigation also includes measures taken to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures are:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system. It complements the disaster preparedness and response activities.

Other options:

Option A - Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage, etc.

Option B - Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.

Option C - Disaster preparedness is a long-term plan with ongoing multisectoral activities, which include the development of policies or programs for disaster management prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. The measures taken will ensure that the country is well prepared to face any future disasters, and effectively prevent or manage to reduce the impact.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis. His fasting triglyceride levels were 1100 mg/dL. He mentions that his mother was diagnosed with a deficiency of lipoprotein lipase and on further investigation, he too was diagnosed with the same condition. Which of the following lipoproteins will be elevated in this patient's plasma?

VLDL- very low density lipoprotein

LDL- low density lipoprotein

HDL- high density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the presence of lipoprotein lipase deficiency indicate a diagnosis of type I hyperlipoproteinemia, where chylomicron, triglycerides and VLDL levels will be elevated.

Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as familial chylomicronemia syndrome or familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency is due to lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency, abnormal LPL, or apo C-II deficiency causing inactivation of LPL. It is an autosomal recessive condition. 

These patients show slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL, low levels of LDL and HDL. 

Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, eruptive/ pruritic xanthomas on the back, buttocks, and extensor surfaces, and recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. On funduscopic examination, the retinal blood vessels may appear opalescent, known as lipemia retinalis. The diagnosis should be suspected if the fasting triglyceride levels are greater than 750 mg/dL.

Lipoprotein lipase is required for the hydrolysis of triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol in circulating chylomicrons, that transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. Therefore, patients who are deficient in lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II (type I hyperlipoproteinemia) show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma after a fatty meal.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A 68-year-old male came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain and easy fatigability. He has also been treated twice for urinary tract infections in the last 3 months. An x-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with this diagnosis?

choices.text: Hypercalcemia, high alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, high alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the skull radiograph showing punched-out lesions suggest multiple myeloma. Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, and elevated ESR are the laboratory parameters consistent with a diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Bone pain is the most common symptom of multiple myeloma. Tumor cells release osteoclast activating factors (OAFs), which increased osteoclast activity and accelerated bone destruction. Furthermore, there is suppression of osteoblast activity to form new bone. Lysis of the bone leads to hypercalcemia. Patients with multiple myeloma also have an increased susceptibility to infections because of diffuse hypogammaglobulinemia (decreased production and increased destruction) of normal antibodies. 

Other important features of multiple myeloma include: 

  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic and normochromic anemia
  • Hyperviscosity syndromes
  • Elevated ESR
  • Normal alkaline phosphatase due to suppression of osteoblast activity.
  • Serum protein electrophoresis shows the presence of monoclonal protein
  • Urinalysis shows free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence-Jones proteins)

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma include: 

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically: (CRAB features)
    • Hypercalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >2 g/dL below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET).
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥ 60%
    • Serum involved / uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater.
    • >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation

questions.text:
An HIV-positive patient on HAART presents with insomnia, vivid dreams, and dysphoria. After a detailed evaluation, you suspect that the presenting symptoms are due to the adverse effects of an antiretroviral drug. This drug acts at which of the following sites?

HAART- Highly active anti retroviral therapy
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of adverse effects of efavirenz. It acts at site 4, i.e it inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase.

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). It is effective against HIV-1 only.

The adverse effects of efavirenz are mainly neuropsychiatric. These include dizziness, impaired concentration, dysphoria, disturbing or vivid dreams, and insomnia. However, these symptoms resolve within the first 4 weeks of therapy and are tolerable.

Other side effects include skin rash, headache, increased hepatic transaminases, and elevated serum cholesterol.

The illustration given below shows the mechanism of action of various antiretroviral drugs.


Antiretroviral drugs are classified by the phase of the retrovirus life cycle that the drug inhibits.

Antiretroviral drug Mechanism of action
Nucleotide/ nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors Inhibits reverse transcriptase
Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors Inhibits reverse transcriptase by binding to an allosteric site of the enzyme
Protease inhibitors Inhibits the viral protease enzyme necessary to produce mature virions upon budding from the host membrane.
Entry inhibitors

Interferes with binding, fusion, and entry of HIV -1 into the cell by blocking a target.

Maraviroc works by targetting CCR5, a coreceptor located on human helper T-cells
Integrase inhibitors Inhibits the viral enzyme integrase, which is responsible for the integration of viral DNA into the DNA of the infected cell.

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir

  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of inability to hold objects firmly. Later, she noticed painless nodules on her palms and her fingers becoming stiffer over time. On examination, the following findings were found. Which of the following is not a common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features and image suggest the diagnosis of Dupuytren's contracture. Aging process is not the cause of this condition. 

The main causes of this condition include:
  • trauma of chronic repetitive nature
  • heredity (Autosomal dominant)
  • epileptics receiving phenytoin therapy
  • associations with diabetes, epilepsy, smoking, alcoholic cirrhosis, AIDS, and pulmonary tuberculosis
  • occupational causes such as vibrations of machines
Dupuytren's contracture is a proliferating fibroplasia of the subcutaneous palmar tissue, forming nodules of cords along its ulnar border. It results in finger contractures, thinning of subcutaneous fat, pitting of skin and knuckle pads. It is more common in males than females. The prevalence increases with age, but onset at an early stage usually means aggressive disease.
 
Clinical features:

The patient complains of a nodular thickening in the palm or finger. The palm of the ring finger and the PIP of the little finger are the most commonly involved. Initially, the lesion is painless, later it may result in slight tenderness. Often both hands are involved. Gradually the nodules may thicken and contract, forming cords. If the subcutaneous cords extend into the fingers, they may produce flexion deformities at the MCP and PIP joints. Sometimes the dorsal knuckle pads are thickened, known as Garrod’s pads.

Treatment of Dupuytren Disease - 

Nonoperative:

  • External beam radiation
  • Steroid injection
  • Collagenase

Operative:

  • Subcutaneous fasciotomy
  • Partial (selective) fasciectomy
  • Complete fasciectomy
  • Fasciectomy with skin grafting
  • Staged external fixation
  • Arthrodesis
  • Amputation

questions.text: A farmer was diagnosed with a hydatid cyst. The following procedure was planned. Which of the following is an indication to perform this procedure?
questions.solution:
The image shows the steps involved in the procedure called PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, and Re-aspiration). Refusal of surgery by the patient is an indication for PAIR. All the other options are contraindications to PAIR.

PAIR is a minimally invasive technique that complements or replaces surgical treatment. It is done after adequate drug treatment with albendazole or praziquantel. It involves puncture, aspiration of the cystic fluid, injection of 95% ethanol solution or hypertonic saline, and re-aspiration of the solution after 5 minutes. Puncture is done under ultrasound guidance.

Hydatid disease is caused by Echinococcus granulosus or the dog tapeworm. Patients may be asymptomatic or may present with a gradually enlarging painful mass in the right upper quadrant. Diagnosis is clinical, supplemented with imaging. Ultrasound and CT scans are the investigations of choice.

WHO proposed an ultrasound classification of hydatid cysts based on the activity of the cyst. They are classified as active, transition, and inactive groups:

  • Group 1: Active group – cysts >2 cm in size and often fertile
  • Group 2: Transition group – cysts starting to degenerate and enter a transitional stage but may contain viable protoscolices
  • Group 3: Inactive group – degenerated, partially or totally calcified cysts

Asymptomatic and inactive cysts are managed conservatively and monitored by ultrasound. Active cysts should first be treated by a full course of albendazole. Procedures used for treatment include PAIR, pericystectomy, and laparoscopic marsupialization of the cyst. Laparoscopic marsupialization of the cyst is the most common procedure and involves removing the cyst containing the endocyst and daughter cysts.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: On performing a histamine test on an individual with brachial plexus trunk injury, you can expect ________.

choices.text: Central capillary dilatation → wheal → Surrounding flare
Central capillary dilatation → wheal without surrounding flare
Central capillary dilatation → wheal with exaggerated surrounding flare

questions.solution:
Brachial plexus trunk injury leads to anesthetized skin over the region. On performing a histamine test on such an individual, one can expect central capillary dilatation → wheal without surrounding flare. The incomplete triple response over the anesthetic skin is characteristic of postganglionic lesions.

Intradermal injection of histamine usually causes a triple response in the surrounding skin i.e, red reaction→ flare → wheal

  • Red reaction is independent of innervation and is due to histamine-mediated relaxation of the precapillary sphincters
  • Flare reaction (Flush, Axon reflex) is due to Substance P mediated arteriolar dilatation (antidromic conduction of afferent impulses via collaterals of the sensory nerve fiber that lead to the release of vasoactive mediators)
  • Wheal (skin edema) is due to histamine-mediated increased capillary permeability
  • The triple response persists after total sympathectomy
  • Flare is absent in locally anesthetized skin

 

Related Pearl: Pre and post-ganglionic lesions

Features Preganglionic Postganglionic
Site Proximal to dorsal root ganglion Distal to dorsal root ganglion
Injury Avulsion of nerve root from spinal cord Disruption of distal nerve root, trunk or the peripheral nerve
Prognosis Poor Good
Histamine test Positive Negative (Incomplete)
Surgical repairability Irreparable Repairable

 

Histamine Test:

Normally, a triple response is produced on the intradermal injection of histamine.

Central capillary dilatation → surrounding flare → wheal.

Conclusions:

  • Normal sensate skin with normal triple response → No Nerve Injury
  • Normal triple response over anesthetic skin → Preganglionic Lesion
  • Incomplete triple response over anesthetic skin → Postganglionic Lesion

 

In postganglionic lesions, incomplete triple response has no flare because of the disrupted pathway to the ganglion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is on an antiglaucoma drug for the past 6 months. He now visits the OPD for a review checkup, and the following finding is observed. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause this side effect?
questions.solution:
The image shows iris pigmentation and it is seen with topical PGF2α (prostaglandin) analogs like latanoprost.

Topical PGF2 alpha (prostaglandin) analogs are used as a first-line drug in glaucoma. Latanoprost is the most commonly used anti-glaucoma medication. Other prostaglandin analogs are travoprost, bimatoprost, tafluprost and unoprostone.

It decreases intra-ocular pressure by enhancing the outflow of aqueous and by altering the ciliary muscle tension.

Other adverse effects are eyelash lengthening, allergic conjunctival hyperemia, and orbital fat atrophy.

questions.text: You are involved in a study about various types of zoonotic diseases. Which of the following is an example of a metazoonosis?
questions.solution:
Plague is an example of metazoonosis.

Metazoonoses are transmitted by invertebrate vectors. In the invertebrate vectors, the infective agent develops or multiplies, and after an extrinsic period of incubation (prepatent period) transmission to another vertebrate host occurs. Examples include arboviral infections, plague, and schistosomiasis

Zoonoses are diseases and infections which are naturally transmitted from other vertebrates to man. They can be transmitted from either animals or other humans.

Zoonoses are classified based on their reservoir hosts:

  • Anthropo-zoonoses are infections transmitted to man from lower vertebrate animals, e.g. rabies.
  • Zoo-anthroponoses are infections transmitted to lower vertebrate animals from a man, e.g. tuberculosis of cat and monkey
  • Amphixenoses are infections maintained in both men and lower vertebrate animals that may be transmitted in either direction, e.g. staphylococcal infections

Related Pearl: Classification of Zoonoses

Classification based on their reservoir hosts into:

  • Anthropozoonoses
  • Zoo-anthroponoses
  • Amphixenoses

Classification based on life cycle if infecting agent is:

Mode

Example

Direct contact/fomite/mechanical vector

No essential developmental/ propagative changes during transmission.

Rabies , Trichinosis, Brucellosis

More than one vertebrate host is needed to complete the developmental cycle. Invertebrate hosts will not suffice.

 Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Meta-zoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors. Inside the invertebrate, the infective agent develops / multiplies. After an extrinsic period of incubation, the infective agent is transmitted to another vertebrate host.

Arboviral infections, Plague and Schistosomiasis

Sapro-zoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil/ plants)developmental site/reservoir.

questions.text: A newborn baby was brought to the dermatology department. His mother says blisters are formed at the site of handling as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above condition is epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

A newborn with trauma-related bullae and vesicles at the site of handling over knees and feet points towards the diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

Epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS) is a type of blistering disease. It occurs due to the mutation in the keratin gene (KRT5 or KRT14) encoding for keratin 5 or 14 expressed in the basal cell layer. This mutation causes the production of defective intermediate filaments. This makes epidermal basal cells fragile and subsequently causes blisters on physical pressure. The separation in EBS is within the epidermis (basal cell layer). 

The child is affected at birth and caregivers present the baby with blisters on the hands, elbows, feet, and ankle. More blisters will appear as the baby starts crawling. 

Epidermolysis bullosa is a group of mechano-bullous diseases in which blisters develop in areas of mechanical trauma. There are three types of epidermolysis bullosa:

  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex -  defect in K5/K14.
  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa -  defect in laminin.
  • Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa -  defect in collagen-7.

Other options:

Option B- Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by large, tense subepidermal bullae in the groin, axilla, and flexors of the forearm. Most frequently they occur in the elderly population.

Option C- Pemphigus foliaceus is characterized by flaccid bullae. They rupture as soon as they appear and crusting occurs. Most frequently they occur in adults of age 40 to 50 years. It shows positive Nikolsky sign.

Option D- Cicatricial pemphigoid is also known as mucous membrane pemphigoid. It is characterized by vesicles that rupture quickly and form ulcers. These are usually seen in mucous membranes like conjunctiva and oral mucosa. Most frequently they occur in older women.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the Suraksha clinic with lesions on his genitals, as shown in the image below. Which of the following STI treatment kits would you recommend for this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows a cluster of vesicles over the penis which points toward the diagnosis of genital herpes infection. It is treated with kit 5 or the red kit, which contains acyclovir 400 mg to be taken orally TID for 7 days. No partner treatment is required.

Genital herpes is more commonly caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) 2. The patients present with painful vesicular-ulcerative lesions. In men, it occurs mainly on the penis or urethra. In women, the cervix, vagina, vulva, and perineum can be involved. The primary infection causes serious symptoms accompanied by fever and malaise, followed by recurrent episodes. A cesarean section is performed in a case of active genital herpes at the time of labor in order to prevent neonatal herpes infection.

Herpes infection can be caused by HSV-1 and HSV-2 viruses. HSV-1 causes orofacial lesions, i.e. herpes labialis, while HSV-2 mainly causes genital herpes. The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers. They heal without scarring. The most common site of cutaneous lesions is in the face, the cheeks, the chin, around the mouth, or on the forehead.

The Tzanck smear technique is a rapid and inexpensive diagnostic method. Scrapings (preferably from the base of vesicles) are obtained from the lesions and stained with a  1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground-glass chromatin, known as Tzanck cells, are seen. Cowdry type A inclusions are seen in the vesicles in Giemsa-stained smears.

The following image shows histology of HSV inclusion bodies.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient with a body mass index of 32 presents to you with the skin lesions shown in the image below. He is a known patient of diabetes and hypertension, taking medication irregularly. Which of the following additional findings would be used to diagnose metabolic syndrome in this patient?
questions.solution:
The dark velvety patches in the axilla of an obese male with diabetes are likely to be due to acanthosis nigricans. Along with this, an additional finding that would be used to diagnose metabolic syndrome in this patient is HDL cholesterol level <40 mg/dL.

Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by the symmetrical darkening of the skin of intertriginous areas, mainly the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck.

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, as defined by National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III (NCEP-ATP III):

  • Central obesity: Waist circumference of >102 cm in males and >88 cm in females
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: Triglyceride level of ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively
  • Hypertension: Systolic BP of ≥130 mmHg or diastolic BP of ≥ 85 mmHg
  • Fasting plasma glucose level: ≥100 mg/dL or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes

Insulin resistance is the most widely accepted pathophysiology behind this syndrome and is associated with the development of acanthosis nigricans or lipoatrophy in these patients. An elevated level of circulating fatty acids is considered a major factor in the development of insulin resistance.

Other associated conditions include non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, hyperuricemia, polycystic ovary disease, and obstructive sleep apnea. The condition is managed by dietary and lifestyle modifications. Individual components of the syndrome also need to be addressed by the use of statins, antihypertensives, or hypoglycemic agents.

questions.text:
A study was performed and the clearance of different substances was recorded on a graph as shown below. Identify the substance represented in curve 1.

PAH - Para-aminohippurate
questions.solution:
The substance represented in curve 1 is PAH (para-aminohippurate).

PAH is freely filtered and partly secreted. Its concentration keeps increasing throughout the length of the nephron due to secretion into tubules. When plasma PAH is low, clearance is high. However, as plasma PAH rises above the threshold level for PAH secretion, clearance falls progressively.  

The given curves basically measure the amount (not concentration) of a particular substance in renal tubules after it undergoes ultrafiltration. It depicts renal handling of glucose, inulin, and PAH.

Other options:

Option A: Inulin is freely filtered (100%) and is represented by curve 2. It further does not undergo any reabsorption or secretion. It is hence a straight line i.e., its concentration does not change throughout the length of the nephron. Hence, it is constant and equal to the glomerular filtration rate.

Options C and D: Substances like amino acids or glucose are represented by curve 3. In normal conditions, they are almost completely reabsorbed. Hence they have a graph that is sloping down. And since they are completely reabsorbed within PCT itself, their concentration is not detected after proximal convoluted tubules. Hence, the clearance is zero. 

In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorption, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero.

questions.text: A worker at a textile mill complains of exhaustion and fatigue and says he works around 72 hours per week. According to the Factories act of 1948, what are the maximum hours of work per day for an industrial worker?
questions.solution:
According to The Factories act, 1948, the maximum hours of work per day for an industrial worker is 9 hours. It should not be more than 48 hours per week, if working overtime, it should not exceed 60 hours per week. 

Adolescents between 15 and 18 years of age can only be employed in certain industries, and their work hours should not exceed four and a half hours per day.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with complaints of long-standing swelling of the left leg, as shown in the image. The swelling disappears in the morning and on examination, pitting is seen. What grade of lymphedema is this?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, pitting edema which disappears completely on elevation and bed rest indicates grade I lymphedema, according to Brunner's classification.

Skin changes seen in lymphedema include peau d'orange, erythema, hyperkeratosis, ulceration, stemmer sign, and buffalo hump.

Stemmer sign is the inability to pinch a fold of skin on the dorsum of the toes due to lymphedema. 

Clinical classification of lymphedema:

Grade (Brunner)

Clinical features

Subclinical

There is excessive interstitial fluid and histological abnormalities in lymphatics and lymph nodes, but no clinically apparent lymphedema.

Grade I

Edema pits on pressure and the swelling completely disappears on elevation and bed rest.

Grade II

Edema does not pit and does not significantly reduce on elevation

Grade III

Edema is associated with irreversible skin changes, i.e. fibrosis and papillae.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presented with progressive difficulty in hearing for the past 3 years. An MRI of the brain shows bilateral cerebellopontine angle tumors that are consistent with schwannomas. There is also a family history of gliomas and meningiomas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is neurofibromatosis type 2.

Neurofibromatosis type 2 refers to a syndrome characterized by bilateral schwannomas of the eighth cranial nerve, meningiomas, and gliomas. This is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to a mutation in the NF2 gene.

The image below shows bilateral schwannomas seen in a patient with neurofibromatosis type 2.

Other options 

Option A: Neurofibromatosis type 1 presents with gliomas of the optic nerve, hamartomas, and pheochromocytomas. These patients have other features like intellectual disability, Lisch nodules (pigmented nodules of the iris), and cafe au lait spots (hyperpigmented macules on the skin).

Option C: Sturge-Weber syndrome presents with port-wine stain lesions of the skin in the area supplied by the trigeminal nerve. They might also have venous angiomas and intellectual disabilities.

Option D: Tuberous sclerosis presents with hamartomas and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas. Hamartomas appear as cortical tubers and subependymal nodules. This is associated with various cutaneous manifestations like angiofibromas, shagreen patches (localized leathery thickenings), ash-leaf patches (hypopigmented areas), and subungual fibromas.

questions.text: A child is brought with the following deformity. This occurs due to the failure of fusion between the _____.

choices.text: Lateral nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Lateral nasal prominence and mandibular prominence
Medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Medial nasal prominence and mandibular prominence

questions.solution:
The image shows cleft lip (hare lip), which occurs due to the failure of fusion between the medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence.

Various defects of fusion of prominences in the face region are as follows:

Cleft lip is due to the failure of the fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence.

Types:

  • Unilateral cleft lip - Failure of fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence on one side
  • Bilateral cleft lip - Failure of fusion of maxillary prominence with the medial nasal prominence on both sides
  • Median (midline) cleft lip - Failure of fusion of the two medial nasal prominences in the midline

Oblique facial cleft: Failure of fusion of the maxillary and lateral nasal prominence, giving rise to a gap running from the medial angle of the eye to the mouth. The nasolacrimal duct is not formed.

 

The image below shows the defects of the fusion of prominences in the face region:

  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

questions.text: All of the following people will be given a weekly dose of 60 mg elemental iron and 500 micrograms folic acid under the Anemia-Mukt Bharat Scheme, except ________.

choices.text: A 17 year-old out of school girl
A 28 year-old non-lactating mother of a 3-year-old child
A 25 year-old lactating mother of a 5-month-old child

questions.solution:
Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme, lactating mothers of 0-6 month-old children are given a daily dose of 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid, not a weekly dose.

Weekly iron and folic acid are given to women of reproductive age (non-pregnant, non-lactating), school-going adolescent girls and boys 10-19 years of age, and out-of-school adolescent girls 10-19 years of age.

For pregnant women and lactating mothers of 0-6 months child, the dose is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 micrograms of folic acid, given daily.

Prophylactic iron should be withheld in cases of acute illness such as diarrhea and pneumonia. It is also not recommended in known cases of thalassemia major or a history of repeated blood transfusions.

Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme follows a 6x6x6 strategy. Here, 6 groups of beneficiaries are assisted by 6 interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.

The six distinct groups of beneficiaries are children of 6-59 months of age, children of 5-9 years, adolescents, women in the reproductive age group, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. 

The six interventions are:

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation prophylactically
  • Deworming
  • Behavior change communication campaign
  • Using digital methods and point-of-care treatment
  • Provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought with complaints of eye pain. On examination, you see multiple corneal erosions. Excessive epidermal thickening of the palms and soles was also observed. Detailed laboratory evaluation revealed a deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase is suggestive of type II tyrosinemia.

Tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome) is caused by a defective TAT gene. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Clinically, children present with painful herpetiform dendritic corneal ulcers, photophobia, palmoplantar keratosis, and intellectual disability.

The image given below shows herpetiform dendritic corneal ulcers seen in type II tyrosinemia.

 

The laboratory finding includes marked hypertyrosinemia and elevated tyrosine and tyramine in urine. The treatment for this condition is a diet low in protein.

The image given below shows the metabolism of tyrosine.

 

Other options:

Option A: Type I tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Children present with mild mental retardation, liver failure, and hypoglycemia. Urine typically has a boiled cabbage odor.

Option C: Alkaptonuria occurs due to a deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. It is an autosomal recessive condition. Patients present with arthritis (usually occurs in the third decade) and bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue (ochronosis). Urine in these patients turns dark in color on standing for long.

Option D: Albinism occurs due to a deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase. Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-month-old baby for a routine evaluation. On examination, a loud, harsh pan systolic murmur was heard on auscultation over the lower left sternal border. There was no cyanosis or finger clubbing. Echocardiography revealed a defect of 8 mm in the membranous part of the interventricular septum. The presence of which of the following would not be a valid indication for surgery?

choices.text: Large defect not controlled by medication
Large defect with failure to thrive

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a loud, harsh pansystolic murmur, with the given echocardiography findings, is suggestive of a ventricular septal defect (VSD). The presence of Eisenmenger syndrome is a contraindication for surgery. 

Ventricular septal defects are the most common congenital heart lesions. 90% are located in the membranous part of the septum with variable extension into the muscular part. 

Children may present at 6–10 weeks of age with congestive cardiac failure, or with palpitations, exertional dyspnoea, and frequent chest infections when they are older. On examination, a loud pan systolic murmur is heard at the left sternal border with a systolic thrill. S2 may be widely split with P2 accentuation. S3 may be audible at the apex.

Muscular VSDs are likely to close spontaneously. Medical management consists of control of cardiac failure, treatment of infections, treatment of anemia, and infective endocarditis. 

Surgery in VSD mainly helps to relieve congestive cardiac failure which manifests as a failure to thrive in an infant. The main aim of performing surgery in VSD is to get the symptoms of heart failure in control and to prevent the development of pulmonary vascular disease.

Indications for surgical closure of a VSD:

  • Large defects with clinical symptoms that cannot be controlled medically
  • Large defects with pulmonary hypertension, controlled by medication
  • Patients older than 2 years with a pulmonary flow of more than twice the systemic flow
  • Patients with a supracristal VSD of any size (because of the high risk for aortic valve regurgitation)
  • Associated pulmonary stenosis.

Surgical treatment is not indicated in

  • Patients with a small VSD (exception subpulmonic/supracristal VSD with aortic valve prolapse)
  • Severe, uncontrolled pulmonary arterial hypertension with a significant right-to-left shunt (Eisenmenger syndrome)
