questions.text: Identify the clinical features expected in the karyotyping given below.

choices.text: Epicanthic fold and endocardial cushion defects
Eunuchoid body habitus with abnormally long legs
Rocker bottom feet and umbilical hernia

questions.solution:
The given karyotyping image shows “45 XO” abnormality, which is seen in Turner's syndrome. Streak ovaries and peripheral edema are clinical features of Turner's syndrome.

Other clinical features of Turner's syndrome include short stature, low posterior hairline, broad chest, widely spaced nipples, coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve, cubitus valgus, and pigmented nevi.

Turner's syndrome is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. The classical karyotype is 45, X. Other variants have structural abnormalities of X chromosomes or mosaic patterns.

Some patients may present during infancy. They mainly present with edema of the dorsum of the hand and foot due to lymphatic stasis. The most important cause of increased mortality in children with Turner's syndrome is cardiac abnormalities. 

Turner's syndrome is a common cause of primary amenorrhea. During embryogenesis, fetal ovaries develop normally and the absence of a second X chromosome leads to accelerated loss of normally formed oocytes. This gets completed by the age of 2. The ovaries are reduced to atrophic fibrous bands without ova and follicles. These are called streak ovaries.

At puberty, they fail to develop secondary sexual characteristics.

Other options:

Option B: Epicanthic folds and endocardial cushion defects are usually seen in Down's Syndrome or Trisomy 21. This is the most common chromosomal abnormality and a major cause of intellectual disability. Clinical features include prominent occiput, intellectual disability, micrognathia, low-set ears, overlapping fingers, simian palmar crease, and congenital heart defects.

Image below shows karyotyping of a patient with Down's syndrome. Note the extra chromosome 21.

Option C: Eunuchoid body habitus with abnormally long legs is usually seen in Klinefelter Syndrome (47, XXY). Clinical features include eunuchoid body habitus, gynecomastia, long arms and legs, mitral valve prolapse, testicular dysgenesis with a small penis, type 2 diabetes mellitus, metabolic syndrome, low IQ, and hypogonadism.

Image below shows clinical features and karyotyping of Klinefelter Syndrome respectively. Note the two X and one Y chromosomes.

Option D: Rocker bottom feet and umbilical hernia are usually seen in Edwards Syndrome, Trisomy 18. Clinical Features are microcephaly, intellectual disability, cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia, polydactyly, cardiac defects, umbilical hernia, renal defects, and rocker bottom feet.

The image below shows karyotyping of a patient with Edwards syndrome. Note the extra chromosome 18.

questions.text: A woman was diagnosed with Stage 3 gestational trophoblastic neoplasia as per the classification by the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO). Which of the following images represents her stage?
questions.solution:
According to the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO), metastases to lungs are considered stage III gestational trophoblastic neoplasia(GTN), represented by image 3.

FIGO Stage  Extent
Stage I   GTN confined to the uterus

Stage II 

 GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures (adnexa, vagina, broad ligament)
Stage III  GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
Stage IV  All other metastatic sites

 

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) refers to the aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblast cells. It includes invasive mole, gestational choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumors, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated β-hCG levels. FIGO criteria for diagnosis of GTN:

  • Persistence of β-hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer
  • Rise in β-hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longer
  • Elevated β-hCG level for 6 months or more
  • Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma 

A modified prognostic scoring system by the WHO distinguishes patients at low risk for therapeutic failure from those at high risk. Treatment for the low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with a history significant of a mood disorder. His moods can be charted as shown in the image. What will be the best drug for him?
questions.solution:
The patient has rapid-cycling bipolar disorder. Sodium valproate is the drug of choice for this disorder.

Diagnosis of rapid-cycling bipolar disorder:

  • 4 or more mood disturbances in a year

Episodes either have a partial or full remission for at least 2 months or switch to the opposite polarity

Other options:

Option A: Lamotrigine has been found to have limited uses in rapid-cycling bipolar disorder. It can prolong the time between depression and mania.

Option C: Carbamazepine takes 2-3 weeks for the onset of action and is used in patients not responding to Lithium in Acute Mania.

Option D: Lithium takes 5-7 days to achieve a level of equilibrium, moreover it is effective in Bipolar I disorder and is less efficacious than Divalproex in rapid-cycling bipolar disorder.

 

A recent trial found that increased levels of parathyroid hormone in patients with bipolar disorder were associated with worse clinical outcomes. Researchers suggest vitamin D supplementation as a possible add-on treatment.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient was evaluated for recurrent pregnancy loss. Her hysterosalpingogram and sonography revealed a bicornuate uterus. Defect in the development of which of the following structures leads to this condition?

questions.text: Which of the following is the smallest cestode infecting humans?
questions.solution:
The smallest cestode infecting humans is Hymenolepis nana.

Cestodes are multisegmented, dorsoventrally flattened worms that appear like tapes. They can be further classified into the orders pseudophyllidea and cyclophyllidea. 

Option A: Diphyllobothrium latum is the longest cestode infecting man.

Option C: Heterophyes heterophyes is the smallest trematode infecting man.

Option D: Strongyloides stercoralis is the smallest nematode infecting man.

Also, Fasciolopsis buski is the largest trematode infecting humans.

questions.text: A young boy was diagnosed with tinea capitis. Further investigations were done, and the causative agent was suspected to be Trichophyton mentagrophytes. Which of the following is not a characteristic of this organism?

choices.text: The colony retains a white surface on 1% peptone agar medium.
Clustered round microconidia on bright field microscopy
It can penetrate the hair shaft of the human hair in vitro.

questions.solution:
Option C is the incorrect statement because Trichophyton mentagrophytes shows a positive urease test.

Trichophyton mentagrophytes is a dermatophyte and has the following characteristics:

  • It retains a white surface on a 1% peptone agar medium.
  • Clustered round microconidia on bright field microscopy.
  • The urease test is positive.
  • It can penetrate the hair shaft of human hair in vitro.

Hair perforation test is done to differentiate Trichophyton rubrum from T. mentagrophytes. Strands of human hair is placed in a petri dish with 20 mL of distilled water and autoclaved. It is then inoculated with a few drops of sterile 10% yeast extract and a few fragments of the test fungus and kept for incubation at 250C for 2-3 weeks. The hair is examined microscopically in lactophenol cotton blue-stained wet preparation. If infected with T. mentagrophytes, the shaft will have a wedge-shaped appearance due to surface erosion.

Tinea capitis refers to ringworm of the scalp where there is an invasion of the hair shafts by dermatophyte fungi (Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton). It presents as hair loss with inflammation, with or without itching. Diagnosis is based on clinical features, Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as culture with microscopic examination of the colonies.

  • Trichophyton: May infect skin, hair, and nails. Microconidia are abundant and macroconidia are scanty. Colonies are powdery, velvety, or waxy and show characteristic pigment based on the species.
    • T. rubrum: Red
    • T. mentagrophytes: White-tan
    • T. tonsurans: Cream-yellow
  • Microsporum: Infect only hair and skin. Macroconidia are predominant and microconidia is scanty. Colonies are white, cotton-like, velvety, or powdery.
    • M. audouinii: Brownish
    • M. gypseum: Buff colored
  • Epidermophyton: Infects skin and nails but not hair. E. floccosum is the only pathogen in this genus. They produce only macroconidia. Colonies are greenish-yellow and powdery.

questions.text: As a researcher employed in a pharmaceutical company, you are involved in a clinical trial. A monoclonal antibody for the treatment of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is entering phase III of the clinical trial. Which of these statements correctly describes this phase?

choices.text: 250 healthy volunteers from the general population, randomized and blinded
2946 patients with RCC, randomized and double-blinded
96 healthy volunteers in an open-label study, to study adverse effects
5548 patients with RCC in an open-label observational study

questions.solution:
Phase III trials are usually done on 500–3000 patients with the disease, and these are randomized double-blinded studies.

Phase III trials are usually considered pivotal trials that are necessary for the approval of the majority of drugs. They are also called a multisite trial, which is done for 3–5 years. This phase confirms the efficacy of the drug. It is also done to study the long-term or rare side effects of this drug. 

When the initial phase III trials are complete, the sponsor (usually a pharmaceutical company) applies to the FDA for approval to market the drug. This application is called either a new drug application (NDA) or a biologics license application (BLA).

Note: In some drugs related to rare diseases or oncology, phase II studies are considered pivotal, and the drug may be approved on the basis of phase II studies.

Other phases of clinical trials:

Preclinical trials are performed on animals and they are regulated by guidelines prescribed by the committee for the purpose of the control and supervision of experiments on animals (CPCSEA) in India. Standards for the conduct of clinical trials involving Indian subjects are laid down in good clinical practice (GCP).

Phase I clinical trials are performed on healthy volunteers in an open-label study to determine the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetic properties of the drug.

Phase II clinical trials are conducted to evaluate the appropriate dose range of the drug. It is evaluated on a small group of patients (50-500) with the target disease. Most of the new drugs will be administered for the first time in patients with the target disease.

The study is designed to obtain proof of concept (potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging study (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase III studies).

Phase IV clinical trials are conducted after the drug is marketed and approved by regulatory authorities. It includes post-marketing surveillance and other studies that complement the earlier findings on the drug.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is not a macrophage?
questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned are macrophages except the dendritic cell which is a professional antigen-presenting cell.

Macrophages are the largest of the lymphoid cells which form a part of the mononuclear phagocyte system. They arise from progenitors in the yolk sac or fetal liver early in embryogenesis and migrate to various organs to persist as stable resident cells. In the bone marrow, the progenitor cells give rise to monocytes which enter the blood during inflammatory processes. According to the tissue location and function, the macrophages are named as: 

Macrophage Location
Kupffer cells Liver

Sinus histiocytes

 Spleen and lymph nodes

Microglial cells

 Central nervous system
Alveolar macrophages Lungs
Mesangial cells Kidney 


Macrophages are components of both innate and acquired immunity. Macrophages that have phagocytosed microbes and protein antigens process the antigens and present peptide fragments to T cells. Thus, macrophages also function as antigen-presenting cells in T-cell activation and efficiently phagocytose and destroy microbes that are opsonized (coated) with IgG or C3b. Phagocytosis is also done by dendritic cells, monocytes, and granulocytes like neutrophils, eosinophils, and basophils.

Dendritic Cells (DCs) are antigen-presenting cells that are located at the common sites of entry of microbes and foreign antigens and in the interstitia of all tissues, where antigens may be produced. These are derived from bone marrow, a lineage different from macrophages and lymphocytes. They possess receptors like TLR (toll-like receptors) for capturing microbes and are recruited in large numbers to the T-cell zones of lymphoid organs. Here, they present antigens to naive T cells with the help of MHC. 

Follicular dendritic cells (FDC) are present in the germinal centers of lymphoid follicles in the spleen and lymph nodes. They present antigens to B cells in the germinal center which in turn express highly affinitive antibodies and later mature into plasma cells or memory cells. Langerhans cells are immature dendritic cells seen within the epidermis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant lady is set to undergo dilatation and curettage. Which of the following instruments will not be used in this procedure?

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with hypertension is diagnosed with stage 4 chronic kidney disease, with eGFR of <30. His doctor wants to prescribe a thiazide diuretic. Which of the following can be given?
questions.solution:
The thiazide diuretic that can be used as an antihypertensive in this patient with chronic kidney disease is metolazone.

In patients with chronic renal failure, thiazide diuretics are ineffective. But metolazone, despite being a thiazide diuretic, is effective as antihypertensives in patients with chronic renal failure.

Metolazone is useful even in severe renal failure (GFR of ∼15 mL/min). It has an additive action when combined with loop diuretics like furosemide. It also has an additional proximal tubular action (thiazides mainly act on DCT). It is commonly used for edema and is occasionally used as an antihypertensive.

Diuretics in hypertension:

Thiazides are the diuretics of choice for uncomplicated hypertension.

Mechanisms of antihypertensive action:

  • Decreases plasma and ECF volume by diuresis thereby decreasing cardiac output
  • Even when the compensatory mechanisms restore the Na+ levels and plasma volume, a low BP is maintained by a reduction in total peripheral resistance.
  • This reduction in total peripheral resistance is due to the persistence of a small sodium and volume deficit even after compensation. The decreased intracellular sodium is responsible for increased compliance of the vessel wall and a  reduced response to constrictor stimulus.

Advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve.
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost
  • Effectiveness in isolated systolic hypertension

Thiazides are ineffective both as antihypertensive and diuretic in patients with chronic renal failure.

High ceiling diuretics: Furosemide is the prototype drug in this class and it is a weaker antihypertensive agent than thiazides. They are given in hypertension only in the presence of the following complications:

  • Chronic renal failure - As thiazides are ineffective
  • Coexisting refractory congestive heart failure
  • Resistance to combination regimen with thiazides
  • Marked fluid retention with the use of potent vasodilators.

Potassium-sparing diuretics - They are only used in combination with thiazides to prevent the loss of potassium.

Side effects of diuretics include hypokalemia, carbohydrate intolerance, dyslipidemia, and hyperuricemia.

questions.text: A group of scientists is studying a protein. They electrophorese the protein and transfer it to a membrane. The proteins are visualized by tagging them to specific antibodies. This procedure is called:
questions.solution:
The above procedure depicts Western blot technique. This technique is used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized. 

Northern blot technique is used to detect RNAs. The RNAs are separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a membrane and bound to radiolabelled probes.

Southern blot technique is used to detect DNAs. In this technique, DNA is extracted from the cells and is cleaved into many fragments using a restriction enzyme. The resulting fragments are separated based on the size using electrophoresis. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane for analysis. The DNA fragment of interest is then identified using the specific DNA probe.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with a T3 tumor of the glottis with invasion into the paraglottic space. All of the following form the boundaries of this space, except ______.
questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned structures form the boundaries of paraglottic space, except the arcuate lines which form the superior and inferior borders of Reinke's space.

Paraglottic space has the following boundaries:

  • Superior - Para-glottic space is continuous with the pre-epiglottic space
  • Posterior - Piriform fossa
  • Lateral - Thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane
  • Medial - Quadrangular membrane in the upper part and conus elasticus in the lower part

It consists of the adipose tissue, internal laryngeal nerve, laryngeal ventricle, and saccule.

Tumors of the glottis are classified as T3 when the growth is limited to the larynx with fixation of vocal cords or thyroid cartilage erosion or invasion into the paraglottic space.

Pre-epiglottic space of Boyer lies anterior to the epiglottis. Its relations are as follows:

  • Superior - Hyoepiglottic membrane.
  • Inferior - Thyroepiglottic ligament.
  • Anterior - Thyrohyoid membrane.
  • Posterior - Epiglottis.
  • Lateral - Greater cornua of the hyoid bone in the upper part, continuous with the paraglottic space in the lower part.

Reinke's space lies under the epithelium of vocal cords. It has the following boundaries :

  • Superior and inferior - Arcuate lines
  • Anterior - Anterior commissure
  • Posterior - Vocal process of arytenoid

questions.text: A surgical team plans for liver transplantation in a child. As a part of the evaluation, you are asked to calculate the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score. Which of the following parameters would you not consider for the evaluation of this score?
questions.solution:
Creatinine is not included in the Child–Turcotte–Pugh Score or Child-Pugh scoring system. Creatinine is used in the MELD score calculation.

The variables taken into account for the calculation of the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score include serum bilirubin, albumin, prothrombin time, International Normalized ratio, and clinical signs suggestive of the presence of ascites and encephalopathy. 

The Child-Pugh score is a predictor of operative mortality in patients with cirrhosis and esophageal bleeding. It is now used to estimate a patient’s overall prognosis. 

Alternative scores include the Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) and Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease (PELD) models for all patients with chronic liver disease. The MELD score is calculated using serum sodium, serum creatinine, serum total bilirubin, and INR level.

The PELD model for children under 12 years of age, includes both clinical and biochemical factors. It is predictive of disease severity and waiting list mortality in pediatric patients. The PELD score is calculated using the following variables:

  • Albumin (g/dL)
  • Bilirubin (mg/dL)
  • INR
  • Growth failure (based on gender, height, and weight)
  • Age at listing

questions.text: A young woman presents with itchy skin lesions on her wrists. On examination, purple, polygonal, plaques are seen on the wrist. The lesions have a thin white line on their surface. On examination of the oral cavity, the following finding is seen. Which of the following is seen on the microscopy?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the image showing thin white lines on the oral mucosa known as Wickham striae are suggestive of lichen planus. Microscopy will show the presence of colloid bodies.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane. Microscopy will show acanthosis of the epidermis, irregular thickening of the granular layer, and compact hyperkeratosis.  Degenerating basal epidermal cells are transformed into colloid bodies. The rete ridges may have the sawtooth appearance, and focal separation from the dermis may lead to Max-Joseph spaces. In active LP, a band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes is seen near the dermo-epidermal junction.

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin, white lines on their surface known as Wickham striae. They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles.

Mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are buccal mucosa and tongue, rarely it can also be found on the anus and genitalia. 

Nail involvement can be seen as thinning of the nail plate, leading to an exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions. The nails can also be destroyed leading to anonychia. Involvement of the nail bed may give rise to longitudinal melanonychia, hyperpigmentation, subungual hyperkeratosis, or onycholysis.

Other options:

Option A - Burrow of mite is seen in scabies. The patients will have skin lesions that are very itchy and worse at night. The family members will also have similar complaints. It is commonly present in the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia, and women's breasts.

Option B - Munro microabscess is the accumulation of neutrophils in the stratum corneum. The lesions present as red scaly plaques, which are well demarcated from the surrounding normal skin. They might have a circle of clear zone around it, which is known as the Woronoff ring. 

Option C - Tear-shaped microconidia are seen in tinea corporis, which is commonly caused due to Trichophyton rubrum. The lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge. There might be a similar history in the close contacts.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

questions.text: A study is performed where the mothers of both low birth weight (LBW) and normal birth weight babies are questioned regarding their intake of oral hypoglycemic agents (OHA) during the 1st trimester to determine the association of LBW and OHA intake in the first trimester. Which measure of association is appropriate for this study?
questions.solution:
The study design mentioned is a case-control study design to evaluate the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome. Hence, the best-suited measure would be the odds ratio.

Note that because the proportion of people in a case-control study who have the disease is determined by the researcher’s choice, and not by the actual proportion in the population, such studies cannot determine the incidence or prevalence of a disease, so they cannot determine the risk of contracting a disease. However, the strength of the association between a risk factor and the disease can still be evaluated with a case-control study, by examining the proportions of the people with and without the disease who had and had not, been exposed to the risk factor.

Other options:

Option A - Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Option C - Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option D - Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer

Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where,

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman with abdominal pain and hematochezia was diagnosed with stage II colon carcinoma located in the hepatic flexure. An extended right hemicolectomy was performed. Which of the following images represents the mentioned procedure?

(the white area indicates the parts resected)
questions.solution:
Image 2 represents extended right hemicolectomy, which is the surgical procedure of choice for colorectal carcinoma in the hepatic flexure.

This procedure involves the division of the ileocolic, right colic, and middle colic vessels, and the removal of the specimen with its mesentery. The parts resected include the cecum, approximately 10 cm of the terminal ileum with ileocecal junction, ascending colon, hepatic flexure, and proximal transverse colon (distal transverse colon and splenic flexure are also sometimes removed).

Procedures performed for tumors of the colon are summarized below:

  • Ligation and division of the ileocolic, right colic, and right branch of the middle colic vessels 
  • Resection of cecum + approx 10 cm of the terminal ileum with ileocecal junction + ascending colon + hepatic flexure

  • Ligation and division of the ileocolic, right colic, and middle colic vessels 
  • Resection of the cecum + approx 10 cm of the terminal ileum with ileocecal junction + ascending colon + hepatic flexure + proximal transverse colon (distal transverse colon and splenic flexure are also sometimes removed)
Splenic flexure/ Descending colon

  • Ligation and division of the left branch of the middle colic vessels, the left colic vessel, and the first branches of the sigmoid vessels 
  • Resection of the transverse colon (left MCA territory) + Splenic flexure + Descending colon up to the sigmoid colon

  • Ligation and division of the sigmoid branches of the inferior mesenteric artery.
  • Removal of the entire sigmoid colon and rectum

 

Other options:

Image 3 represents a total proctocolectomy. Here, the entire colon, rectum, and anus are removed, and the ileum is brought to the skin with ileostomy.

Image 4 represents a total or subtotal colectomy. The entire colon is removed except for the sigmoid colon to create an ileosigmoidal anastomosis. It is done for fulminant colitis, attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), or synchronous colon carcinomas.

questions.text: Identify the muscle attached at the marked location in this posterior surface of the femur.
questions.solution:
The marked structure in this posterior surface of the femur is the intertrochanteric crest. The muscle attached at this location is the quadratus femoris. 

Quadratus femoris muscle originates from the upper part of the external aspect of the ischial tuberosity and is inserted on a small tubercle above the middle of the intertrochanteric crest of the femur. It mainly causes lateral rotation at the hip joint. It is innervated by the nerve to quadratus femoris.

 

Below is the image showing posterior hip muscles:

 

Other options:

Option A) Obturator externus originates from the obturator membrane and from the adjacent pubic and ischial rami. It is inserted into the trochanteric fossa of the femur. It assists in lateral rotation at the hip joint. It is innervated by the posterior branch of the obturator nerve

Option C) Gluteus medius originates from the outer surface of the ilium between the anterior and posterior gluteal lines and from the strong fascia superficial to its upper part. It is inserted into the lateral surface of the greater trochanter. It acts with the gluteus minimus to cause abduction and medial rotation at the hip joint. It is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

Option D) Gluteus minimus originates from the outer surface of the ilium between the anterior and inferior gluteal lines and from the margin of the greater sciatic notch. It is inserted into the anterolateral ridge of the greater trochanter and also contributes to the capsule of the hip joint. Its main actions are abduction and medial rotation at the hip joint. It is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl presents with high-grade fever, diarrhea, and abdominal pain that is unresponsive to medication for the past 4 days. She recently recovered from COVID-19 and there is no other history of illness. On examination, the following findings were observed. Which of the following drugs is used in managing the condition?

General physical examination shows a generalized rash all over her body

HR: 70/min

BP: 100/72 mmHg

RR: 18/min

C-Reactive protein: 12 mg/L

ESR: 62 mm/hr
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the lab values point towards the diagnosis of Multisystemic Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C). Since the patient is hemodynamically stable she is classified as MIS-C without shock and IV methylprednisolone 1-2 mg/kg/day is used in the management of this subtype.

Diagnostic criteria for MIS-C:

  1. Children and adolescents 0–18 years of age with fever ≥3 days
  2. And any two of these:
  • Rash or bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis or mucocutaneous inflammation signs (palmoplantar erythema, lip hyperemia, periorbital erythema and edema, strawberry tongue, and malar erythema).
  • Hypotension or shock
  • Features of myocardial dysfunction, pericarditis, valvulitis, or coronary abnormalities (including ECHO findings or elevated Troponin/ NT-proBNP)
  • Evidence of coagulopathy (PT, PTT, elevated D-Dimers)
  • Acute gastrointestinal problems (diarrhea, vomiting, or abdominal pain)

    3. And elevated ESR >40 mm, C-reactive protein >5 mg/L, or procalcitonin.

    4. And no other obvious microbial cause of inflammation including bacterial sepsis, staphylococcal or streptococcal shock syndromes.

    5. And evidence of COVID-19 (RT-PCR, antigen test, or serology positive), or likely contact with patients with COVID-19.

Other options:

Option A:  IV immunoglobulin 2 mg/kg alone is not used in the management of MIS-C. 

Option C: IV immunoglobulin 2 gm/kg + IV methylprednisolone 1-2 mg/kg/day is used in the Kawasaki phenotype of MIS-C. The absence of fever for more than 5 days without conjunctival findings, cervical lymphadenopathy, strawberry tongue, and swollen hands and feet rule out the possibility of Kawasaki's disease and Kawasaki phenotype of MIS-C.

Option D: Although prednisone has almost similar anti-inflammatory action as methylprednisolone, the latest Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, Govt. of India guidelines prescribe the use of IV methylprednisolone 1-2 mg/kg/day in the management of MIS-C.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presented with a sore throat, fever, and malaise.  Examination findings are given in the image below. She was also found to have a penicillin drug allergy. Which of the following antibiotics can be used for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing a bull neck appearance and greyish-white membrane over the faucial pillar are suggestive of pharyngeal diphtheria. Erythromycin can be used in this patient as she has a penicillin allergy.

Diphtheria is caused by the bacteria Corynebacterium diphtheriae which spreads via droplets through the respiratory tract (most important), cutaneous lesions, and fomites.

Respiratory tract diphtheria is characterized by a thick, adherent pseudomembrane (grey or white) on one/both tonsils and adjacent pharynx. Underlying soft tissue edema and enlarged lymph nodes can cause a bull-neck appearance. 

Patients with laryngeal diphtheria are at risk for suffocation because of local soft-tissue edema and airway obstruction by the diphtheritic membrane.

Management includes antitoxin therapy as a single empirical dose of 20,000-100,000 units and antibiotics. Penicillin G/ Benzylpenicillin is the drug of choice for diphtheria. However, in case of an allergy to the same, Erythromycin is used. Other antibiotics used are clindamycin, rifampin, and tetracycline.

All household contacts should be closely monitored for 7 days. Culture should be taken from both the throat and nose. After culture, all contacts should receive the following.

  • Antibiotic prophylaxis (benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin), regardless of immunization status.
  • If fewer than three doses of diphtheria toxoid have been given, or vaccination history is unknown, an immediate dose of diphtheria toxoid should be given and the primary series completed according to the current schedule.
  • If more than 5 years have elapsed since the administration of the diphtheria toxoid-containing vaccine, a booster dose should be given.
  • If the most recent dose was within 5 years, no booster is required.

At least two successive negative cultures obtained 24 hr apart after completion of therapy are needed to confirm the elimination of the organism. If positive culture is obtained, the erythromycin course is repeated.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man feels embarrassed to talk with his peers because of the persistence of a high-pitched childhood voice. At times, he has noticed that on pressing the thyroid prominence, he was able to produce an adult-type voice. Which of the following thyroplasty procedure would benefit this patient?

choices.text: Shortening or relaxation of vocal cord
Lengthening or tightening of vocal cord

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of puberphonia, also known as mutational falsetto voice. A type III thyroplasty causing shortening or relaxation of the vocal cord would benefit this patient.

When larynx matures at puberty, the voice becomes low-pitched in males. Puberphonia (mutational falsetto voice) is a condition in which the transition from high-pitched childhood voice to adult male voice fails to occur. The vocal cords are stretched and pose high tension.

Pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and a low tone voice can be produced. This is called Gutzmann’s pressure test.

In type III thyroplasty, the vocal cord is shortened and hence the tension is reduced. This can revert from a childhood voice to an adult one.

Type of thyroplasty Procedure done
Type I Medial displacement of vocal cord
Type II Lateral displacement of vocal cord
Type III Shortening (relaxation) of vocal cord
Type IV Lengthening (tightening) of vocal cord

questions.text: A young patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. On examination, there was a loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception over the left lower limb. A provisional diagnosis of hemisection of the spinal cord was made. Lesions of which of the following structures are responsible for the findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of hemisection of the spinal cord is suggestive of Brown-Séquard syndrome. Lesions of the left fasciculus gracilis are responsible for the observed findings.

Lesions of the fasciculus gracilis lead to the loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception over the ipsilateral lower limb (fibers from the sacral cord are positioned most medially and those from the cervical cord are positioned most laterally).

On the other hand, lesions of fasciculus cuneatus lesion will lead to loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception over the ipsilateral upper limb.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to the ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Given below is the histological section of the cornea. Identify the structures marked X and Y in the image.
questions.solution:
The structures marked X and Y are the endothelium and Bowman's membrane, respectively.

The human cornea has five layers. From the anterior to posterior, the layers of the human cornea are as follows:

  1. Corneal epithelium - It is the outermost layer made up of non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. It is continuous with the conjunctival epithelium.
  2. Bowman's layer - The anterior-limiting lamina lies behind the corneal epithelium. It contains a dense mass of collagen (mainly type I collagen fibrils) set in a matrix similar to that of the substantia propria.
  3. Corneal stroma (also substantia propria) - It is a thick, transparent middle layer, consisting of regularly arranged collagen fibers along with sparsely distributed interconnected keratocytes.
  4. Descemet's membrane - It is a thin acellular layer that serves as the modified basement membrane of the corneal endothelium, from which the cells are derived. This layer is composed mainly of collagen type IV fibrils.
  5. Corneal endothelium - The endothelium covers the posterior surface of the cornea and consists of a single layer of squamous cells.

The sixth layer called Dua’s layer or pre-Descemet’s layer has been recently discovered, located between the stroma and the Descemet’s membrane.

questions.text: The image below shows the various steps of the primary hemostasis mechanism. What are the steps defective in the platelet functional disorders Bernard-Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann thrombasthenia, respectively?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option B-1, 5. 

In the given image

  • 1 - Platelet adhesion, which is defective in Bernard-Soulier syndrome
  • 2 - Shape change
  • 3 - Granule release
  • 4 - Recruitment 
  • 5 - Platelet aggregation which is defective in Glanzmann thrombasthenia

Bernard-Soulier syndrome:

It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to an inherited deficiency of platelet membrane glycoprotein complex Ib-IX. This glycoprotein is a receptor of the von Willebrand factor, which is needed for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. 

Glanzmann thrombasthenia:

It is an autosomal recessive platelet disorder that results from a deficiency of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex, which is needed for platelet aggregation.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of drugs act on the same receptor but have opposite effects?
questions.solution:
Diazoxide and nateglinide act on K-ATP channels (potassium-ATP channels) on the beta cells of pancreas. Nateglinide causes these channels to close, while diazoxide keeps them open.

Closure of these channels eventually results in insulin release, hence nateglinide is used in diabetics. Diazoxide is used in insulinomas, because it inhibits insulin release by keeping these channels open.

Other options:

Option A: Octreotide is a synthetic surrogate of somatostatin. They both inhibit growth hormone release. Since octreotide is more potent and with increased duration of action, it is preferred for use in acromegaly and secretory diarrheas.

Option B: Thioridazine and haloperidol are D2 (dopamine) receptor blockers. These are typical antipsychotics and used to treat schizophrenia and similar psychotic conditions.

Option C: Pioglitazone is a PPAR gamma agonist used in diabetes, while gemfibrozil is a PPAR alpha agonist, used in hyperlipidemia. (PPAR: peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor).

questions.text: What kind of suturing is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a subcuticular suture.

The subcuticular suture technique is performed by taking a bite alternatively on either side of the wound and gently pulling until the end. This is used in the skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily.

Either an absorbable or non-absorbable suture material can be used.

Frequently used suture techniques are as follows:

Interrupted suture (Option B): Here, the needle is inserted perpendicular to the incision. It then passes through both sides of the suture line and exits again at a right angle. The distance from the needle's entry point to the edge of the wound (x) should be approximately the same as the depth of the tissue (x) being sutured. The next suture should be placed twice the distance away from the first suture (2x). Interrupted sutures are shown below.

 

Continuous suture (Option C): The first suture is placed in the same way as an interrupted suture, but the remaining sutures are inserted in a continuous manner till the far end of the wound. It is shown below.

 

Mattress suture (Option D): Mattress sutures may be either vertical or horizontal. They result in either eversion or inversion of the wound edge. The first suture is inserted like in an interrupted suture. After that, the needle is moved either horizontally or vertically, traversing both edges of the wound. It is shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the structure of skin?

choices.text: The epidermis is composed of stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium
Stratum lucidum is present between stratum granulosum and stratum spinosum
Stratum spinosum is also called prickle layer
Melanocytes are present in stratum spinosum

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding the structure of the skin is stratum spinosum also called the prickle cell layer.

Stratum spinosum of the skin consists of intercellular attachments, also called desmosomes, which appear like spines on microscopy, hence the name prickle layer or spinous layer. Desmosomes connect keratinocytes in the epidermis of the skin.

The skin is the largest organ in the body and consists of the epidermis and dermis. The epidermis is derived from ectoderm whereas the dermis is derived from mesoderm. The dermal collagens are types I and III while the basement membrane collagen is type IV collagen.

The epidermis is composed of keratinized, stratified squamous epithelium. Depending on the number of layers of the epidermis, either thin skin or thick skin may be seen. 

Thin skin refers to the skin that has four layers of the epidermis, which are, from deep to superficial:

  1. Stratum basale
  2. Stratum spinosum
  3. Stratum granulosum
  4. Stratum corneum. 

Thick skin is found only on the palms and soles. It has a fifth layer, called the stratum lucidum, which is located between the stratum corneum and the stratum granulosum.

The malpighian layer of the epidermis includes both stratum basale and stratum spinosum as a unit.

The epidermis is predominantly made up of keratinocytes. Melanocytes and Merkel cells are present in the stratum basale, and langerhans cells are present in the stratum spinosum.

Mnemonic for epidermal layers (superficial to deep): Come Let's Get Some Beer (Corneum, Lucidum, Granulosum, Spinosum, and Basale).

questions.text: A newborn is being assessed for his gestational age. Which of the following is not a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score?
questions.solution:
The cubital angle is not a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded new Ballard score.

The expanded New Ballard score is used to assess the physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn and thereby calculate the gestational age.

  • There are six criteria each to assess physical maturity and neuromuscular maturity.
  • The physical maturity and neurologic maturity scores are added to calculate the gestational age.
  • The minimum score is -10 and the maximum score is 50.
  • It is accurate to within 2 wk of actual gestational age
  • Premature infants have low scores while post dated infants have higher scores.

Neuromuscular criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  1. Posture
  2. Square window (wrist)
  3. Arm recoil
  4. Popliteal angle
  5. Scarf sign
  6. Heel to ear

Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  1. Skin
  2. Lanugo
  3. Plantar surface
  4. Breast
  5. Eye/ear
  6. Genitals - male or female

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding symmetric intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)?

choices.text: It is caused by placental insufficiency
Insult on fetal growth occurs early

questions.solution:
The insult on fetal growth occurs at an early stage in symmetrical intrauterine growth restriction.

Asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) is associated with a brain-sparing effect, unlike symmetric IUGR, where there is no sparing of head growth.

IUGR is often classified as follows: 

Symmetric IUGR

Asymmetric IUGR
Insult on fetal growth occurs early, as a result, head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected. Insult occurs in late gestation, producing a relative sparing of head growth.
It is caused by genetic, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections. It is caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension, or maternal medical diseases.

 

Note: The Ponderal index can be used to determine the degree of fetal malnutrition. It is calculated as the ratio of body weight in grams to length in cm expressed as PI = [weight {in gram} × 100] ÷ length {in cm}³. The normal value of the ponderal index is 2-2.5. Ponderal index > 2 is suggestive of symmetrical IUGR whereas value < 2 is suggestive of asymmetrical IUGR.

questions.text: Which of the following polysaccharides does not have a plant origin?
questions.solution:
Chitin among the mentioned polysaccharides has an animal origin. It is present in mushrooms, exoskeletons of crustaceans, and insects. It is made of N-acetyl-D-glucosamine units joined by β1 → 4 glycosidic bonds.

Polysaccharides are polymers of monosaccharides. It is of two main types: 

1) Homopolysaccharide is made of 1 type of monomer. e.g. starch, insulin, glycogen, and cellulose
2) Heteropolysaccharide is made of >1 type of monomer. e.g. hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate

Option A: Starch is the reservoir carbohydrate of the plant kingdom. It is the most important dietary carbohydrate. It is present mainly in cereals, potatoes, legumes, and other vegetables. The glycemic index of a starch-rich food is a measure of its digestibility. Starch hydrolyzes 100% in the small intestine.
The two main constituents are as follows: 
- Amylose has a non-branching, helical structure
- Amylopectin (major) consists of branched chains. It is made of 24 to 30 glucose residues with α1 → 4 linkages in the chains and α1 → 6 linkages at the branch points.

Option C: Cellulose is the chief constituent of plant cell walls. It is insoluble and consists of β-D-glucopyranose units linked by β1 → 4 bonds to form long, straight chains strengthened by cross-linking hydrogen bonds. Mammals lack the enzyme that can hydrolyze β1 → 4 bonds, so they cannot digest cellulose. It is a major constituent of dietary fiber. Microorganisms in the gut of ruminants and other herbivores can hydrolyze the linkage and ferment the products to short-chain fatty acids as a major energy source. 

Option D: Inulin is composed of D-fructose units with repeating beta-1,2 linkages. It is of plant origin and is found in tubers and roots of dahlias, artichokes, and dandelions. It is readily soluble in water and is used to determine the glomerular filtration rate. 

Other polysaccharides of importance: 

Dextrans are highly branched homopolymers of glucose units with 1-6, 1-4, and 1-3 linkages. Since they will not easily go out of the vascular compartment, they are used for intravenous infusion as plasma volume expanders for the treatment of hypovolemic shock.

Glycogen is also known as animal starch because it is the reservoir carbohydrate in animals. It is stored in the liver and muscles. Excess carbohydrate is stored in this form. It is a more branched and more compact structure than amylopectin: it has chains of 12 to 15 α-D-glucopyranose residues (in α1 → 4 glucosidic linkage), which show branching through α1 → 6 glucosidic bonds.

Dietary fibers: It is the edible part of plants which is non-digestible, non-starch carbohydrates and lignin. The AI for dietary fiber is 25 g/day for women and 38 g/day for men. It is completely or partially fermented by the gut bacteria to short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) in the large intestine. SCFAs play an essential role in regulating host metabolism, the immune system, and cell proliferation. Dietary fiber provides little energy but has several beneficial effects.

  • It adds bulk to the diet.
  • It draws fluid into the lumen of the intestine and increases bowel motility (laxation).
  • It delays gastric emptying and can result in a sensation of fullness (satiety).
  • This delayed emptying also results in reduced spikes in blood glucose following a meal.
  • It lowers LDL cholesterol levels by increasing fecal bile acid excretion and interfering with bile acid reabsorption.
  • It decreases the risk for constipation, hemorrhoids, and diverticulosis. 

Functional fiber is the term used for isolated fiber that has proven health benefits such as commercially available fiber supplements. The introduction of fiber into the diet should be gradual as it can lead to abdominal discomfort, gas, diarrhea, and even constipation.

questions.text: You are writing a review on various government schemes that help provide non-formal education and aim at reducing malnutrition, morbidity, and mortality. The logo of one such scheme is given below. Which of the following schemes does it represent?

choices.text: Ministry of Woman and Child Development
National Commission for Protection of Child Rights

questions.solution:
The given logo is of ICDS - Integrated child development services.

Integrated child development services:

It was launched on the 2nd of October, 1975, and focuses on early childhood care and development. The scheme helps in providing pre-school non-formal education and breaking the vicious cycle of malnutrition, morbidity, reduced learning capacity, and mortality. Beneficiaries under the Scheme include children in the age group of 0-6 years, pregnant women, and lactating mothers.

Objectives:

  • to improve the nutritional and health status of children in the age group 0-6 years
  • to lay the foundation for proper psychological, physical and social development of the child
  • to reduce the incidence of mortality, morbidity, malnutrition, and school dropout
  • to achieve effective co-ordination of policy and implementation amongst the various departments to promote child development
  • to enhance the capability of the mother to look after the normal health and nutritional needs of the child through proper nutrition and health education.

Other options:

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is admitted for a minor surgical procedure, which is likely to be completed in 75 minutes.  Which of the following infiltrative anesthetics is suitable for this patient?
questions.solution:
Lidocaine is the infiltrative anesthetic suitable for this patient due to its moderate duration of action, which lasts for 30–60 minutes.

Lidocaine is a local anesthetic that can be used for peripheral nerve blockade, topical, infiltrative, spinal, and epidural anesthesia. The duration of infiltration anesthesia can be prolonged by the addition of epinephrine to lidocaine (up to 120 minutes). It is also used for intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA) in short surgical procedures (<90 minutes) on the limbs. 

It is metabolized by CYP enzymes in the liver. Large amounts of lidocaine can exacerbate symptoms of myasthenia gravis and cardiac toxicity, as well as transient neurological symptoms.

Bupivacaine, ropivacaine, and tetracaine are all long-acting drugs.

questions.text: A known alcoholic patient with chronic liver disease presents to you with jaundice, pedal edema, and the following finding. This finding does not improve despite sodium restriction. What will you do next?
questions.solution:
In the above image, the patient has abdominal distension and fullness of flanks suggestive of ascites. If ascites does not improve with sodium restriction alone, then the next step in the management of this patient is to administer diuretics.

Ascites is the accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity. In cirrhosis, it occurs as a result of portal hypertension.

The initial step in the management of ascites is sodium restriction. If the patient is not improving despite sodium restriction, then the next step would be to start diuretics. Spironolactone and furosemide are the diuretics used.

The majority of the patients improve with sodium restriction and diuretics. When the ascites is not improving despite these measures, it is called refractory ascites. In such cases, large volume paracentesis and transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) procedures should be considered.

Large volume paracentesis is the removal of 5 or more liters of ascitic fluid. Following paracentesis, fluid from the intravascular space shifts to the extravascular space leading to circulatory dysfunction. Therefore, intravenous saline or albumin infusion is required to maintain intravascular volume. Paracentesis of up to 4 liters can be performed safely with saline infusion alone. If the volume of fluid removed is ≥5 L, then an albumin infusion of 8g should be administered for every liter of ascitic fluid removed.

The pathophysiology of the development of ascites in liver cirrhosis is given below.

Related Pearl: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme activity is increased in the fed state?
questions.solution:
The activity of the enzyme glycogen synthase is increased in the fed state.

Glycogen functions as the secondary long-term energy storage, with the primary energy stores being fats held in adipose tissue. Hence, glycogen synthesis/glycogenesis activity is increased in the fed state. Glycogenesis takes place majorly in the skeletal muscle and the liver.

Metabolic changes that take place in fasting and fed states:

Glucose 6-phosphate derived from glycogen breakdown can

  • Be used as a fuel for glycolysis in muscles,
  • Be converted into free glucose in the liver and subsequently released into the blood, and
  • Enter into the the pentose phosphate pathway to generate NADPH or ribose in a variety of tissues.

Other options:

Option A: Glycogen phosphorylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis and is decreased in the fed state.

Option B: HMG CoA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme of ketogenesis and is decreased in the fed state.

Option D: Pyruvate carboxylase is the enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis. It converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate. Its levels are decreased in the fed state.

questions.text: An elderly man with schizophrenia, on typical antipsychotics for 2 years, presents with involuntary, painless orofacial movements. The psychiatrist diagnosed it as an extrapyramidal side effect. Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of his presenting symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the long-term extrapyramidal side effect of a typical antipsychotic known as tardive dyskinesia. FDA approved the VMAT2 inhibitors valbenazine and deutetrabenazine for its treatment.

It develops after months to years of initiation of the drug. Choreiform movements affect the mouth, lips, and tongue. In severe cases, trunks, limbs, and respiratory muscles may also be affected.

In one-third of cases, tardive dyskinesia remits within 3 months of stopping the drug, and improvement occurs over several years.

Valbenazine is metabolized by CYP3A4 and CYP2D6. Hence, it is to be used with caution with inducers or inhibitors of each. It is also avoided in hepatic impairment. 

Other options: 

Option A: Beta-blockers like propranolol are used for akathisia.

Option B: Dantrolene is used for neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option D: Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic drug that is used in acute dystonia and parkinsonism.

questions.text: All the passengers coming to India were screened for COVID-19 at the airport. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for the immigrants to a country is prospective screening. 

Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are examined for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community, thereby reducing the mortality associated with the disease.

Examples of prospective screening:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever

Other options:

Option A - Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined for their own benefit. Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. It may lead to an early diagnosis of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to arrest disease progression.

Examples of prescriptive screening:

  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of school children for visual and auditory defects.

Option B - Multiphasic screening is the combined application of two or more screening tests to a large number of people at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

Option D - Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most productive screening tests. Examples include MRI screening of the breast done annually in a 25-year-old woman with a first-degree relative having BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.

questions.text: A newborn child presents with the following finding in the right eye as shown in the image below. The left eye is normal. What is the ideal age to take this patient up for elective surgery?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dense unilateral congenital cataract. Ideally, unilateral dense cataract merits urgent surgery and it is at 6 weeks when elective surgery should be performed.

Generally, it is not advisable to operate on lamellar cataracts until the child is 1 or preferably 2 years old. But when the lens is completely opaque, or the pupil will not dilate, and when squint or nystagmus is developing, it is wise to operate at an earlier age. Moreover, the results of surgery in unilateral cataracts in children are universally poor, unless the operation is carried out within the first 6 weeks of birth.

This is because the critical period for developing the fixation reflex in both unilateral and bilateral visual deprivation disorders is between 2 and 4 months of age. Thus, any cataract dense enough to impair vision must be dealt with before this age and the earliest possible time is preferred. 

Surgery involves anterior capsulorhexis, aspiration of lens matter, capsulorhexis of the posterior capsule, limited anterior vitrectomy, and IOL implantation, if appropriate. It is important to correct associated refractive errors.

Related Pearl: Types of Congenital Cataract

Punctate cataract: Blue-dot cataract, most common congenital cataract

 

Zonular/Lamellar cataract: Most common congenital cataract with diminished vision; Spokes of a wheel appearance (Rider’s Cataract) A, B, and C

 

Fusiform/coralliform cataract: Anteroposterior spindle shaped appearance. 

 

Nuclear cataract: Most common type of cataract seen in congenital rubella syndrome

 

Coronary cataract: Appears as a corona of club-shaped opacities near the periphery of the lens.

 

Anterior polar cataract: May arise either due to delayed development of anterior chamber or due to corneal perforation

 

Posterior polar cataract: Progressive form of posterior polar cataract, which typically shows an "onion whorl appearance"

questions.text: A middle-aged man suffering from chronic constipation presents with swelling in the inguinal region. On further evaluation, the swelling was confirmed to be due to direct inguinal hernia. Identify the following surgical landmark (denoted in green) from where this type of hernia arises.
questions.solution:
The surgical landmark (shown in green) from where a direct inguinal hernia arises is the Hesselbach triangle.

Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle:

  • Laterally by inferior epigastric artery 
  • Medially by the lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferiorly by inguinal ligament

The floor of the Hesselbach triangle is formed by the transversalis fascia.

A hernia refers to the protrusion of part of the contents of the abdominal cavity through a weakness in the abdominal wall. Inguinal hernias may be direct or indirect. Direct inguinal hernias occur within Hesselbach triangle, while indirect inguinal hernias occur lateral to the triangle.

Patients present with an abdominal lump that is usually painless, but sometimes with an aching or heavy feeling. Cough impulse is usually present, and it is usually reducible. Treatment is urgent in irreducible hernias. Diagnosis is usually clinical.

Other options:

Option A: The boundaries of the triangle of pain are the iliopubic tract, testicular vessels, and the peritoneal fold. The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve are located here.

Option C: The boundaries of the triangle of doom are the vas deferens, testicular vessels, and the peritoneal fold. The external iliac artery and vein are found in this triangle.

Option D: Corona mortis is an anastomosis between the obturator and the external iliac or inferior epigastric arteries or veins, which can lead to life-threatening hemorrhage if accidentally cut.

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)

questions.text: A patient under general anesthesia is being monitored with the device shown below. In this device, what should be the recommended value for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Bispectral index technique with frontal EEG leads. In this device, the recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for general anesthesia is 40-60.

The bispectral index is commonly used in clinical practice to assess the depth of anesthesia.

  • Individual intraoperative awareness is evaluated.
  • It utilizes 4 EEG components - Low-frequency waves, high-frequency waves, suppressed EEG waves, and burst suppression.
  • The algorithm calculates a number combining all these variables. The lesser the number, the deeper is anesthesia.
  • It has numerical values from 0 to 100 with 0 representing isoelectric EEG and 100 being awake CNS.
  • Recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for anesthesia- 40-60.

     60-80   Moderate sedation
     40-60 General anesthesia

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the clinic with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. On bimanual examination, the apposition of vaginal and abdominal fingers is possible below the body of the uterus. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
This sign described above is called Hegar's sign.

During bimanual examination, two fingers are placed in the anterior fornix and two fingers feel are on the abdomen, behind the uterus. Around 6-10 weeks of gestation, the growing fetus leads to enlargement of the upper part of the uterus, while the lower part is empty and soft. The cervix is firm in consistency. Because of this, apposition of the abdominal and vaginal fingers, below the body of the uterus, is possible on bimanual examination. This is called the Hegar's sign.

Other options:

Option A- A bluish tint of the ectocervix due to increased vascularity- Chadwick's sign

Option C- Cervical edema and softening- Goodell sign

Option D- Increased pulsations felt through the lateral fornices - Osiander's sign

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2 P1 lady at her 20th week of gestation presents to the clinic. Her anomaly scan is suggestive of bilateral renal agenesis. On examination, her fundal height is 15 cm. Which among the following parameters is likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Bilateral renal agenesis leads to decreased production of amniotic fluid or oligohydramnios, and the single deepest vertical pocket will be less than 2 cm. (option D).

Oligohydramnios refers to an abnormally decreased amount of amnionic fluid. A diagnosis of oligohydramnios is made when amniotic fluid index (AFI) is less than 5 cm or a single deepest vertical pocket (DVP) of amniotic fluid is less than 2 cm.

Causes of oligohydraminios:

  • Placental abnormalities
  • Maternal complications leading to uteroplacental insufficiency: Pre-eclampsia, vascular disease
  • Renal anomalies:
    • Bilateral renal agenesis
    • Bilateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Unilateral renal agenesis with contralateral multicystic dysplastic kidney
    • Infantile form of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney dis­ease
    • Fetal bladder outlet obstruction - posterior urethral valves, urethral atresia, or stenosis
  • Complex fetal anomalies: persistent cloaca and sireno­melia 
  • Drugs: ACE inhibitors, ARBs, NSAIDs when taken in the 2nd or 3rd trimester

Other options:

Options A and B imply polyhydramnios since the AFI is greater than 24 cm, and the single deepest vertical pocket (DVP) is greater than 8 cm.

Option C: AFI = 10 cm indicates normal AFI (5–25 cm)

questions.text: During a screening camp at a village, a man was found to have severely impaired vision. According to the WHO definition of blindness, what is the cut-off for visual acuity to define it as blindness?
questions.solution:
According to the WHO, blindness is defined as visual acuity of less than 3/60.

The leading causes of vision impairment and blindness are uncorrected refractive errors and cataracts.

Distance vision impairment:

  • Mild – visual acuity worse than 6/12 to 6/18
  • Moderate – visual acuity worse than 6/18 to 6/60
  • Severe – visual acuity worse than 6/60 to 3/60

questions.text: A patient with pulmonary tuberculosis comes for a follow-up. While presenting the history, you explain to the medical students that this is a case of chronic inflammation where macrophages predominate. Which of the following statements is false about the classical pathway of macrophage activation?

choices.text: Activation of this pathway is induced by endotoxins
Th1 CD4+T lymphocytes are essential for the activation of this pathway
Interferon-gamma is the primary cytokine involved in the activation of this pathway
Main function of the macrophages activated by this pathway is cessation of inflammation

questions.solution:
The statement main function of the macrophages activated by this pathway is cessation of inflammation is false about the classical pathway of macrophage activation.

Macrophages are the predominant cells involved in chronic inflammation. These cells are derived from precursors in the embryonic yolk sac and fetal liver in prenatal life and from hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow in postnatal life.

The principal functions of macrophages in chronic inflammation are as follows:

  • Microbicidal activity by secretion of cytokines
  • Continuation of the inflammatory response
  • Initiation of tissue repair and end inflammatory response
  • Sending and responding to signals from T lymphocytes that are essential for cell-mediated defense mechanisms

The abovementioned functions of macrophages are carried out once they are activated by two principal pathways:

  • Classical macrophage activation pathway:
    • The macrophages activated in this pathway are called M1 macrophages.
    • The activation of this pathway is induced by microbial endotoxins and other products that activate toll-like receptors (TLRs).
    • The primary cytokine involved in the activation of this pathway is interferon-gamma.
    • Microbicidal actions that are mediated by the release of nitric oxide, reactive oxygen species, and lysosomal enzymes are the primary function of M1 macrophages.
    • Release of IL-1, IL-12, and IL-23 by M1 macrophages is involved in promoting the inflammatory response.
  • Alternate macrophage activation pathway:
    • The macrophages activated in this pathway are called M2 macrophages.
    • The activation of this pathway is induced by IL-4 and IL-13 produced by T-lymphocytes.
    • Tissue repair is the primary function mediated by growth factors and transforming growth factors-β (TGF-β).
    • Cessation of inflammation is another important function mediated by IL-10, TGF-β. 

Three subsets of CD4+ T cells secrete different types of cytokines and elicit different types of inflammation.

TH1 cells - activate macrophages by the classical pathway by secreting IFN­γ.

TH2 cells - recruit and activate eosinophils and are responsible for the alternative pathway of macrophage activation by secreting IL­4, IL­5, and IL­13.

TH17 cells - secrete IL­17 and other cytokines, which are responsible for neutrophils and monocyte recruitment.

questions.text: A young woman presents to your clinic with complaints of palpitations. Her vitals are normal. On auscultation, you hear a mid-systolic click after the first heart sound at the apex of the heart, which softens on lying down and amplifies on standing up. Which of the following is not true about her condition?

choices.text: Caused by myxomatous degeneration of the valve

questions.solution:
The statement that the murmur reduces during the Valsalva maneuver is not true. This young woman with palpitations, a mid-systolic click heard at the apex which exacerbates when standing up and improves on lying down, most probably has a diagnosis of mitral valve prolapse.

Mitral valve prolapse is a valvular heart defect in which the mitral valve leaflets are floppy and prolapse into the left atrium during ventricular contraction, making it the most common cause of primary mitral valve regurgitation. It is seen most commonly in young women and can be inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion with incomplete penetrance. 

This produces the classic mid-systolic click which is heard at the apex of the heart. The intensity of this click sound changes depending on the left ventricular (LV) volume. When LV volume increases, the floppy valve is able to maintain tension, and the degree of prolapse is reduced. Thus the intensity of the murmur reduces. On the other hand, when the LV volume is low, the mitral valve leaflets remain floppy and produce a louder click sound.

By this logic, when the patient stands up, the venous return reduces and so the LV volume decrease. This causes the murmur to become louder. On lying down, venous return increases, leading to increased LV volume and a softer murmur. On performing the Valsalva maneuver, intrathoracic pressure increases. This reduces venous return, and hence the murmur becomes louder because of reduced LV volume. 

Option A - Mitral valve prolapse is also called Barlow's syndrome or floppy valve disease.

Option B -  It is associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan's syndrome, Ehler's Danlos syndrome, and osteogenesis imperfecta.

Option C - The valve becomes floppy due to myxomatous degeneration of the valve.

The diagnosis can be made with a combination of clinical examination and transthoracic or transesophageal echocardiography. 

Treatment of these patients involves the usage of beta-blockers for palpitations. If the patient has severe symptoms due to mitral regurgitation, surgical repair is advisable. In case of prior history of endocarditis, prophylaxis for infective endocarditis should be prescribed.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of a painless lump on the lateral aspect of his left knee. The radiograph of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the given radiograph showing pedunculated growth in the metaphyseal region projecting away from the epiphysis suggest the diagnosis of osteochondroma. 

Osteochondromas are benign bone tumours that are commonly present in the adolescent age group. They usually present as painless masses in long bones like the femur or humerus. 

They are seen as well-defined bony protuberances, which may be pedunculated or sessile. Pedunculated osteochondromas point away from the joint, towards the diaphysis. The cortex and cancellous bone of osteochondroma blend with that of the host bone. MRI shows a classical cartilaginous cap. Osteochondromas usually grow with skeletal maturity and stop once growth stops.

Osteochondroma can turn into low-grade chondrosarcoma, but the malignant transformation is extremely rare. It should be suspected in the following cases:

  • Growth after skeletal maturity
  • Lucency in the bone
  • Additional scintigraphic activity
  • Cortical destruction
  • Pain after puberty
  • Soft tissue mass
  • Thickened cartilage cap >2 cm

Treatment is not indicated if the lesion does not produce symptoms. Excision can be done for large lesions with local pressure effects.

Other options:

Option A: Enchondroma is an intramedullary tumour of hyaline cartilage. They are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. They are usually seen in individuals aged 20 to 50 years in the tubular bones of the hands and feet. Radiographically, it appears as a central lesion with well-defined, rounded edges and a thin rind of reactive sclerosis.

Option B: Chondroblastoma is a benign tumour and presents as a painful mass that causes effusion or stiffness. On X-rays, they are seen as round or oval lytic lesions in the epiphysis. The bony cortex is not breached but can appear expanded. The common sites are the ends of long bones. Microscopically, chondroblastoma consists of a sheet of chondroblasts embedded in the chondroid matrix. The calcification is often present and surrounds individual cells, giving the appearance of ‘chicken wire.’

Option D: Giant cell tumour or osteoclastoma is a benign but locally aggressive tumour. It usually affects young adults, with a peak incidence in the age group of 20–45 years. It presents as a painful mass. A plain radiograph reveals an eccentric, expansile, lobulated lytic lesion in the epiphysis. There is minimal calcification within the tumour. Biopsy reveals osteoclast-like giant cells scattered among round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells.

questions.text: A multiparous woman has a previous history of birth trauma with injury to the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. According to DeLancey's classification, which level of uterine support is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey's classification, level 1 of uterine support is affected in this patient as the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments are injured.

DeLancey introduced three-level systems of genital tract supports:

  • Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Damage to these ligaments leads to uterine descent, enterocoele, and vault prolapse.
  • Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos,arcus tendineus, pubocervical, and rectovaginal fascia. Damage to these structures leads to cystocele and rectocele.
  • Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Deficient perineum
